# 1 Introduction

## 1.1 Dresden in general

Dresden is a modern city with a population of around 572,240. Dresden is located in the south-eastern part of the Free State of Saxony, which borders on German territory (Bavaria, Thuringia, Saxony-Anhalt, Brandenburg) as well as Czech and Polish territory. The layout of the city is characterised by the widening of the Elbe. Dresden is located in the border triangle of Germany, the Czech Republic and Poland on the banks of the Elbe. The foothills of the Eastern Ore Mountains, the Lusatian Granite Plateau and the Elbe Sandstone Mountains make up the attractive surroundings of the Saxon state capital. At 32,828 hectares, the city area is larger than average (fourth largest German city) and has differences in altitude of almost 200 metres. The urban structure has developed in a polycentric manner.

Today, Dresden is an important cultural city throughout Europe; its economy and population are developing dynamically. The city has the densest network of research institutions in Europe, is home to the only German university of excellence in the new federal states and is Europe's most important chip centre. Also known as the "Gateway to Central Europe", it maintains close, historically grown relations with neighbouring countries and is in intensive exchange with both eastern and western European cities.

## Population

As at 31.12.2023, Dresden had 572,240 main residents and a population density of 1,742 people per square kilometre. Dresden ranks 12th in the national comparison of major German cities. Dresden has a foreign population of approx. 12%. The population forecast 2023 extends to the year 2040, based on the population on 30 June 2023, according to which around 585,000 people would live in Dresden in 2030 and around 603,000 in mid-2040.

From January 1990 to 1998, the number of "population at the place of main residence" fell to just under 447,000 inhabitants due to emigration and relocation to neighbouring municipalities (see Figure 1-1). Out-migration and relocation to the surrounding area can be observed in two separate waves, with relocations to the surrounding area only occurring significantly in the mid-1990s as a result of increasing prosperity (particularly to enable home ownership). The incorporations carried out in 1997 and 1999 (25,483 people on 1 January 1999) partially or completely offset the aforementioned effects.

Since 1999, the population has been increasing again due to significant migration surpluses and re-urbanisation. Alongside Munich and Bonn, Dresden's population is one of the fastest growing in Germany with an annual increase of around 0.68 Percent. A slight acceleration in growth was observed until 2006. In 2006, there was even a slight surplus of births and the number of "population at the place of main residence" exceeded the 500,000 mark. As a result, the population fluctuated by more than 50,000 inhabitants within a decade. In addition to the slowdown in suburbanisation in the first years of the 21st century and the relatively high birth rate, the reason given for the (recently accelerated) increase is the second home tax, which led to the conversion of many second homes into main residences.

# Urban policy

City policy is shaped by the City Council, the Mayor and the six specialised Mayors (Deputy Mayors). A term of office lasts seven years. On 11 July 2022, the citizens of Dresden confirmed Dirk Hilbert (Unabhängige Bürger für Dresden e.V.) in his office as Mayor, which he has held since 2015, with 45.3 percent of the vote. The Dresden City Council is the elected representation of the citizens of Dresden. According to the Saxon municipal code, the Mayor chairs the City Council. The City Council lays down the principles for the administration of the City of Dresden and decides on all matters concerning the City of Dresden, unless the Mayor is responsible by law or the City Council has delegated certain matters to him. On 9 June 2024, the citizens of Dresden elected a new city council consisting of 70 honorary city councillors. The council held its first constituent meeting on 22 August 2024.

# Building stock

The building stock of the city of Dresden comprises around 70,000 buildings (see Figure 1-2). Of these, around 50 Percent are used for residential, 44 Percent for commercial and 1 Percent for public purposes. The use of the remaining 5 Percent cannot be precisely determined.

The majority of the flats were built before 1918. Many flats were also built in the GDR period from 1949 to 1990. After the reunification of Germany in 1990, extensive refurbishments were carried out in the building sector, which also greatly improved the energy efficiency of the buildings. The proportion of listed buildings in Dresden is around 10 Percent. As listed buildings can often only be refurbished to improve their energy efficiency at great expense, it is sensible and necessary to differentiate between listed and non-listed buildings in terms of energy refurbishment.

The energy supply of Dresden's buildings accounts for approx. 48 Percent of the total energy demand and approx. 43 Percent of GHG emissions (see Figure 2-1 and Figure 2-3). The energy supply of buildings is largely based on the final energy sources natural gas, electricity and district heating (see Figure 2-2). District heating, which in Dresden is based almost entirely on the use of natural gas by means of combined heat and power generation, currently contributes to the fact that the share of building energy supply in GHG is lower than in energy demand. In addition to GHG emissions, the high proportion of fossil fuels used to supply individual buildings and district heating leads to an import dependency of around 95 Percent (natural gas, heating oil) in the supply of heat to buildings.

In addition to the supply and supplier risks that can result from the high dependence on imports, Dresden is exposed to the price risks of fossil fuels on the international energy markets. This was particularly evident in the period from mid-2021 to mid-2023 for buildings supplied with natural gas and district heating. Future price risks arise primarily from CO2 pricing, which will increase, and further geopolitical conflicts. The use of local and climate-neutral energy sources will play a central role in realising a secure and affordable energy supply with the most stable prices possible in Dresden in the long term.

To achieve this, the energy requirements of buildings must be gradually reduced and - where possible and necessary - made fit for the use of climate-neutral energy sources. The greatest challenges exist in particular in the part of the existing building stock where energy efficiency is lower than in new buildings. This is often due to lower insulation and sealing standards, which result in higher heat losses, and heat distribution systems in buildings that require higher flow temperatures and are therefore less efficient when using renewable energies (RE). In new buildings, on the other hand, the German government has set the course for climate neutrality with the Building Energy Act (GEG 2024) with the minimum standard KfW55 and the requirement of at least  $65\%$  RE from 1 January 2024 in new construction areas.

# Green space and urban development

Dresden is one of the greenest cities in Europe. Around 62 Percent of the city's area is covered by forests and green spaces. The entire urban area of Dresden is characterised by numerous parks and green spaces, a rich variety of street trees, many allotment gardens and important cemeteries. Large forest and open spaces (Dresdner Heide, Altelbarm), a network of green spaces and avenues and over 400 streams as well as the Elbe, Weißeritz and Lockwitz rivers, together with the residential and commercial areas, also characterise a varied urban landscape.

Since 2000, there have been several floods of the century; heavy rainfall events are increasing, as are heat and drought, which have a negative impact on the city's ecological green network and the quality of life and health of its residents. As a green city with many green spaces, Dresden's urban area has a slight sink function (-0.64 tCO2/a) and also a large carbon reservoir. These must be preserved (damage to green infrastructure leads to higher emissions of the released carbon). The large watercourses should also contribute to the utilisation of heat sources (river heat pumps).

The cultural landscape of the Dresden Elbe Valley was included in the UNESCO World Heritage Programme in 2006. For many Dresdeners, the Elbe Valley area, which is exposed to views, must not be disturbed. Conversely, this has an impact on infrastructure projects such as bridge construction (as a result of which Dresden lost its World Heritage title) and/or the construction of wind turbines and ground-mounted photovoltaics.

The settlement area is made up of buildings and open spaces, recreational areas and cemeteries, so it cannot be equated with the actual degree of sealing, but it does represent the degree of urbanisation. Agricultural land in particular, on the other hand, is steadily decreasing. This is all the more problematic as this often involves high-quality soils. From a soil protection perspective, land consumption is still far too high and jeopardises the German government's goal of allowing only 30 hectares per day of land consumption by 2030. Broken down linearly to Dresden, the city is likely to take up around ten hectares a year. Aerial and satellite images are used to determine the actual land sealing across the entire area. From the long-term trend since 2010, it can be deduced that the heavily sealed areas (60 - 100 Percent) are increasing by around 46 hectares per year. This is taking place both at the expense of already moderately and lightly sealed areas with densification and gap development, as well as through the utilisation of open spaces. When land is utilised for development and sealing, particular emphasis is placed in urban land-use planning on space-saving construction and compliance with the specified floor area ratios of 1 and 2.

# Transport

Dresden has a transport system that is efficient in its basic features and also largely meets future requirements, especially for public transport and motorised traffic. After the political change in 1990, one of the greatest challenges was to integrate the Dresden conurbation into the European transport network. Over the last 30 years, enormous efforts have therefore been made in Dresden to expand the transport infrastructure, which has had a considerable impact on today's traffic flows in the Dresden urban area.

For example, the following should be emphasised:

# (Extension) construction of motorways e.g. Expansion of the A 4 motorway in the city of Dresden including the new Elbe bridge, new construction of the A 17 Dresden - Prague motorway including the corresponding motorway feeder roads, # Complete expansion of new S-Bahn lines, new construction of S-Bahn stops, renovation of Dresden main station and Neustadt station as well as numerous other stations and stops, Construction of Terminal II at Dresden Airport including better connections to the road network and the S-Bahn # Construction and renovation of Elbe bridges in the city area, # Renovation/expansion of efficient transport trains in the main urban road network and numerous other public transport lines, # Construction of new tram lines, renovation of main inner-city roads with special consideration of local public transport, # Facilities for cycling and pedestrian traffic were built and improved (e.g. section-by-section construction of the new Elbe bridge) B. construction of new sections of the Elbe cycle path, gradual expansion of cycle paths as part of the main road network, marking of cycle lanes and hard shoulders in the main road network, construction of numerous new cycle parking facilities, barrier-free design of the footpath network and traffic-calming actions).

Other projects realised include Realisation of underground car parks/parking garages in the city centre, development of a dynamic parking guidance system, expansion of the Dresden traffic control centre

Today, Dresden is structurally very well integrated into the national and international transport networks:

The city is directly connected to all neighbouring regional centres and metropolitan regions via the A 4, A 13 and A 17 motorways (Greater Berlin, Leipzig/Halle, Chemnitz and the Nuremberg metropolitan region, the Prague conurbation and Wroclaw).
The long-distance railway lines (Hamburg -) Berlin - Dresden - Prague - Vienna, Frankfurt am Main - Leipzig - Dresden and Hanover - Leipzig - Dresden are important in the long-distance rail network. The route to Wroclaw should also be mentioned.
In the regional rail network, the main and medium-sized centres are connected to the Dresden regional centre as a link to long-distance transport.
In the long-distance bus network, various transport companies offer regular connections from Dresden main station or Dresden-Neustadt to destinations in Germany and abroad.
The regional bus network covers the western part of the district of Sächsische Schweiz-Osterzgebirge, parts of the districts of Meißen and Bautzen and the City of Dresden.
The Elbe is a 1st class federal waterway (class Va) and connects Dresden with the inland ports of central Germany and the German North Sea ports.
Dresden has a commercial airport. In 2023, Dresden Airport had a passenger volume of around 921,400 passengers.
With the German routes D4 (Mittelland Route) and D10 (Elbe Cycle Route), Dresden is well connected in terms of supra-regional cycle traffic. With the city centre cycling concept, a classified municipal cycle route network with main, connecting and access routes has also been in place since 2007 and is being successively implemented in the city centre.
In terms of pedestrian traffic, Dresden is integrated into national hiking trails such as the Way of St James, as well as regional routes such as the Saxon Wine Trail or the Malerweg.

Traffic in Dresden has increased in connection with the dynamic urban development of recent years. The city has succeeded in absorbing this significant increase in traffic primarily through environmental transport (public transport, cycle paths and footpaths). Motor vehicle traffic fell slightly despite the growing population. The main reasons for this are: i) distances have been shortened due to the increase in population density and the supply infrastructure for daily needs has improved, ii) road infrastructure close to the city has been improved, iii) further expansion of the S-Bahn, iv) the public transport system has been continuously optimised, v) the cycling infrastructure is being gradually expanded, vi) the importance and share of cycling has increased considerably, which is also due to a change in image

The development of mobility and transport in recent years can be described on the basis of an excellent database that Dresden has at its disposal. One of the most important sources for this is the regular mobility survey "System repräsentativer Verkehrsbefragungen (SrV)" of the Technical University (TU Dresden). Dresden has been taking part in the survey, which is repeated every five years, since 1972. The most recent SrV survey took place in 2023. The results are expected at the end of 2024. In addition, a total of 42 permanent counting points spread across the entire city of Dresden automatically record motor vehicle traffic. Dresden's public transport operators collect data on the use of local public transport by systematically counting passengers. # Economy

In 2022, Dresden was home to around 36,800 companies from a wide range of economic sectors, such as manufacturing, construction, trade, transport, hospitality, information and communication, financial and insurance services, real estate and housing, etc. The economy of the CoD is characterised by a correspondingly high level of industry diversity. A strategically important chip industry for the whole of Europe is located in the north of Dresden.

Following the economic and financial crisis in 2008/2009, positive economic development was recorded until 2019. In 2020, the effects of the coronavirus pandemic led to a remarkable 1.1 Percent decline in value added. The service sector accounted for the lion's share of value added in 2020 at around 77 Percent, with the manufacturing industry accounting for around 17 Percent and the construction industry around 6 Percent. Based on the figures available to date, it is not possible to determine whether there has been a recovery in value added over the past two years. However, it can be assumed that the value added of Dresden's companies will continue to rise. In the manufacturing sector in particular, this is generally associated with an impact on resource consumption and the associated GHG emissions.

The semiconductor industry is also of particular importance for Dresden's energy requirements. Well-known companies in this future-oriented industry and this important economic sector in Dresden include Infineon, Global Foundries, Bosch and possibly Jenoptik and ESMC in the future. The semiconductor industry has a relatively high electricity requirement for its production processes, with typical consumption processes including room cooling, process cooling water, compressed air generation, ultrapure water preparation, building vacuum and lighting in addition to the main production process. In 2018, the semiconductor industry already accounted for 16 Percent (approx. 420 GWh/a) of Dresden's electricity consumption in the public distribution grid. It also accounted for 33 Percent (approx. 1,397 GWh/a) of Dresden's natural gas consumption, although this is mainly due to power plant consumption for electricity generation directly at the factory site. Since then, the Bosch semiconductor plant has been added in 2021 and an expansion of the Infineon semiconductor plant is currently under construction. The semiconductor industry's electricity consumption from the public electricity distribution grid increased by 29 Percent to approx. 543 GWh/a between 2018 and 2022. The semiconductor industry's future expansion and relocation projects will result in further significant growth.

# 1.2 Current climate neutrality target in Dresden and current resolutions:

Dresden has been actively involved in climate protection for many years and set an important course for sustainable development at an early stage. As early as the 1990s, the city began networking at an international level and formulating ambitious climate targets. Through continuous actions, such as the preparation of climate protection reports and the establishment of the climate protection office, concrete steps were taken to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and combat climate change. Dresden's most important milestones on the road to climate-friendly urban development are listed below.

Decision of the Conference of Aldermen on the subject of the resolution "Membership of City of Dresden in the International Council for Local Environmental Initiatives (ICLEI) and in the Saxon Network of Environmental Experts (SENU)

The Integrated Energy and Climate Protection Plan (IEuKK) from 2013 represents the City of Dresden's current resolutions on climate protection. The IEuKK set Dresden the target of reducing GHG emissions by 10% every five years from 2005 to 2030. Since 2013, the framework conditions, technological standards and market conditions have changed considerably (including developments in gas and energy prices and CO2 pricing) and awareness of advancing climate change and its social consequences has increased enormously. Against this background, the update of the Integrated Energy und Climate Protection Plan (IEuKK) from 2013 was initiated by the City Council resolution on motion A0011/19 (SR/007/2020) "Update of the climate protection goals of the City of Dresden" of 30 January 2020. The 2020 city council resolution set the goal of climate neutrality well before 2050. This was the first time that a concrete target for green house gas neutrality was set and a political mandate for achievable green house gas neutrality was introduced. Climate protection was named as a task of the highest priority, which should go hand in hand with municipal welfare and the social compatibility of actions.

In addition to the application for the EU mission, which was initiated by the city administration, the 2035 target for Dresden's climate neutrality was demanded in 2022 via a citizens' petition by Dresden Zero.

# 1.3 Other CCC-relevant strategies and projects:

# Municipal heat planning

CoD has set itself the goal of making the complex transformation process towards an affordable, secure and climate-neutral heat supply manageable and creating planning security for all stakeholders involved by means of municipal heat planning. The result is the municipal heat planning with a corresponding action portfolio for implementation. Parallel processes, particularly in the area of the municipal energy supplier SachsenEnergie AG, and different perspectives of the urban society are brought together. This dovetailing of concepts relevant to energy and climate protection is essential and is to be ensured in particular through coordinated strategic network planning across all energy networks. This also includes a revision and concretisation of the future expansion and densification area for district heating on the basis of the heat transformation plan, as well as the integration of findings from the process of the gas grid area transformation plan and the electricity grid expansion plan.

# Dresden Mobility Plan (SUMP)

Parallel to the update of the IEK, the current Transport Development Plan 2025plus, which was adopted by the City Council in 2014, is currently being updated. The new plan is entitled Dresden Mobility Plan  $2035+$  (DMP  $2035+$ ). More recent city council resolutions and changes to the general conditions are being incorporated into this update process. These include the Clean Air Plan, the Green City Plan, a CO2 reduction in the transport sector, "Vision Zero", the implementation of the cycling concept and the pedestrian transport strategy as well as a target of 30 Percent public transport share adopted by the city council.

The DMP  $2035+$  is being developed in three phases. Phase I Objectives: Analysis and evaluation and definition of new key objectives; Phase II Scenarios: Fields of action and proposed actions, drafting development scenarios with evaluation of target achievement, drafting a preferred scenario with actions. Phase III Concept development: Mobility strategy for the period up to 2035 and beyond, drawing up actions up to 2035 in an action plan.

The dovetailing of the IEK with the DMP2035+ is coordinated through strategic cooperation. The balancing of GHG emissions in the DMP 2035+ is carried out in accordance with the BISKO standard in order to balance congruently with the IEK. The starting year here is 2018 because 2018 serves as the year of analysis for the DMP 2035+ and data for both the transport model and CO2 emissions in the transport sector were already available at the time the concept was commissioned. For further information, see 3.2.2.

Integrated urban development concept:

The integrated urban development concept "Future Dresden 2035+" is the city-wide and overarching strategy of the City of Dresden for managing the city's development, geared towards the 2035 planning horizon. It identifies cross-thematic key objectives for urban development and localises important key projects and actions in the priority areas. It is created in collaboration with all of the city's specialist departments. On 2 March 2023, the City Council adopted the 2nd update of the paper.

The City of Dresden is aware of its responsibility for globally sustainable development and is committed to the United Nations 2030 Agenda with its 17 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). By integrating the SDGs into the update of the INSEK, the City of Dresden is emphasising its contribution and the importance of the UN Sustainable Development Goals for further urban development. In the INSEK, the City of Dresden also commits itself to the visions of a "productive", "green" and "just city" of the New Leipzig Charter as a "compact city in an ecological network" (strategic model of the 2018 landscape plan, Environmental Agency of the City of Dresden, LandschaftsArchitekt Paul).

# Decarbonisation concept of SachsenEnergie AG

The conversion and expansion of the district heating system requires considerable financial and human resources, but these are limited. The individual potentials must therefore be examined and qualified for implementation step by step. Permanent monitoring of the economic feasibility of the individual decarbonisation potentials and the achievement of the target of complete decarbonisation of district heating in Dresden can be used to determine an optimal and constantly updated decarbonisation path. The basis for this continuous monitoring are scenarios and price time series from a fundamental model to map possible developments, which are adapted to the current political framework conditions, as well as a heat demand forecast for the city of Dresden.

To decarbonise district heating, SachsenEnergie AG is currently planning the implementation of various potentials, which are presented as milestones up to the year 2045. In order to achieve green house gas

# Climate change adaptation concept:

The IEK forms an interface with many other CoD planning strategies. Above all, this includes the climate change adaptation concept currently being developed under the leadership of the Environment Agency. The climate change adaptation concept describes how climatic changes affect the natural resources in Dresden and what risks this poses for the urban space and for those living, working and visiting the city. The main areas of action are the water balance in the city, the vitality of urban greenery and human health. For these key areas of action, the potential risks are identified at neighbourhood level and actions are developed to reduce the risks and thus make the city more resilient to the impacts of climate change. In the implementation section, target group-specific recommendations are given on how the climate adaptation measures can be effectively implemented. Completion of the climate adaptation concept is planned for 2024. The climate adaptation concept also incorporates existing project results from climate change adaptation projects.

An overview can be found here: Adapting to the climate | City of Dresden

# Heat action plan:

The City of Dresden is currently drawing up a heat action plan to prevent health consequences and to respond to the increasing heat stress in the summer months as a result of climate change. This takes into account comprehensive intervention measures for health protection. Behavioural and situational preventative actions are intended to reduce heat stress and UV exposure and prevent damage to health. The heat action plan shows which municipal facilities are involved and when which actions take effect.

# 1.4.1 Basics CCC:

As shown above, the City of Dresden has strategies relevant to the CCC that have been developed in various participatory processes and are being implemented in pilot actions and innovative projects. The preparation of the Climate City Contract in Dresden overlaps in terms of content and timing with the
#

Dresden. Dresden

Dresden action plan for climate neutrality in 2030

#

updating of relevant city strategies and integrates these into the Action and Investment Plan. The content of the Action Plan is based on the Integrated Energy and Climate Protection Concept (IEK) as the overarching climate protection strategy of the City of Dresden. The Climate Protection and Adaptation Unit is responsible for updating the plan. The creation of the CCC is coordinated across departments in the Office for Urban Strategy, International Affairs and Citizenship within the Mayor's portfolio.

# 1.4.2 Integration of Dresden climate targets and Ambition 2030:

In all resolutions on Dresden's climate strategy, the City of Dresden is clearly committed to the process of transformation and the goal of becoming a climate-neutral city. As part of the update of the Integrated Energy and Climate Protection Plan (IEK) adopted in 2020, the initial situation in Dresden was quantified and described by means of a comprehensive inventory. The basis for the objectives in the IEK and thus in the CCC is the commitment to a greenhouse gas-neutral city.

In the municipal context in particular, there are different definitions compared to the global or national context due to different accounting boundaries and local requirements. The IEK correctly uses the term GHG-neutrality for the target. This refers in particular to the energy requirements for heat, electricity and production processes as well as the energy sources and infrastructures used. Based on this initial analysis, the Dresden Climate Protection Concept (IEK) considers three scenarios for achieving GHG-neutrality: two target scenarios, in accordance with the City Council resolution (V1818/22) to achieve GHG-neutrality by 2035 and alternatively by 2040, as well as a reference scenario in which the current federal policy targets are achieved by 2045. The results of the potential analyses have been incorporated into the possible reduction paths for the three previously defined scenarios. As a result, the minimum target of GHG-neutrality by 2040 is proposed in accordance with the reduction path of the 2040 target scenario. The background to this is that achieving the target of climate neutrality by 2035 is not feasible even in the 2035 target scenario with the existing potential and implementation options as well as the external framework conditions. Specifically, for the reduction path presented in the IEK, this means an  $80\%$  reduction by 2030 compared to 1990 (as an interim target for EU city emissions) or absolute emission values of -2,019,200 tCO2 $_{\text{eq}}$  compared to 2018. This would leave 1,586,900 tCO2 $_{\text{eq}}$  in 2030, which would be reduced to 329,900 tCO2 $_{\text{eq}}$  by 2040, which is defined as the GHG neutrality level for Dresden (Figure 1-5). The target covers the entire urban area and is set as a fixed value regardless of population growth. In addition, there is a  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  budget that is checked for compliance as part of monitoring and controlling.

The city-wide target is thus set for 2040, with an acceleration to 2035 if possible. From today's perspective, the framework conditions are not good enough for green house gas neutrality by 2030. This would require:

Availability of renewable electricity by 2030
Concerns about green hydrogen for industry and peak-load power plants in the urban area by 2030
Sufficient personnel capacities in craft businesses, planning offices, companies and administration to implement the necessary actions and projects by 2030.

In parts of Dresden, neighbourhoods and various locations could already be greenhouse gas neutral before 2035 and serve as Field tests that can then achieve a scaling effect. These include the Neutral Path projects and other city neighbourhoods as well as parts of the city administration.

# 2 Part A - Current status of climate protection

## 2.1 Module A-1 Baseline inventory of greenhouse gas emissions

### 2.1.1 GHG accounting method

The central element of monitoring the city's climate protection strategy is the city-wide energy and greenhouse gas (GHG) inventory. This forms the basis for quantitative city-wide climate protection monitoring. Regular updates allow long-term developments in the use of energy sources, final energy consumption and GHG emissions to be identified. The GHG inventory is compiled and published by the Climate Protection and Adaptation Unit.

The BISKO methodology focuses on energy consumption and the resulting GHG emissions in the territory of the municipality. In particular, this makes the progress made in reducing energy demand in a municipality visible. In order to evaluate the effectiveness of climate protection, factors such as population growth, economic development and weather influences are taken into account in the form of further analyses. The balance makes major changes visible and shows trends, whereby small fluctuations cannot be clearly assessed as successes or failures of climate protection activities due to overlapping effects. The GHG inventory is a monitoring method at the top-down level. In addition to the GHG inventory, numerous potential studies in the area of buildings were carried out last year or are currently being carried out, which provide the basis for municipal heat planning and further area planning for RE. Based on this data, the actions for the action portfolio of the current IEK and the action programme to be continued have been and are being drawn up.

The last published GHG inventory covers the reporting year 2018, which is now far in the past, meaning that no current GHG inventory is available for the city of Dresden for the last three years. In 2024, the GHG inventory will be updated for the reporting years 2019-2022. This involves setting up a process with the help of external service providers that makes it possible to submit the balance sheet annually and according to fixed procedures. It should be noted that due to the availability of data and statistics, the current balance sheet can generally only be prepared for the year before last (e.g. in 2024, the balance sheet year 2022).

Since the 2017 reporting year, the state capital of Dresden, like many German cities and municipalities, has been reporting using the municipal reporting system (BISKO). Prior to this (until 2016), GHGs were accounted for using a separate methodology, which was based on BISKO but used its own emission factors in some cases. At that time, transport was also accounted for according to the national and not the territorial principle.

CoD uses the Climate Alliance's climate protection planner to calculate GHG emissions in accordance with BISKO. The calculation logic is based on the territorial principle - only the emissions in the urban area are considered. By using the same methodology, it is possible to compare local authorities in Germany with each other. In contrast to the presentation up to 2016, the BISKO balance sheet is no longer recorded per inhabitant, but in absolute GHG emissions. The published figures are also not weather-adjusted. This is provided for in the BISKO system.

In the BISKO system, the private households, trade/commerce/services/other and industry sectors as well as municipal facilities are included in the GHG inventory as sub-sectors of stationary energy and the transport sector. For the categorisation according to the GHG Protocol, the "stationary energy" sector corresponds to the "buildings" sector. The private households, trade/commerce/services/other and
#

Dresden. DIREC

Dresden action plan for climate neutrality in 2030

#

industry and municipal facilities sectors include the energy requirements of buildings, while the industry sector is primarily characterised by expenditure on process energy.

The GHG emission factors are taken from the GEMIS database and calculations by the ifeu Institute and made available to the municipalities via the "Klimaschutzplaner (Software)" software,

In the context of the municipal GHG inventory in Dresden, commercial energy requirements are summarised under the generic term "economy", which includes the industrial and commercial/trade/services sectors and others (e.g. public facilities that are not municipally owned). The subdivision of the industry and trade/commerce/services sectors was defined in consultation with the Dresden energy supplier when the Integrated Energy and Climate Protection Plan (IEuKK) was drawn up in 2013. However, it should be noted that this categorisation no longer fully corresponds to the current data from the supplier. It is therefore necessary to revise the categorisation in order to be able to make more precise differentiations. The differentiation between energy consumption in the commercial/trade/service and industrial sectors is primarily based on the supply tariffs, whereby the industrial sector is predominantly considered a large consumer and the differentiation is based on load band measurement. Despite the necessary reworking, the breakdown into the various sectors and areas represents additional information to the actual balance of urban GHG emissions. It is important to note that this breakdown has no influence on the total sum of final energy requirements and GHG emissions, but rather serves to provide detailed insights into the specific energy requirements of the various economic sectors. In the course of updating the GHG inventory in 2024, a new system for differentiating between these two sectors is to be agreed with the energy supplier as the data provider.

The current public GHG inventory shows the energy requirements and GHG emissions for the last five years. The following figures show the diagrams for final energy consumption (Figure 2-1) and GHG emissions (Figure 2-3) for the years 2013 to 2018 according to the BISKO methodology.

Final energy consumption in the city of Dresden barely fell between 2013 and 2018 (-2.5 % in 2018 compared to 2013). In the energy and green house gas inventory, there is a lack of clarity regarding non-pipeline-based energy sources in the stationary sector (heating oil, coal, liquid gas). To determine this consumption, which accounts for around  $4\%$  of energy consumption, data from district chimney sweeps is used, which is reported to the state office (LfULG) every five years and analysed there. The latest data from 2015 is shown in the balance sheet. Due to a lack of more recent data available from the City of Dresden in 2022, a constant number of combustion plants is taken into account in the balance sheet years up to 2018. The integration of more recent data could lead to a reduction in consumption, as the replacement of old heating systems with new ones and the associated efficiency gains are not taken into account in the figures shown here. This also has an impact on the GHG emissions shown below, as oil and coal heating systems are generally replaced with gas boilers or renewable energy systems, thereby reducing the GHG emissions caused. However, the trend shown of almost constant energy consumption is also accompanied by an average population growth of  $1\%$  per year. The largest share of energy consumption is in the business sector (trade and industry, as well as public, non-municipal facilities). This sector accounts for a total of  $47\%$  of final energy demand. Private households account for  $28\%$  of the final energy demand. Municipal buildings account for approx.  $2\%$ . This means that the stationary sector accounts for approx.  $77\%$  of the city's total final energy demand. The mobility/transport sector accounts for  $23\%$  of the final energy demand. The building energy sector requires approx.  $46\%$  of final energy. Process energy accounts for  $29\%$  of the city's final energy demand.

The energy sources used in the city (see Figure 2-2) are mainly natural gas with a share of  $34\%$ , electricity with a share of approx.  $24\%$  and district heating with  $15\%$  of the total final energy demand. It should be noted that almost  $100\%$  of district heating is generated from natural gas in CHP plants. The local electricity mix is also characterised to a large extent by natural gas CHP. Fossil fuels account for  $23\%$  of the city's final energy demand. Renewables are still of minor importance, accounting for  $1\%$  of the heat supply (based on the data sources available to the City of Dresden).

GHG emissions in the city of Dresden fell slightly between 2013 and 2018 (-7.5% in 2018 compared to 2013). In 2018, total GHG emissions amounted to approx. 3.5 million tonnes CO2_eq. However, the trend shown of only slightly decreasing GHG emissions is also accompanied by an average population growth of 1% per year. The largest share of emissions is in the business sector (trade and industry, as well as public, non-municipal facilities). This sector accounts for a total of 51% of final energy demand. This is primarily due to the high electricity demand of the economy, especially industry, and the comparatively high specific emission factor of the reference electricity. Private households account for 24% of the final energy demand. Municipal buildings account for approx. 2%. This means that the stationary sector accounts for approx. 77% of the city's total final energy demand. The mobility/transport sector accounts for 23% of the final energy demand. The building energy sector is responsible for approx. 41% of GHG emissions. Process energy accounts for 34% of GHG emissions. District heating, which in Dresden is based almost entirely on the use of natural gas by means of combined heat and power generation, currently contributes to the fact that the share of building energy supply in GHG is lower than in energy demand.

The energy sources causing GHG emissions in the city (see Figure 2-4 : Greenhouse gas emissions 2018 in tCO2,eq broken down by energy source and sectorFigure 2-4Figure 2-2) are mainly electricity with a share of approx.  $40\%$ , natural gas with a share of  $26\%$  and district heating with  $7\%$  of total emissions in the city area. It should be noted that almost  $100\%$  of district heating is generated from natural gas in CHP plants. The local electricity mix is also characterised by high proportions of natural gas CHP. Fossil fuels for mobility account for  $23\%$  of the city's emissions.

Emissions were significantly reduced from 1990 until the 2000s. This is largely due to the switch from coal to natural gas for heating and district heating. The construction of the "Nosserer Brücke" combined heat and power plant, which went into operation in 1995 and replaced the old lignite-fired power plant, made a major contribution to this. In contrast to other sectors, GHG emissions in the mobility sector in both Germany and Dresden have remained more or less the same since the 1990s. This is largely due to the fact that although engines have become more efficient, the efficiency gains have been eliminated as rebound effects due to growing transport performance and a sharp increase in vehicle weight and power. In addition, more than 93 Percent of the final energy demand for transport is still covered by fossil fuels (as of 2019).

It should be noted that the development of past years cannot necessarily be compared, as the balancing in the respective years is based on different methods and the results differ in some cases (a comparison of the methodology up to 2016 and BISKO from 2017 onwards showed a difference of approx. 3 t/EW/a). The two methodological approaches are therefore analysed in parallel for the available years in Figure 2-5 are shown in parallel for the available years. The collection of data in the past according to the BISKO methodology will be examined in 2024. This can be done to the extent that historical data is available in full (possibly going back to 2010). The originally published balances should not be overwritten, but the difference between the two methods should be clarified and the development trend should be easier to understand.

However, it should be noted that the reference values (1990 and 2005) used as a basis in the following chapters of the Action Plan for the Dresden target have a different methodological approach than the current baseline inventory. These differences can no longer be corrected from this point in time. The development is therefore also characterised by a proportion of the change in methodology (approx. 1.5 t/EW/a for the stationary sector and approx. 1.2 t/EW/a for the transport sector).

## Subsidiary balance sheet agriculture

Methane and nitrous oxide are mainly produced by cattle during digestion. In agriculture, nutrient management (slurry, liquid manure, plastic fertiliser, liming) determines the level of GHG emissions. Water management can also be decisive. Drained moors and wetlands are a source of  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ . At present, the emissions from this Fields of action are not recorded in the urban balance sheet using BISKO. In an initial rough assessment, the IEK estimated GHG emissions of around 3,800 tonnes per year for livestock in 2020 and around 13,000 tonnes per year for agriculture (based on an agricultural area of 4,973 hectares). A brief methodological explanation can be found in 6.4. This means that the non-energy-related emissions for agricultural use are well below 20,000 tCO2 $_{\text{eq/a}}$ , which is very low compared to the current energy-related GHG emissions of more than 3 million tCO2 $_{\text{eq/a}}$ . In future, however, these GHG emissions will also play an increasing role in achieving GHG-neutrality in the urban area. It is planned to report these non-energy-related GHG emissions in the future as part of the GHG inventory.

## 2.1.3 Process for regularly updating the GHG inventory and expansion of emission sources

### 2.1.3.1 Process for regularly updating the GHG inventory

For the regular preparation of the annual green house gas inventory, the data stocks and recording system for the BISKO balance sheet and other subsidiary balances will be processed in 2024. Existing data and recording tables (Excel) will be used as part of the inventory processing. If necessary, the data collection tables are to be further developed, provided that the cost of further development does not exceed the cost of creating a new data collection system from scratch. Data recorded includes

Queries about energy demand and generation at the energy supplier (with the query centralised as far as possible),
Queries on energy requirements of the city administration,
Reports from chimney sweeps to the State Office for the Environment, Agriculture and Geology (LfULG), which collects the data tables on combustion sites every five years and makes them available to the CoD.

The review serves to provide orientation and identify the necessary documents and query tools for systematic and timely annual GHG balancing. In addition, it is planned to develop a proposal for continuous monitoring of energy consumption based on renewable energy sources, for which no continuous and comprehensive data set is currently available. However, their increasing use must also be reflected in the GHG inventory in order to visualise the switch from fossil fuels to renewable energy sources.

In order to drive forward the preparation and systematisation, questions about the data and its classification logic are to be discussed with the processors at energy suppliers and the municipal administration as part of a workshop. The aim is to find an agreed variant for recording and categorising the data in the logic of the climate protection planner (or BISKO methodology) for trade/commerce/services and others, industry, municipal facilities and private households. In addition, the workshop will be used to coordinate the necessary schedules and record them in a process overview for the annual preparation of the GHG inventory. This includes the duration of data delivery and the possible date of publication of the GHG inventory. Synergies are also to be created with the topic of GHG-neutral city administration (GHG inventory of the core administration) in order to avoid duplicate data queries. The development of the energy management system and the acquisition of new energy data software will also help to provide the information required for the GHG inventory in a timely manner.

## BISKO methodology and its limitations in GHG accounting

The BISKO methodology proves to be inadequate for the presentation of GHG-neutrality, as it is based exclusively on the recording of energy-based GHG emissions and ignores non-energy emissions from waste, wastewater, agriculture, industrial processes and product use. As a result, the methodological limitations mean that specific climate protection efforts, such as the local expansion of renewable energies for electricity supply, do not appear in the BISKO main balance sheet, as this is calculated exclusively with reference electricity. However, the majority of GHG emissions are recorded via the energy share, so that the BISKO method in its current form can sufficiently show the necessary GHG reductions for the coming years.

The system of the BISKO territorial balance is also limited, as it is not able to visualise emissions caused by Dresden's citizens outside the city area. This approach is only comprehensive if all territories use the same GHG accounting system. As things stand today, this is not yet the case.

## Necessity of additions through subsidiary balances

In view of these limitations, it is proposed to supplement the GHG inventory according to BISKO (main inventory) with additional secondary inventories. These secondary balances are intended to show specific developments that cannot be adequately taken into account in the main balance. The integration of secondary balances enables comprehensive top-down monitoring, which allows a more precise depiction of the sum of local climate protection activities. This initially includes

Subsidiary balance transport national principle (previously part of the GHG inventory until 2017),
balance for emissions from agriculture,

balance for emissions from waste,

Further subsidiary balances are to be added once sufficient data and methods for the municipal level have been clarified in order to be able to include other emission sources in the GHG inventory. It should also be noted that the municipal GHG inventory is not the sole indicator of successful climate protection activities in the city. Rather, a system of different assessment standards and levels is required in order to properly reflect the complexity of climate protection efforts.

## Outlook and further development

It can be assumed that the BISKO methodology will be further developed to enable municipalities to present GHG-neutrality in their municipal balance sheets. In this context, the CoD will actively participate in the Climate Alliance working groups and maintain an intensive dialogue with other municipalities and the developers of the climate protection planner. This committed participation should help to promote future adjustments to the methodology and thus enable improved and standardised mapping of climate protection measures at municipal level.

## Shares of energy and non-energy emissions

Figure 2-6 shows an overview of the shares of energy and non-energy emissions in the national GHG inventory in Germany². This shows that energy-related emissions account for the largest share of GHG emissions, but that non-energy-related emissions must also be taken into account for GHG-neutrality. For a large city like Dresden, the proportion of energy-related emissions is likely to be even higher than the German average due to its urban character. However, there is no data on this that can be analysed at municipal level. Therefore, only the nationwide statistics can be used to assess the impact.

# Agriculture:

At present, emissions in the Fields of action of agriculture are not recorded in the urban balance sheet using BISKO. An initial rough estimate of emissions from this area was presented in the IEK. As a result, GHG emissions currently play a subordinate role compared to the city's total emissions. In the future, however, these GHG emissions will also have to be considered in order to achieve GHG-neutrality in the city. It is planned to report these non-energy-related GHG emissions in future as part of the GHG inventory. The methodology for this still needs to be analysed in more detail. However, the simple calculation of the climate protection planner based on federal key figures can be used as a minimum.

# Waste and wastewater:

The preparation of a GHG inventory for the waste sector in accordance with the Greenhouse Gas Protocol requires a systematic approach, taking into account emission scopes 1 and 3. This is necessary in order to obtain a complete picture of GHG emissions in the context of GHG-neutrality, as only energy-related emissions have been assessed in the municipal balance sheet to date.

With regard to the accounting framework, all direct GHG emissions caused by the direct incineration of waste or by landfills, although these hardly play a role in Germany any more, should be recorded. Indirect emissions from external sources, such as the production and disposal of products in waste, as well as transport in connection with waste management, should also be taken into account.

To date, there is no established and standardised methodology for balancing GHG emissions from waste in a municipal context. The BISKO methodology used for the municipal GHG inventory only takes into account the GHG emission factor of district heating or the local electricity mix for the possible use of residual waste for heat and electricity production. Assessment methods for GHG emissions resulting from other forms of utilisation or not from the local incineration of residual waste do not yet exist. A standardised methodology (analogous to the BISKO methodology or as a further development of it) must first be agreed at a higher level. Standardisation leads to comparability between municipalities
#

Dresden. 1

Dresden action plan for climate neutrality in 2030

#

and makes it possible to use standardised assessment factors. In particular, definitions of the interfaces (spatial, organisational, municipal/commercial) are required. A complicating factor here is that the waste management sector operates in supra-regional structures after collection.

In addition to defining a standardised methodology, the comprehensive collection of data poses a major challenge. Due to the separate collection of the different types of waste and the commissioning of different waste disposal companies alone, the CoD does not have all waste quantities and transport routes. Only once the methodology and thus also the accounting framework have been clarified can it be checked which data is available in municipal hands or must be procured by adapting contracts or which data must be provided to the municipalities from the higher-level collection system (e.g. dual systems).

Once these fundamental issues have been clarified, the GHG inventory for the waste management sector can be drawn up. This would require external support, at least for the initial balance (initial set-up of the calculation logic). For this step, it would also be important to subsequently balance the year 1990 according to a similar methodology in order to evaluate the GHG emissions from waste with regard to the GHG reduction already achieved and still to be achieved by the target year of GHG-neutrality. Once the methodology has been set up and the balance drawn up, a process is to be set up with which the GHG inventory for waste can be regularly updated.

# Industrial processes (non-energetic)

There is no statistical data available at municipal level to record non-energy emissions from industrial and commercial processes or product utilisation. An initial approach that Dresden can pursue in the coming years is the use of national indicators and the extrapolation of these on the basis of economic data (knowledge of economic sectors) in Dresden. This methodology must be developed and it must be checked that the data sources used for this can also be retrieved regularly and consistently in terms of data volume.

structure of the Table 2- are not available and cannot be presented without further adjustment. It is planned to present the balance sheet to the public in autumn 2024. For this reason, the figures for the GHG inventory - in the form in which the CoD has communicated to the public to date - are included here for information purposes. It should be noted that 2018 remains the base year of the IEK reduction pathway and the potentials shown continue to relate to this. The process described above (see 2.1.3) to prepare the database has been carried out in the form described below in order to update the BISKO balance sheet and ensure consistency. In the further process up to the end of the year, further details will be agreed with data providers and the updatability of the balance sheet will be ensured.

The city of Dresden has prepared its GHG inventory in accordance with BISKO for the year 2022. The presentation covers the period from 2013 to 2022 and provides a consistent analysis of the city's greenhouse gas emissions over ten years. This is shown below for absolute emissions. It should be noted that there are changes to the historical values as a result of the revision of the data sources and consistency: The GHG inventories for the years 2013 to 2018 were adjusted retrospectively. This was necessary because a new data set from the chimney sweeps was available for 2021, which was combined with the data for 2015. This led to slight adjustments and a change in the timing of the non-pipe-based energy sources. In addition, new, more plausible values were taken into account in the energy consumption of the central heating and cogeneration plants, which also led to adjustments. Slight shifts were made in the allocation of sectors - in particular from industry to private households. In addition, a new data set for solar thermal systems was implemented.

# Key messages of the new balance sheet

Stagnation of emissions: Greenhouse gas emissions in Dresden have only changed marginally since 2013. Over the entire period from 2013 to 2022, emissions have fallen by around  $8\%$ . This reduction is mainly due to improvements in the German electricity mix up to 2020. However, emissions
#

Dresden. Dresdner

Dresden action plan for climate neutrality in 2030

#

rose again slightly in 2021 and 2022 due to external factors such as increased coal-fired power generation and reduced use of wind energy.

Energy consumption: Energy consumption in Dresden has remained at a relatively constant level since 2013, with a marginal decrease since 2018. This small change illustrates that the actions taken so far are not yet sufficient to have a significant and steady impact on overall energy consumption and thus on emissions.
Influence of the German electricity mix: Around 32% of urban energy consumption is accounted for by the electricity sector, which is heavily dependent on the emission factors of the German electricity mix. While the emission factor of the electricity mix fell continuously until 2020, it rose again in 2021 and 2022. This increase has a significant impact on the overall balance of the city of Dresden and shows the city's dependence on supra-regional developments.

## Sectoral distribution of emissions:

Transport: The transport sector accounts for around a quarter of the city's total greenhouse gas emissions. The share of this sector has increased slightly in recent years, which is due to the fact that renewable energies are increasingly being used in the stationary sector, while the transition in the transport sector is progressing more slowly.
Private households: Households are responsible for around a third of the city's energy consumption, but only contribute around a quarter of emissions. This is due to the low-emission district heating supply, which is widespread in Dresden.
Economy: The economic sector is responsible for almost half of the city's greenhouse gas emissions, which emphasises its central role in urban climate protection. This sector is particularly diverse and comprises a large number of industries with different energy requirements and emission profiles.
Municipal facilities: These only account for around 2% of urban emissions, but special attention should be paid to them due to their exemplary function and the direct control options available to the city.

## Corona effect:

The effects of the coronavirus pandemic on the GHG inventory are particularly noticeable in 2020, although these were less pronounced in the city itself than initially expected. Energy consumption in the transport sector fell significantly, while there was hardly any reduction in energy consumption in the economy. The biggest influence on emissions in 2020 was the low emission factor of the German electricity mix, but not an overall reduction in energy consumption.

## Necessity of the Integrated Energy and Climate Protection Plan (IEK)

The balance sheet clearly shows that the actions taken to date have not been sufficient to significantly reduce emissions. The stagnation of emissions over a period of almost ten years emphasises the urgent need for further climate protection measures. The City of Dresden's Integrated Energy und Climate Protection Plan (IEK) is therefore a decisive instrument for implementing more ambitious actions and driving forward the transformation towards a climate-neutral city.

The IEK will include actions that affect all sectors and promote both technical and behavioural changes. These include expanding renewable energies, improving energy efficiency in buildings and industry and promoting sustainable mobility. The progress made to date, such as the expansion of the district heating supply and the improvement of energy efficiency in municipal buildings, form a solid foundation that must be further expanded through the IEK in order to achieve the city's climate targets.

## 2.2 Module A-2 Evaluation of current policy guidelines and local climate protection strategy

### 2.2.1 Legal framework:

The legal foundations of climate protection are anchored at both international and national level. The Paris Agreement, the decisions of the Federal Constitutional Court and the climate protection targets of the federal government and the Free State of Saxony form the foundation within which Dresden must define and implement its climate protection targets. These legal obligations are not only binding, but also provide a framework for the development of strategies that promote climate protection and at the same time bring social and economic benefits for the city and its citizens.

# Focus Affordable and climate neutral housing

# Affordable and climate neutral housing in Germany and Dresden

As a means to achieve net greenhouse gas neutrality by 2045, the housing construction industry will have to use its investments in the building stock to drive the decarbonization of most of the remaining GHG emissions in the building sector. Only a broad-based decarbonization strategy with a switch from fossil to emission-free energy sources, more efficient energy use and adapted building management and usage behavior can ultimately lead to the required renovation rates being achieved. We have to tackle three interconnected challenges: new construction, renovation of existing buildings, and social housing.

# New construction as the basis of social housing

Quantitatively, there are too little housing units in Germany. Speeding up in housing construction has become an urgent demand. The sector of new builts need adequate margins, in order to attract investors. As in the past, this can be achieved through subsidies for new construction projects, short depreciation periods or low-interest loans. In reality, the German housing policy has withdrawn from the provision of affordable housing for decades, thus depriving itself of its influence in shaping rental prices. Meanwhile, more financial investors have
#

Dresden. 1

Dresden action plan for climate neutrality in 2030

#

flooded into the housing market. They bought into large portfolios and are interested in exploiting all opportunities for rent increases. As a consequence, every year, several tens of thousands of social housing units fall out of price control, and hardly any new ones are being built – affordable housing is becoming increasingly scarce.

Therefore, new housing construction bears an important socio-economic function as in providing affordable housing. Those who currently have to look for a new apartment, are burdened by sharply increased rent prices due to lack of available flats, especially low-income households and single people or single-parent households, who have particularly high rent burden rates. This gap also explains that it has become increasingly difficult for the middle class to buy a property in recent years that build wealth and provide for their retirement.

It should be noted that municipal housing companies like Wohnen in Dresden (WiD) which are responsible for municipal social housing, have to comply with regulations on public procurement which reduces their overall efficiency. European Procurement Law requires to issue a wide tender, which consumes a lot of time and company resources, namely: Directive 2014/24/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council of 26 February 2014 on public procurement and repealing Directive 2004/18/EC Text with EEA relevance, as well as Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2023/2495 of 15 November 2023 amending Directive 2014/24/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council in respect of the thresholds for public supply, service and works contracts, and design contests. New and climate neutral housing construction requires effective exemption clauses to duly achieve the set targets for the building sector.

As a consequence of the shortfalls, the current volume of housing construction has been shrinking continuously in real terms since 2021. The federal government's goal of building 400,000 apartments p.a. is quite lagging behind its targets. The shortfall has already grown to up to 800,000 apartments in Germany. In fact, the housing deficits mainly affect the areas of social and affordable housing.

Since 2020, the number of people in Germany living in overcrowded apartments has increased by 800,000 to 9.3 million (11% of the population). Of those at risk of poverty, more than one in five lived in too small a space.

There is a particular lack of small apartments in the price range between €6 and €10 net cold per m² of living space.

Due to the massive slump in new housing construction, the housing sector is strategically not adequately prepared for demographic and migration-related population development or for the (necessary) transformation of the existing residential building stock.

# Net greenhouse gas neutrality versus affordable housing

The German Federal Building Energy Act and the revised Energy Performance of Buildings Directive (EPBD) aims to make all buildings in the European Union climate-neutral by 2050. To comply with this regulative framework, industry experts estimate that 45 percent of all buildings in the entire EU would have to be renovated in just nine years. At the moment, Germany is only managing to renovate one percent of the total building stock. Under the current conditions, it is impossible for the industry to cover the costs to finance necessary renovations. The costs of these obligations are translated into higher rents.

Anyway, it does not work to solve the housing gap by (renovating) existing housing alone. There is great need for new housing construction to fill the gap. There is a price problem above all and price formation takes place in existing housing when new housing does not come emerge. Missing proper public funding, modernization costs due to renovation requirements are transferred to tenants as higher rents. Some urban researchers pose that climate-friendly renovation has partly become a displacement business for rent-seeking real estate companies. Low-income households are struggling with an enormous dilemma: heating costs that are too high and
#

Dresden. 2020

Dresden action plan for climate neutrality in 2030

#

rents that are too high. They cannot cope with either. Existing tenants can be displaced and the apartments can be rented out again at high prices.

Against the background of the population growth until 2035 especially by immigration effects, it is questionable whether the housing industry can contribute to a social balance.

Dresden has been successful in attracting new investors, especially semiconductor producers into its jurisdiction. Several thousands of new apartments must be built to cope with the planned large inflow of new labour. As new builts would will inevitably lead to a higher regional rent index, Dresden municipality has to increase the portion of social housing units for social vulnerable groups. The City leaders and the construction industry are willing to do so. The challenge is to work on an adequate regulative framework and public funding schemes to achieve these goals when faced with a narrower time window, inflation, higher input and financing costs and overall lack of skilled workforce.

# Focus on wind energy

Wind energy has great potential for decarbonising the energy system. In 2040, around two thirds of net electricity generation could come from wind turbines, which means it has the most economic expansion potential of all renewable energies in the short to medium term. In Germany, wind power accounted for the largest share of renewable electricity generation in 2020 at 53 Percent. The legal framework at federal and state level has been changed in favour of an accelerated expansion of wind power plants, e.g. with the Renewable Energy Sources Act (EEG, 2023), the Act to Increase and Accelerate the Expansion of Onshore Wind Energy Plants (Wind Energy on Land Act, 2022), the Act on the Determination of Land Requirements for Onshore Wind Energy Plants (Wind Energy Land Requirements Act - WindBG 2022), as well as amendments to building and nature conservation laws. As a result, around two Percent of the land area nationwide must be designated as priority areas for wind energy by 2032. In Saxony, the regional planning associations have been designated as the responsible planning authorities for the planning area designations (Section 4a SächsLPIG). For Saxony, it was specified that each regional planning association must designate two Percent of its area by 2027 (Section 4a SächsLPIG). This means that CoD also has a responsibility to contribute to the expansion of wind energy. This is contradicted by the decision of the city council on 20 June 2013 that no wind turbines may be erected within the city limits. In July 2023, the regional planning association Oberes Elbtal/Osterzgebirge, which is responsible for the CoD area, decided on the partial update of the regional plan in the area of energy and carried out a participation procedure on the intended planning approach in the fourth quarter of 2023. A draft plan is expected to be available in 2025.

# Focus on the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF)

# ERDF in general and subject of funding:

In the City of Dresden, the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) is particularly relevant for sustainable, integrated urban development projects. As part of these projects, a GIHK (area-based, integrated action plan) is created with actions from all Fields of action to ensure a sustainable, integrated approach.

# Example Dresden - Johannstadt/Pirnaische Vorstadt neighbourhood

The Johannstadt/Pirnaische Vorstadt development area is an area that already benefited from ERDF funding in the last funding period 2024-2021. A neighbourhood-based energy, climate protection and climate adaptation
#

Dresden. 2020

Dresden action plan for climate

neutrality in 2030

#

concept was developed and examined to determine where the urban ecology could be improved and CO2 reduced. The result was a catalogue of actions. This was the basis for identifying and implementing the climate protection and climate adaptation measures, as well as improvements to the living environment and many other actions in the current 2021-2027 funding period. The current climate protection and climate adaptation measures consist of various sub-measures, such as the green roof of the new building of the adventure playground in Silbermannstraße or various PV systems on the buildings of the WGJ. Actions to improve the living environment also consist of various sub-measures, such as the creation of swale infiltration in the neighbourhood of the WGJ to protect against heavy rainfall events.

# Benefits and opportunities

With a funding rate of  $70\%$ , ERDF funding is a great opportunity to promote climate protection and climate adaptation in the city of Dresden.

A higher prioritisation of these topics in the city administration is another positive effect. The importance of these topics is also passed on within the city administration.

The short funding periods mean that projects can be realised very quickly, which makes sense in view of the current climate situation.

Sustainable, integrated urban development means that the neighbourhood is strengthened at various levels. The social level, such as the promotion of small and micro enterprises, is also taken into account. It has been shown that it makes particular sense to utilise ERDF funding within two consecutive funding periods in a neighbourhood.

# The challenges

Actions must be requested from the relevant departments for a new funding period during the current funding period. This results in high staffing peaks. These are also apparent at the beginning of the funding period. Due to the tight timeframe, multi-stage participation is usually not possible. (Intensive participation before the funding period, on the other hand, is difficult, as it is not yet certain whether the actions will actually be implemented).

The SAB (Sächsische Aufbaubank) manages the fund and acts as the interface between the state of Saxony and the municipal administration. Communication is sometimes difficult and requires a lot of patience.

EU law applies. This means a stricter approach than under national law, particularly in the areas of state aid and public procurement.

Overall, many topics in the area of climate protection and climate adaptation are still in the trial phase in the Dresden city administration, which is why the funding is still being accepted and the projects implemented very hesitantly.

Creation of green infrastructure by the specialised departments, as no funds are earmarked for the care and maintenance of the newly created green spaces.

Due to some bad experiences in the production of PV systems on existing municipal buildings in the specialised offices and the care and maintenance, hardly any cooperations come about.

Some specialist departments have a staff shortage. Without the capacity of the specialised offices, it is very difficult or even impossible to implement the actions.

# 2.2.2 Local climate protection strategy: Dresden's target for reducing greenhouse gas emissions

The IEK (Integrated Energy und Climate Protection Plan of the City of Dresden) presented at the beginning of 2024 also proposed a way for the city to become greenhouse gas-neutral $^{10}$  by 2040 at the latest.

The further development of the Dresden Action Plan to tackle the challenges of climate change, in parallel with the application for an EU mission, proved to be a decisive step. The seamless integration of this mission into the Action Plan, also known as the Integrated Energy und Climate Protection Plan (IEK), was fundamental. This integration made it possible to formulate clear objectives for the year 2030 that go beyond the City Council's targets. While the city council is aiming for climate neutrality well before 2050 and is considering a sharpening up to 2035 or alternatively 2040, it was important that the IEK already set a clear direction for this early time frame.

The reduction path designed as part of this process is not based solely on predefined target values, but also takes into account the specific potential for reducing greenhouse gas emissions. In particular, a high level of detail was achieved in the area of building energy supply through extensive, GIS data-supported analyses. Concrete plans and feasibility studies also already exist for the decarbonisation of district heating, which were used in the IEK. In other sectors such as industry, the pathway is based on assumptions of parameters, while a separate process is underway for the transport sector, which will be completed by 2025 and must be confirmed by a city council resolution. This process will take into account the greenhouse gas neutrality requirements and implement them accordingly.

Until now, the Integrated Energy und Climate Protection Plan (IEuKK) from 2013 was valid and binding for Dresden. This envisaged reducing energy-related greenhouse gas emissions in the city area by around  $41\%$  by 2030 compared to 2005, which corresponds to a target of 3,300,780 tCO2 equivalents per year (cf. Table 6-1). With the continuation of the process from the IEuKK to the Integrated Energy und Climate Protection Plan (IEK), the goal of green house gas neutrality for Dresden by 2040 at the
#

Dresden. Dresden

Dresden action plan for climate neutrality in 2030

#

latest was set. Some areas of the administration are even to be climate-neutral by 2035, while the expansion of renewable energies in the electricity sector in the city is to be driven forward by 2035. By 2040, only  $5\%$  of emissions should remain compared to 1990, with an interim target of  $20\%$  of 1990 emissions being set for 2030. As part of this update, a significant reduction in emissions is planned for 2030, which is to be reduced to the IEK target of 1,586,900  $\mathrm{tCO_2}$  equivalents per year.

The reductions in emissions already achieved are remarkable. Between 1990 and 2018, a reduction of  $54\%$  was achieved, despite a resulting population growth of around  $10\%$ . However, Dresden experienced a sharp decline in population after the 1990s and only saw population figures rise again after 1999 (cf. The published GHG inventory to 2018).

This emissions reduction target pathway demonstrates not only the City of Dresden's commitment to climate action, but also its ability to develop innovative and inclusive approaches to achieve these goals. By continuously monitoring and adapting these strategies, Dresden will continue to lead the way in the fight against climate change and ensure a sustainable future for generations to come.

# Fields of action for green house gas neutrality

The IEuKK of 2013 focussed on the Fields of action electricity, heat, transport and cross-cutting issues, which only considered final energy-based GHG emissions in the GHG inventory. However, in order to achieve GHG-neutrality in the long term, it is equally important to take non-energy GHG emissions into account. This is achieved in the IEK by categorising the Fields of action. The nine Fields of action are based on the emission sources as defined in international standards. In addition, the Fields of action "Grey energy, construction, consumption and food" and "Overarching organisation and control" are introduced. Although these are not emission sources themselves and therefore cannot be recognised as a separate category in the GHG inventory, they have a considerable scope of influence. The partial combination of energy and non-energy emissions in the Fields of action "Industrial processes and product use" and "Waste and wastewater management" brings the perspective of the actors more into focus.
