The Fields of action define strategic priorities with corresponding topics for action. This is done in varying degrees of detail in the IEK, whereby the focus is on providing at least an initial overview of all relevant areas. The orientation is based on the fundamental principles of climate protection:

Consistency/ substitution: replacement of fossil fuels with low-GHG or GHG-neutral energy sources, use of recyclable materials
Efficiency: efficient utilisation of emission-intensive substances and raw materials in general, reduction of energy consumption
Sufficiency: limiting energy and resource consumption: producing and consuming less

The final energy-based GHG emissions, as recorded in the GHG inventory according to BISKO, can be found in the Fields of action "Building energy supply", "Expansion of renewable energies in the area", "Mobility" and "Industrial processes and product use". Concrete potentials were analysed for the Fields of action "Building energy supply" and "Expansion of renewable energies in the area" and taken into account in the scenarios for the reduction path.

The "Industrial processes and product use" Fields of action also describe initial aspects of non-energy-related GHG emissions.

The Fields of action "Agriculture, forestry and other land uses" addresses non-energy-related emissions in this area on the one hand and the potential for natural  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  sinks in the urban area on the other.

The "Waste and wastewater management" Fields of action describe both relevant energy and non-energy GHG emissions and offer initial approaches for reducing them in these two areas.

The Fields of action "Grey energy, construction, consumption and nutrition" classifies the possible options for action in this area.

The field of action "Overarching organisation and management" acts as a cross-cutting topic and forms an overarching framework for all other Fields of action.

The Fields of action also form the basis for the action portfolio (IEK, Volume II; App.1).

# Scenarios analysed in the IEK

Three scenarios were considered in the IEK to illustrate the possible development towards GHG-neutrality:

two so-called target scenarios, in accordance with the City Council resolution (V1818/22) to achieve GHG-neutrality by 2035 and alternatively by 2040, and
a reference scenario in which the current federal policy targets are achieved with a slight delay.

Other scenarios that do not achieve GHG-neutrality before 2050 are not taken into account. There is therefore no "business as usual" scenario (BAU scenario). The CoD recognises its contribution to achieving the federal policy targets and the goal of the Paris Climate Agreement.

The scenarios differ in terms of a number of political, social and economic aspects that accelerate, delay or only enable the implementation of climate protection measures to a limited extent. These include, among others:

political will to implement,
Availability of land for renewable energies (RE),
Authorisation times and capacities,
Acceptance among the population,
Craftsmen (capacities, expertise),
Scaling effects (e.g. reduction in system prices, reduced planning effort due to serial roll-out),
Availability of raw materials (e.g.  $\mathsf{H}_2$ ) and materials (system components),
technical progress and the transition to a sustainable economy.

Figure 2-8 provides a brief description of the scenarios.

# Reduction path calculator in the IEK

The reduction path calculator, which was developed in the IEK, is a tool that shows the possible reduction of greenhouse gases (GHG) for the city of Dresden over time in the three different scenarios. The timeline covers the period from the start year 2018 to the target year of GHG-neutrality 2035, alternatively 2040 and beyond to 2045. The starting point for the reduction path calculator is the GHG inventory for the balance sheet year 2018.

It should be noted that the reduction path calculator is a model that shows the conditions under which GHG-neutrality can be achieved in Dresden. The reduction potentials included in the calculator are based on concrete and calculated potentials. However, it is not possible to use the pathway to assess how the trajectory shown can be realised in reality. For this, the respective underlying assumptions must be checked and compared with the respective feasibility of specific actions. Despite this, the reduction trajectory provides important information on the "levers" for achieving GHG-neutrality. Its main purpose is to visualise a compilation of the individual steps towards achieving GHG-neutrality by 2035 or 2040 and to enable a comprehensive, cross-potential analysis. The objective for the reduction path calculator is:

Presentation of the temporal potential for GHG reduction,
Presentation of the resulting final energy requirements and GHG emissions, taking into account the energy demand and GHG reduction potential over time,
Examination of the achievement of GHG-neutrality by 2035 and 2040 in the scenarios,
Presentation of the difference between the resulting GHG emissions and the GHG neutrality target ("ambition gap") for the scenarios.

In addition to the current GHG emissions (2018), the GHG reduction potentials from the potential analyses in the IEK and the assumed changes outside the urban area (scenario framework) are included in the reduction path. The reduction path is based on the calculation methodology used for the city's GHG inventory. This is based on the calculation of GHG emissions as the product of final energy demand and

Based on the scenario analyses, for which a target scenario for 2035 and a target scenario for 2040 were examined in the IEK, a concrete path to reduce GHG emissions for the CoD was proposed as a result (target scenario). This path must meet the requirements of City Council resolutions A0011/19 and V1818/22 to achieve climate neutrality well before 2050 or 2035 (alternatively 2040). In addition, it should fulfil the guidelines for GHG-neutrality and take into account the Paris-compliant  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  budget, which makes it necessary to set interim targets.

The implementation of the analysed potentials for reducing energy-related GHG emissions leads to a defined target state of GHG-neutrality with regard to energy-related GHG emissions, whereby the time component for the implementation of the potentials is not shown.

The expansion path of the renewable electricity potentials should be in line with the 2035 target scenario in order to meet the 80 Percent expansion target of the EEG 2023 and at the same time ensure greater municipal influence and reduce dependency on purchased electricity (federal electricity mix).

The reduction path for the other areas takes place by 2040 - in line with the 2040 target scenario - as achieving green house gas neutrality by 2035 is not feasible even in the 2035 target scenario. This is due to the required planning periods, skilled labour capacities and dependencies on higher levels (e.g. availability of green hydrogen infrastructure, fully decarbonised electricity supply). By specifying the target year 2040, sufficient leeway for achieving GHG-neutrality is taken into account.

A separate reduction path is assumed in the mobility sector, which is based on the scenarios used in the DMP 2035+. A further analysis in scenarios and specific actions will be carried out as part of the Dresden Mobility Plan 2035+, which is currently being developed. Unlike the stationary sector, the mobility sector is therefore not underpinned by differentiated potentials and assumptions in the target path, but should rather be seen as an overarching requirement for the further development of actions in the DMP2035+.

The reduction pathway scenarios make it clear that it is possible to achieve GHG-neutrality by 2040. In order to realise this goal, the urban potential identified as feasible, particularly in the energy sector, must be fully exploited.

Complete energy self-sufficiency cannot be realised for Dresden. Nevertheless, there is considerable potential through the installation of local renewable energy systems for the provision of electricity,
#

Dresden. Diegeur

Dresden action plan for climate neutrality in 2030

#

which is estimated at around 1,500 GWh/a. Tapping into this potential harbours several opportunities, including increasing the security of supply, making it more attractive for industrial settlements and promoting local value creation.

The realisation of the targeted GHG-neutrality in the urban area is based on several pillars. A number of key requirements must be met in order to achieve the defined targets:

Substitution of natural gas: Natural gas must be substituted as an energy source by 2040.
Decarbonisation of the purchased electricity: In accordance with the political requirements (Climate Protection Act, EEG 2023), the purchased electricity must be decarbonised (if the decarbonisation of electricity is not progressing as quickly as assumed, this can be mitigated by targeted savings).
Availability of emission-free hydrogen: Hydrogen must be available and "largely emission-free" by 2035.
Defossilisation of mobility: The aim is to achieve the greatest possible defossilisation in the mobility sector by 2040 (concretisation and implementation of the target via DMP 2035+).
Implementation of SachsenEnergie AG's decarbonisation concept (acceleration scenario, in particular tapping industrial waste heat potential): The implementation of this concept plays a decisive role in achieving the defined targets.
Efficiency gains in industry: High efficiency gains in industrial processes are essential to maximise this sector's contribution to GHG-neutrality, with the assumed savings in the industrial sector of 30 percent in total being offset by a simultaneous increase.
In addition, the aim is to increase the efficiency of heating requirements in existing buildings by twelve Percent.

The proposed reduction path is characterised by a high level of ambition, but is considered feasible under the assumptions made.

# Target for Dresden (city council resolution)

For the City Council's resolution on the IEK, the specified reduction path is translated into concrete, controllable (interim) values for GHG reduction. The target for the resolution text within the framework of the IEK is to achieve GHG-neutrality with a reduction of 95 Percent compared to 1990 GHG emissions by 2040 at the latest. Against the background of the citizens' petition adopted by the City Council with the target of 2035 ("Dresden Zero") and the urgency of climate protection, the acceleration of all implementation measures to achieve greenhouse gas neutrality as early as possible must be pursued. In order to concretise this overarching objective, interim targets will be defined:

For 2027: a minimum reduction of 70 Percent.
For 2030: A minimum reduction of 80 Percent of GHG emissions, based on the target of the EU mission.
For 2035: A minimum reduction of 90 Percent of GHG emissions, as a further step towards the overall target by 2040.

In order to achieve the target, the potential for renewable energies in the urban area identified in the IEK, particularly in the areas of wind energy and PV, is to be tapped by 2035. This includes the targeted utilisation and expansion of these renewable energy sources in the following stages (electricity generation from renewable energy plants, expansion target for 2040 already achieved, therefore no value).

The (interim) targets are reviewed as part of monitoring and controlling with a two-year delay (review year). The GHG inventory according to BISKO as well as the indicator for the feed-in of renewable energy systems and the renewable energy systems installed in the urban area are used to check the achievement of targets.

The GHG inventory is expanded to include the cumulative GHG emissions from 2020 to the respective review year in order to check the consumption of the  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  budget. This comprehensive review enables a targeted evaluation of progress and ensures that the (interim) targets set as part of the climate protection strategy are on track.

Another significant step towards achieving the target is the endeavour to make the city administration GHG-neutral by the target year of 2035. This emphasises the commitment at municipal level not only to reduce GHG emissions in general, but also to lead by example in the administration itself.

Module A-3 Systemic obstacles and opportunities for climate neutrality in 2030

System description and analysis:

Categorisation of the municipal scope for action

There are certain factors and aspects that are not directly within the municipalities' control that can affect their GHG-neutrality efforts. Some of these factors are:

National and international environment: Major political and economic decisions at national and international level can influence the framework conditions for municipal initiatives. For example, national laws, international agreements or global economic trends can influence the opportunities and challenges for municipalities.
Social developments: Various developments in society as a whole in terms of preferences, trends or socio-demographic factors can only be changed to a very limited extent at municipal level. For example, the necessary trend towards a certain sufficiency, i.e. a resource- and energy-saving lifestyle, can only be realised as a development for society as a whole, whereby the federal and EU levels must also exert their influence.
Economic structure: The economic structure of a region may to some extent be outside the direct control of a municipality. If a municipality is heavily dependent on emissions/energy-intensive industries, it may be more difficult to achieve GHG-neutrality without simultaneously impacting the economy.
Technological developments: The availability and affordability of green technologies and innovations can be influenced by external factors beyond the control of an individual community. This can make the introduction of new green technologies more difficult or easier.
Global market dynamics: Access to environmentally friendly resources and technologies can also be influenced by global market dynamics that depend on political decisions, trade agreements and international economic relations.
Research and development: Progress in research and development, particularly in the field of renewable energies and climate-friendly technologies, cannot be directly controlled by local authorities.
Natural conditions: Some natural conditions, such as local climate, geography or the availability of renewable resources, may be factors outside the direct control of a municipality.

Despite these challenges, the CoD can play an active role by using its local resources and spheres of influence, promoting cooperation and exerting political pressure on other levels to create favourable framework conditions for climate protection.

## 2.3.3 Focus: Challenges in the building sector

At a good 30 Percent, the energy renovation status in Dresden is better than the national average. On the one hand, this is pleasing, as only a relatively small proportion of buildings are considered to be unrenovated and therefore urgently require energy-efficient refurbishment. On the other hand, the energy refurbishments of the last three decades mean that it is often not worthwhile from the building owner's or tenant's point of view, for example, to reinforce the façade insulation, retrofit panel heating or carry out other extensive energy refurbishments. In view of the income burdens that may result from additional extensive energy refurbishments, the acceptance of the actions, but also the limited capacities of the trades, it therefore does not seem advisable to demand extensive energy refurbishments to achieve high efficiency standards as an action in general. Such actions would have to be accompanied by a high level of public funding and would be difficult to implement due to the known shortage of skilled labour. Even if the highest possible energy efficiency standards would be desirable in principle, in view of the challenges outlined, it must be ensured that the building energy supply achieves GHG-neutrality by pragmatic and innovative means. This means that only as much energy refurbishment should be required as is necessary for the use of green district heating or the use of renewable energies in the form of heat pumps or neighbourhood heating networks, where possible in the building. If green hydrogen is available as a climate-neutral option for the building, this would be the benchmark.

For all of the climate-neutral options mentioned, no or only relatively minor energy refurbishment measures need to be carried out on the outer shell or the building's heat distribution system due to the already relatively good state of refurbishment. These could be, for example, the replacement of individual radiators or simple sealing measures, usually with the aim of reducing the required maximum flow temperatures in the building to below $65^{\circ}\mathrm{C}$. Most greenhouse gas-neutral solutions can operate at this temperature. Nevertheless, this must be checked on a case-by-case basis by the specialised company or planner and should not be misunderstood as a general recommendation. In addition to switching to greenhouse gas-neutral heat generators, a key objective should be to maximise the overall energy efficiency of the building and thus save energy.

Dresden. Dresdener

Dresden action plan for climate neutrality in 2030

#

By innovative means, we mean that so-called serial refurbishments could also be considered for suitable building types, for example. Serial refurbishment means the use of prefabricated façade or roof elements including the associated system technology (e.g. PV, heat pump modules) and their more efficient installation on or in existing buildings. The elements prefabricated off-site have such a high degree of prefabrication that the time required on site is significantly reduced compared to conventional refurbishment. These are currently on the rise, are also subsidised by the German government[13] and have several advantages. Firstly, they are usually more cost-effective than commissioning several specialist planners and individual trades. They also reduce interface management between the trades and the associated risks and, finally, they effectively counter the problem of skilled labour, as the time required is significantly reduced.

Another innovative means is to combine different heating technologies as intelligently as possible. For example, investment costs can be saved if a rather small heat pump is installed in an existing building for the efficient provision of the basic heat load and an additional low-cost heat generator is only added for the few very cold days of the year or in rooms with higher temperature requirements. This could be, for example, additional infrared panels in individual rooms or so-called split air conditioning units. In this way, investment costs can be saved on building refurbishment and possibly also on the heat generator, while still achieving a high level of living comfort and a reliable and climate-neutral supply.

A key aspect of energy-efficient building refurbishment is checking the hot water supply. In many apartment blocks, a high hot water temperature is permanently generated and possibly still circulated in the building due to the risk of legionella. This results in considerable heat losses. In apartment blocks with hot water circulation, the hot water energy consumption corresponds to the same level as the heating energy consumption due to the circulation losses. These systems lead to high operating costs and make the use of RE more difficult. It is therefore necessary to examine the extent to which these systems can be made more efficient in operation by means of an adapted legionella control programme or a technical retrofit/conversion, taking into account the drinking water hygiene regulations. This is being investigated as part of the Neutral Path project together with the TU Dresden. The findings are to be incorporated into municipal heat planning.

One approach that can be easily combined with sector coupling is the joint development and utilisation of (local) energy resources. Specifically, this means, for example, district heating or local heating networks, which offer the possibility of integrating various local energy sources or important supplementary energy sources (e.g. biomass, hydrogen, "surplus electricity") and storing the heat generated from them and making it available as required. Therefore, in addition to the further development of Dresden's district heating system, the expansion and construction of new local heating networks outside the district heating areas is an important contribution to an affordable, secure and climate-neutral heat supply.

# 2.3.4 Opportunities: Regional added value, cost savings and benefits

Climate protection aims to minimise the negative effects of climate change as far as possible. In the context of urban development, the goal of a climate-robust and resilient city takes centre stage. A city that not only withstands the challenges of climate change, but is also sustainable and adaptable, offers a variety of additional benefits. These include an increased quality of life, improved public health and the creation of attractive green and recreational spaces. In addition, sustainable urban design helps to reduce maintenance and flood protection costs. A particular focus here is on the city of Dresden, where targeted climate protection measures can both save costs and improve environmental and living conditions in the long term. The most important benefits and associated cost and savings potentials are presented in more detail below. The costs and cost savings mentioned relate to Dresden.

# Avoidance of  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  costs

Costs already have to be paid for the emission of greenhouse gases. A distinction must be made between European and national emissions trading. The European Union introduced the European Emissions Trading Scheme (EU ETS) in 2005 to reduce GHG emissions from power plants, industrial facilities and aviation in a cost-efficient manner. The quantity of available certificates is continuously decreasing, causing certificate prices to rise while demand for certificates remains the same or increases. The EU ETS allowance price is currently around 70 euros/ $\mathrm{t}_{\mathrm{CO}_{2\mathrm{e}}}$ . Since 2021, there has also been national emissions trading, which currently affects the transport and heating sectors and will also affect the waste sector from 2024. The Emissions Trading Authority (DEHSt) at the Federal Environment Agency is responsible for implementation. Currently, certificate prices are fixed and not determined on a market basis. In 2023, the national allowance price was 35 euros/ $\mathrm{t}_{\mathrm{CO}_{2\mathrm{e}}}$ . However, as part of the "Fit for 55"
#

Dresden. Dresden

Dresden action plan for climate neutrality in 2030

#

package at European level, there are plans to also integrate the heating and transport sectors into a European certificate trading scheme, the "EU ETS 2", from 2027. $^{14}$

It must therefore be assumed that certificate prices in European emissions trading will equalise from 2027 and continue to rise. The fundamental model calculations carried out by SachsenEnergie AG as part of the district heating transformation plan resulted in a certificate price forecast of EUR  $208 / t_{\mathrm{CO2}}$  for the year 2045. This forecast is subject to major uncertainties, but should be used to illustrate the direct annual savings of future  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  price costs for Dresden. If the goal of GHG-neutrality is achieved in Dresden, this corresponds to an annual GHG emissions reduction of 3.2 million tonnes $_{\mathrm{CO2}}$  compared to 2018 emissions. If these emissions still occur in 2045 and emission allowances would have to be purchased for them, this would result in annual costs of around 668 million euros. Over a period of 20 years, which corresponds to the technical service life of heating systems, for example, this would mean savings of more than 13 billion euros. In reality, however, it must be assumed that the  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  certificate price will rise even more sharply due to its significant shortage, particularly at the end of the 1940s, meaning that the savings for Dresden would be significantly higher.

# Ecological benefit according to damage cost approach (climate impact costs)

The damage cost approach published by the Federal Environment Agency (UBA) estimates the amount of damage caused to society by GHG emissions and the resulting climate change. "The damage caused by greenhouse gas emissions will increase over time, for example as the value of buildings and infrastructure damaged by extreme weather events increases. Therefore, the cost rates to be applied will also increase over time."15 For GHG emissions emitted in 2022, this damage cost rate is estimated by the UBA at 237 euros/tCO2 and for 2050 at 286 euros/tCO2 , but with a higher weighting of the prosperity of current generations compared to that of future generations (time preference 1 Percent). If the prosperity claim were weighted equally (0 Percent time preference), the cost rate for 2050 would rise to 865 euros/tCO2 . This clearly shows that not only the achievement of GHG-neutrality itself, but also the total emissions still emitted until GHG-neutrality is achieved cause considerable damage and must therefore be included in the analysis. Based on the damage cost rates for a higher weighting of the current level of prosperity (time preference 1 Percent) and in comparison between the target for achieving GHG neutrality and the reference scenario of the IEK, the acceleration of the federal target for achieving GHG neutrality in 2045 alone results in a reduction in the damage amount of around EUR 3.2 billion by achieving GHG neutrality by 2040 and adhering to the CO2 budget for the 1.75 °C target (see chapter 6.1 and Table 6-3).

# Strengthening regional value creation

Another sustainable benefit from an economic perspective is the increase in regional added value for Dresden and the region. This is because a large proportion of the investments listed will not only take place in Dresden, but will also be realised by regional companies from planning to construction. The fact that the additional plants and infrastructure have to be serviced and maintained also leads to long-term orders and jobs for the regional economy. Furthermore, Dresden will significantly reduce its energy imports and thus also the outflow of financial resources.

# Location advantage

Climate protection is playing an increasingly decisive role as a location factor for municipalities, particularly in terms of attracting large companies. Companies are attaching more and more importance to sustainable business practices and favour locations that offer a future-proof, climate-friendly infrastructure. Municipalities that pursue clear climate protection strategies and implement actions to reduce greenhouse gas emissions are signalling a willingness to innovate and a sense of responsibility. This can help to strengthen their image as an attractive business location and increase their competitiveness in global competition. Companies also benefit from sustainable location development, as it makes it easier for them to achieve their own climate targets and sustainability requirements. By creating climate-friendly framework conditions, a municipality not only secures its ecological future in the long term, but also attracts investors and companies that are active in sustainable growth markets.

# Increasing the security of supply

Dresden is currently more than 95 Percent dependent on imports of fossil fuels to cover its heating requirements. This is primarily due to the import of natural gas. Such dependence on fossil fuel imports is not only problematic in terms of the outflow of cash flows and rising  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  costs, but also represents a supply risk. Even if Dresden, as a major city, will probably always be dependent on energy imports, reducing and diversifying them as sustainably as possible will contribute to greater resilience in the event of external shocks. With the IEK's proposed target path, the dependency in the heat supply is reduced or diversified from more than 95 Percent of the heat demand being covered by natural gas imports to around 25 Percent of the heat demand being covered by hydrogen imports (used in the district heating CHP plants) and a small proportion of electricity imports (used for heat pumps). As the district heating CHP plants are used in particular on days with high electricity prices, for example on cold winter days with low renewable electricity generation, they generate some of the electricity required for heat pumps in Dresden's distribution grid in addition to the waste heat for district heating. They thus contribute to a reduced dependence on electricity imports. On days with good conditions for PV electricity generation, a significant proportion of the heat pump electricity required in Dresden will be generated directly with intelligent control, and connected heat storage units can be charged accordingly. In times with good conditions for electricity generation from wind power, Dresden will be able to benefit from favourable imports via the transmission grid in addition to its own plants.

# Financial benefits and increased self-sufficiency

In addition to the benefits from Dresden's overall perspective, the operation of private RE systems, for example PV roof or balcony systems, can help to reduce energy costs for tenants or building users and thus contribute to a financial advantage. Ideally, companies can also reduce their energy costs by using renewable energy systems on their buildings or areas compared to full grid supply. In addition, supplying their own decentralised energy and possibly storage systems represents a certain degree of self-sufficiency, which can contribute to local security of supply.

To summarise, it can be stated at this point that the investments in Dresden's GHG-neutrality not only make an important contribution to achieving climate protection targets, but also bring several important additional benefits.

# Social benefit

The energy transition has the potential to make the energy supply more democratic at both an individual and international level. At an individual level, depending on individual circumstances, it can expand the

opportunities for participation in the energy supply, although not everyone can benefit equally. This can increase the self-efficacy of individual groups and thus also the acceptance of actions. Internationally, this can reduce inequalities between countries and reduce dependencies on fossil resources. While the energy transition does not bring about complete democratisation in the political sense, it does make various aspects of energy supply more democratic.

Last but not least, climate protection and climate change adaptation measures have an impact on the health, mortality and quality of life of the urban population. As a result of global warming, heat stress in the summer months is increasing enormously for residents in densely populated neighbourhoods. In order to prevent health consequences, the City of Dresden is currently drawing up a heat action plan. This takes into account comprehensive intervention measures for health protection. Behavioural and situational preventative actions are intended to reduce heat stress and UV exposure and prevent damage to health.

Increasing weather changes and natural disasters also have an impact on the quality of life and health of the city's inhabitants. Climate protection is intended to mitigate the effects of climate change as far as possible.

# 3 Part B - Pathways to climate neutrality by 2030

# 3.1 Module B-1 Climate neutrality scenarios and impact pathways

The reduction path pursued by the City of Dresden to achieve GHG-neutrality is characterised by a very high level of ambition, but is considered feasible under the assumptions made. Complete energy self-sufficiency is not realisable for Dresden. Nevertheless, there is considerable potential through the installation of local renewable energy systems for the provision of electricity, which is estimated at around 1,500 GWh/a. Tapping into this potential harbours several opportunities, including increasing security of supply, making the city more attractive for industrial settlements and promoting local value creation.

The realisation of the targeted GHG-neutrality in the urban area is based on several pillars. A number of key requirements must be met in order to achieve the defined targets:

Substitution of natural gas: Natural gas must be substituted as an energy source by 2040.
Decarbonisation of reference electricity: In accordance with the political requirements (Climate Protection Act, Renewable Energy Sources Act 2023), the reference electricity must be decarbonised (if the decarbonisation of electricity does not progress as quickly as assumed, this can be mitigated by targeted savings).
Availability of emission-free hydrogen for industrial applications: Hydrogen must be available and "largely emission-free" by 2035.
Defossilisation of mobility: The aim is to achieve the greatest possible defossilisation in the mobility sector by 2040 (concretisation and implementation of the target via DMP 2035+).
Implementation of SachsenEnergie AG's decarbonisation concept (acceleration scenario, in particular tapping industrial waste heat potential): The implementation of this concept plays a decisive role in achieving the defined targets.
Efficiency gains in industry: High efficiency gains in industrial processes are essential to maximise this sector's contribution to GHG-neutrality, with the assumed savings in the industrial sector of 30 percent in total being offset by a simultaneous increase.
In addition, the aim is to increase the efficiency of heating requirements in existing buildings by twelve Percent.

Another significant step towards achieving the target is the endeavour to make the city administration GHG-neutral by the target year of 2035. This emphasises the commitment at municipal level not only to reduce GHG emissions in general, but also to lead by example in the administration itself.

# Description of the impact pathways

The impact pathways are characterised by the fact that they have the greatest influence on the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions in the city. They address a large proportion of the city's GHG emissions (energy-related emissions &gt; 85% of total emissions). At the same time, they must be implemented quickly in order to achieve short-term reductions. The necessary planning and implementation periods must be taken into account, particularly in the case of infrastructural changes.

Various assumptions are included in the impact paths:

Green hydrogen will not be available until after 2030 at the earliest, meaning that the switch to hydrogen for industrial applications will not be possible until after 2030.
The GHG emission factor of natural gas will increase by 2026 due to increased shares of LNG, which has a higher emission factor than pipeline natural gas.

The share of district heating in building heating will increase to approx. 50% by 2040 (strong expansion, therefore also more total emissions from district heating than if no expansion takes place).
The share of renewable energy in the urban area could reach 20% of total electricity demand by 2030 and 42% of total electricity demand by 2040. To achieve this, the potential for generating approx. 1,500 GWh/a from PV and wind energy would have to be utilised by 2035.
The expansion of production capacities for industry will lead to an increase in energy demand and thus GHG emissions by 2030 (forecast based on existing studies); the savings from energy efficiency in industrial companies will dampen this effect and will be visible as a reduction from 2030.

# 3.2 Module B-2 Climate neutrality portfolio design

The climate neutrality portfolio in the CCC incorporates the most important actions from the three core sectoral plans IEK, DMP35+ and climate change adaptation of the CoD. The climate neutrality portfolio was developed as an action portfolio as part of the IEK. This is based on the Fields of action of the IEK and is therefore not fully consistent with the system of the CCC's Action Plan template. The action portfolio only contains actions that can be implemented by the City of Dresden and its participating companies. Third-party actions are outside the scope of municipal action and are therefore not part of the action plan. These are listed and described by actor in the Commitent (Part 1).

# Focus EU project NEUTRAL PATH

The city of Dresden's smart city project "NeutralPath" focuses on the urban heat and energy transition, particularly in the building sector with locations in the Leuben and Loschwitz districts. Five cities form the innovation network here: together with Zaragoza, Dresden is demonstrating feasible PCEDs as a pioneering city, in close dialogue with the three "copycat cities" of Ghent, Istanbul and Vantaa. The aim is to develop and demonstrate energy-positive, climate-neutral urban neighbourhoods (Positive Clean Energy Districts/PCEDs) in Dresden and Zaragoza, Spain as model cities and Ghent (Belgium), Istanbul (Turkey) and Vantaa (Finland) as multipliers or copycat cities. The project focuses on the building sector, specifically the decarbonisation of the heat supply, expanding the use of renewable energy sources and increasing the energy efficiency of buildings ("heat transition"). Electromobility and sector coupling are dealt with as integrated topics. Relevant actions:

Demonstration of climate-neutral neighbourhoods (Positive Clean Energy Districts) in Dresden
Installation of photovoltaic systems and heat pumps to increase local energy production and optimise consumption
Development of a low-temperature heating network as a prerequisite for the integration of renewable energies in Leuben
Energetic refurbishment and modernisation of existing residential buildings and installation of innovative insulation solutions in Pillnitz-Hosterwitz
Monitoring and performance monitoring of the installed systems in parallel: Establishment of innovation centres for PCEDs (Climate-Neutral Labs) in Dresden

# 3.2.2 Portfolio of mobility measures

The IEK does not include any actions in the area of mobility. These measures are part of the Dresden Transport Development Plan (VEP) 2025plus for the Dresden Mobility Plan (DMP) 2035+, which is currently being updated (see 1.3). Based on jointly developed key objectives and various scenarios, a preferred scenario with actions will be developed there and the actions will be described in more detail. This is planned for 2025.

In December 2022, the City Council adopted 14 key objectives for the DMP2035+. These form the basis for the evaluation of the scenarios and necessary actions.[17]

Climate: The transport system contributes to the necessary CO2 reduction and thus to climate protection.
Accessibility: All destinations can be reliably reached by citizens and businesses throughout the city using suitable means of transport, depending on the purpose.
Participation: All population groups can use Dresden's transport system easily, conveniently and without barriers.
Road safety: The transport system is being reorganised so that there are fewer accidents with fatalities and serious injuries. Dresden is aiming for "Vision Zero" by 2035.
Health: Traffic is becoming quieter and cleaner and Dresden is complying with noise and air quality limits. The transport system promotes active mobility.
Urban-friendly choice of transport: Walking and cycling as well as public transport with its multi-mobile services achieve a share of at least 75 Percent of urban traffic by 2035. The services are so well developed and networked that they fulfil mobility needs without the need for a car.
Short distances: Urban and transport planning ensures short distances in Dresden. In everyday life, all destinations are easily accessible on foot, by bike or by public transport.
Urban space quality: Streets and squares are designed to create spaces for people to live, move, stay and communicate. This requires intensive greening, which also improves the local urban climate.
Regional connections: Dresden and the region are well connected in terms of transport. By 2035, more than 50 Percent of visitors and commuters in Dresden will use public transport and bicycles.
Mobility management: All stakeholders in Dresden take responsibility for the sustainable mobility of their customers, visitors and employees and actively support the use of alternatives to private cars.
Economic efficiency: The transport system becomes crisis-proof, orientated towards the common good and conserves natural resources, as only then will it be economical in the long term. The costs of climate-neutral mobility are distributed fairly between the economy, the public sector and citizens.
Energy and space efficiency: Energy consumption for transport is significantly reduced. Transport facilities are built in a space-efficient manner.
Innovation and technology: Dresden focuses on innovative traffic control, digitalisation and automation for sustainable, safe and energy-saving mobility.
Mobility culture: Respect and mutual consideration characterise the way we work together. The needs of the individual and the common good are weighed up in a goal-orientated manner.

# Campus line

A new tram line is being built between the Löbtau and Strehlen districts. It is intended to relieve the heavily used bus route 61, which is an important connection to the TU Dresden and is used by students in particular.

![img-0.jpeg](img-0.jpeg)

![img-1.jpeg](img-1.jpeg)

Source: Road and civil engineering office

With its greater capacity, the tram is intended to relieve bus traffic and make public transport more efficient and faster. With modern light rail vehicles, more passengers can be transported and travelling comfort is increased. In this way, even more people can be won over to climate-friendly modes of transport.

The new routes will enable new direct connections and better links, for example to the TU campus, including from Gorbitz, Löbtau, Pieschen and Reick. Further information about the planned new connections can be found here.

# MOBILITIES4EU

Innovative and cost-effective concepts for passenger mobility and freight transport, developed and implemented according to participatory and user-centred principles, are at the heart of the EU project MOBILITIES FOR EU. MOBILITIES FOR EU identifies innovative solutions for urban mobility that can accelerate the transformation of the urban transport sector and include electrification, automation and connectivity as key themes to achieve this goal. Seven European cities, most of which have committed to the 112 Mission Cities, form the core of the project. They are divided into pioneer and replication cities. Dresden, along with Madrid (Spain), is one of two pioneer cities that will test the effectiveness of 27 innovative mobility solutions in eleven pilot actions. The 27 solutions relate to innovations in both vehicles and the overarching infrastructure. Examples include autonomous medium-sized e-buses for transporting around 20 people and the development of a decentralised data ecosystem for autonomous mobility for automated driving. The demonstration includes a design phase, the deployment of the solutions and their evaluation to assess their impact and relevance for future expansion and replication. The implementation of new urban mobility solutions can only be effective if they meet the needs of city residents and other local stakeholders. Therefore, Urban Transport Labs (UT-Labs) will be set up in all seven project cities to involve these stakeholders and play an important role in the project. The labs are involved in all project phases, in particular in the co-design of pilot activities and in the planning of up-scaling and replication activities after the project period. The centrepiece of Dresden's participation in the EU project Mobilities for EU is the Urban Transport Lab - OSTRA Laboratory for Urban Mobility located in the project area. This innovation hub will promote cooperation between citizens, industry, science and administration in order to shape the future development of mobility. Our goal is to create accessible options that bring people together regardless of their personal abilities, ensuring inclusive and collaborative progress. Beyond the duration of the project, the lab will further develop Dresden's transport system and position the city as a pioneer for sustainable urban mobility. The Urban Transport Lab will open on 31 August 2024. Further milestones include the testing of a charging robot in the Ostragehege in autumn 2024 (with VW GI) and car park monitoring in the Ostragehege at the end of 2024/beginning of 2025. The project is scheduled to run for the next five years, during which the technologies will be deployed and monitored by a project consortium comprising 29 prestigious institutions from nine European countries, covering the different perspectives of academia, industry and the public sector. MOBILITIES FOR EU is funded under Horizon Europe - the European Commission's research and innovation funding programme - in collaboration with the two European partnerships CCAM and 2ZERO.

The BUGA represents a major contribution to the development of green infrastructure in Dresden in the context of climate change adaptation measures.  |

# 3.2.4 Action profiles - individual action plans

The system of actions in the IEK was carefully designed and should be retained. It was decided not to depart from this system in the Action Plan, as it was already published with the City Council's submission on the IEK and any deviations from it could lead to confusion. Further cost data will only be included in the investment plan, as this information is not to be published at present. The system of actions is explained below:

The IEK is divided into three volumes, with Volume II containing the action portfolio. The focus of the IEK is on an action portfolio, which is characterised by concretely developed packages of measures and fact sheets agreed with the stakeholders. Its detailed presentation not only makes it easier to agree on the necessary next steps, but also facilitates the targeted implementation of the actions that form the prelude to achieving GHG-neutrality in Dresden. The independence of the action portfolio allows it to be used autonomously, in the sense that stakeholders can use the action portfolios for their own work independently of the concept.

The updatable system of the action portfolio and the action profiles helps to ensure that the actions can be planned and updated over time. This structure supports the sustainable implementation of actions and provides scope for adjustments in the dynamic context of climate protection. In order to ensure effective controlling and enable transparent monitoring of success, the actions in the action portfolio (Volume II) are integrated directly into the climate protection monitoring software to be procured. This integration ensures that the implementation of the actions can be monitored promptly, precisely and conveniently and that it is possible to react to changing conditions. Aligning the fact sheets with the requirements of the Municipal Guidelines - Technical Annex ensures that the actions comply with current standards and regulations. This ensures that the actions listed fulfil the requirements for funding.
#

Dresden. Diego

Action plan for climate neutrality 2030

#

The structure of the action portfolio and the action profiles envisaged in the IEK thus offers a starting point for a clear and practical guideline for the implementation of climate protection measures, which is to be continuously expanded over the next few years into an action programme that reflects the target pathway adopted by the city council to achieve GHG-neutrality. The municipal scope for action is to be made clear and recommendations for action for other stakeholders outside the CoD's remit are to be taken into account.

In the action portfolio, the various Fields of action, packages of measures and specific actions are presented in a clearly structured hierarchy. This structure not only facilitates clarity, but also makes it easy to identify and assign the individual actions. In some cases, actions can also be assigned to several Fields of action, in which case the Field of action in which the action is likely to have the greatest impact has been selected. The links and interactions between actions and Fields of action can be identified in the action profiles.

The structure of the action portfolio is as follows:

# Level 1: Fields of action (FoA):

The various Fields of action for reducing greenhouse gases are described in detail in the IEK. These form the basis for the future action programme. Each Fields of action is labelled with an abbreviation to ensure clear identification in the measure numbers (Table 3-1).

## Level 2: Packages of measures:

The second level contributes to further differentiation. Each package of measures is given a consecutive number, preceded by the abbreviation of the associated Fields of action and separated by a dot. This numbering enables a clear allocation of the actions clustered in the package of measures. As of the status of the action portfolio, the options for action required in the packages of measures are not fully underpinned by concrete actions.

Example:

G.1: Package of measures in the Fields of action Buildings
E.2: Package of measures in the Fields of action Energy supply (central)

## Level 3: Actions:

The third level consists of the specific measure profiles within a package of measures. The numbering is consecutive, with the number of the associated action package being placed in front and separated from the two-digit number of the specific action by a hyphen.

Example:

G.1-01: First concrete action in action package G.1 (buildings)

This systematic structure not only enables the action portfolio to be organised efficiently, but also makes it easier to search for, identify and implement specific climate protection measures. Each element in this hierarchy helps to present the large number of actions clearly and to facilitate their integration into the overall context of climate protection.

Key measures are listed below. The IEK action portfolio is attached as an extra document to the CCC (Annex ...). All packages of measures and actions are listed there.

|  Description: Dresden's district heating network already represents an important backbone of the city's heating supply with a share of approx. 44% of heat demand and a length of 630 kilometres. Its CHP plants utilise highly efficient, coupled electricity and heat generation. However, this is still based on fossil natural gas, which must be replaced for a climate-neutral heat supply. SachsenEnergie AG's decarbonisation concept, which places a special focus on district heating, shows the potential and ways to achieve GHG-neutral district heating by 2035 and 2045. The heat transformation plan for district heating underpins this with further detailed planning. This concerns, for example  |   |
|  ■ Thermal utilisation of residual waste  |   |
|  ■ Use of large heat pumps  |   |
|  ■ Use of electrode heating boilers  |   |
|  ■ Lowering the grid temperatures ("Low Ex")  |   |
|  ■ Expansion of heat storage capacities  |   |
|  In addition to replacing natural gas, Dresden's district heating also has potential for densification and expansion. The compression potential lies in particular in areas where natural gas and district heating are currently still being used in parallel.  |   |
|  Objective: The expansion and decarbonisation of district heating is to use the heat transformation plan to demonstrate how a climate-neutral district heating supply can be achieved by means of specific, coordinated individual measures. It takes into account the redensification of existing areas as well as expansion areas. The results of the heat transformation plan will be integrated into municipal heat planning in such a way that they are compatible with the Dresden City Council's climate neutrality target.  |   |

|  Ring 30 - Waste treatment and recycling plant  |   |
|  Description of the Together with Stadtreinigung Dresden GmbH, SachsenEnergie AG is planning the construction and operation of a waste treatment plant including a thermal waste utilisation plant in the form of a refuse-derived fuel (RDF) cogeneration plant. With the construction of our own plant in Dresden and its connection to CoD's central district heating network, up to 80% of the energy contained in residual waste can be utilised. By pretreating the waste, recyclable materials still contained in the residual waste can also be fed back into material cycles and a high-calorific substitute fuel can be produced for heat generation. The quantities generated on site are also disposed of safely on site. Natural gas previously used and imported from abroad will be proportionately substituted and the generation of heat decarbonised accordingly. As a result, this economical and ecological solution in municipal hands closes local material and energy cycles. In the future, this will make an important contribution to the affordability of waste disposal and energy supply for local people and create new jobs at the same time. The Hammerweg site, which has been used for waste management for decades and is located close to the conurbation, which is essential for district heating supply, will become a new focal point for this. A state-of-the-art RDF cogeneration plant will characterise the site in terms of energy management as a future component of a secure electricity and heat supply for CoD. There are currently plans to create processing capacities for non-hazardous waste with a capacity of up to 110,000 tonnes per year. The RDF will be thermally utilised in a new RDF cogeneration plant to be built with a combustion capacity of approx. 120,000 tonnes per year. The steam generated will be used to generate electricity and heat by means of an extraction condensing turbine. Innovative technologies in the turbine area and in the utilisation of waste heat potential are intended to achieve a fuel utilisation rate of up to 80%. The heat generated will be fed into the central district heating network of the city of Dresden as district heating.  |   |
|  Objective Decarbonisation of Dresden's district heating generation and securing an affordable waste disposal and energy supply. By pretreating residual waste and bulky waste that is subject to disposal, recyclable materials are to be fed back into the material cycle and the substitute fuel produced in the RDF cogeneration plant is to be utilised in the best possible way to generate energy. Waste utilisation close to the conurbation should also ensure a considerable reduction in transport routes.  |   |

|  River water heat pump on the Vereinigte Weißeritz  |   |
|  Description of the  |   |
|  The project comprises the planning and construction of a heat pump system in the urban area of Dresden Löbtau (near the Nossener Brücke). The heat pump is to utilise river water (surface water) from the Vereinigte Weißeritz as a heat source. The river water is to be taken from the middle water channel via a lateral branch. The water will be channelled to a pump shaft via an extraction structure in the bank walls and subsequent pipelines. From there, the water is channelled to the heat pump hall. Once the river water has cooled down in the heat pump's evaporator, it is channelled back into the Weißeritz via pipes and a shaft. The heat extracted from the river is brought to a higher, usable temperature level in the heat pump and then fed into the central district heating network. The heat pump has a thermal output of 6.5 MW. The above information reflects the current planning status.  |   |
|  Objective: Use of environmental heat to decarbonise district heating.  |   |

|  Description: The aim of the project is the construction and operation of a heat pump system for green neighbourhood heating in Dresden-Gorbitz. The planned heating capacity is approx. 1 - 1.6 MWth. The mine water from the deep Elbe tunnel serves as the heat source. In a first planning step, the site fundamentals including the potential of the heat source for the provision of district heating were recorded and necessary preliminary investigations such as an exploratory borehole to determine the geological conditions were carried out. The design of the plant and the necessary peripherals will be specified in more detail in the more detailed planning stage. According to the current planning status, the construction of the plant can be divided into four sections. These include the excavation of a technical cavern in the deep Elbe tunnel, the installation of the mine water pipe from the surface to the cavern by means of boreholes, the construction of the mine water route from the borehole to the Q10 heat exchanger station (WÜS Q10) and the equipping of the empty WÜS Q10 with a heat pump and the necessary peripherals. In particular, permits are required for the necessary work, some of which must be carried out on the city's compensation areas. Care is taken to minimise the permanent use and sealing of green spaces. Furthermore, contractual agreements with WISMUT GmbH are a prerequisite for the utilisation of mine water heat.  |   |

Package of measures no.: G.4

Fields of action Building energy supply

Description: Municipal heat planning is a strategic planning instrument that shows the path to an affordable, secure and climate-neutral heat supply for the City of Dresden in terms of space, time and concrete actions.

Based on the determined heat requirements of the buildings, potentials from renewable energies and waste heat sources, as well as the existing supply infrastructure, different heat supply areas are developed, which are adapted to the local conditions.

With a view to the existing supply infrastructure and its future development, municipal heat planning takes into account the district heating, electricity and gas network infrastructures and, in particular, their subsequent transformation and expansion plans:

Heat transformation plan for district heating
Gas grid transformation plan (GTP)
Electricity grid expansion plan (NAP)

Another important element of municipal heat planning is its close development with local energy network operators, the intensive involvement of relevant stakeholder groups, e.g. from the housing industry or the skilled trades, as well as extensive public relations work. The aim is to achieve cost-efficient planning and implementation of the heating transition as well as broad acceptance.

Objective: The primary objective of municipal heat planning is to develop a socially and economically viable transformation path for a greenhouse gas-neutral heat supply for the entire urban area of the City of Dresden.

Energy advice makes an important contribution to the implementation of the energy transition and fulfilment of the climate protection goals in the City of Dresden.  |   |

The municipal information and energy advice service for citizens, property owners and companies offers a central point of contact for actions to save energy, funding opportunities and the use of renewable energies in individual buildings or as a neighbourhood solution. In addition to the transformation of the heat supply and infrastructure, educating and advising the population and local businesses is another important focus on the path to climate neutrality in the City of Dresden.

# Neighbourhood concepts

Description: Neighbourhood heating concepts are a key pillar of the energy transition in the heating sector, in which entire neighbourhoods are considered instead of individual buildings in order to improve the efficiency of the overall system and tap further potential for renewable energy sources. A number of specific neighbourhoods are already being planned:

# Geystrasse" pilot project

A key pillar of the energy transition in the heating sector are so-called "cold" local heating solutions or networks (lowering operating temperatures compared to conventional systems, thus enabling heat generation from renewable energies) and neighbourhood heating concepts (looking at entire neighbourhoods instead of individual buildings to improve the efficiency of the overall system).
As part of the Geystraße neighbourhood concept, the existing and planned new buildings of the Olga-Körner nursing home run by the municipal company CULTUS gGmbH and the planned owner-occupied homes are to be connected to a "cold" local heating network. The heat will be extracted using geothermal probes and the brine pumped into the buildings will be raised to the required temperature level using brine-water heat pumps. The concept is rounded off by coupling with PV and solar thermal systems to power the heat pumps and regenerate the geothermal probes.
The result will be a heating solution that enables a high degree of self-sufficiency and largely market-independent, stable prices.

|  Title: Dresden Hydrogen Agenda  |   |
|  Description: Hydrogen plays a central role in achieving GHG-neutrality in Dresden. This applies in particular to the decarbonisation of Dresden's district heating and industry, which means that it is also highly relevant for process energy. It is also an important element in maintaining energy and supply security. The connection to the hydrogen core network, which has been announced for 2032 in Dresden, represents an important milestone. However, in order to be able to provide and ensure the corresponding quantities of hydrogen and the necessary hydrogen distribution networks for Dresden, coordination between the relevant players at municipal/regional level is absolutely essential. SachsenNetze GmbH should be in charge of bundling the hydrogen requirements and should also draw up the GTP on this basis. However, this process should be actively supported by partners such as the CoD, in particular the Office for Climate Protection and Climate Change Adaptation and the Office for Economic Development, SachsenEnergie AG as the district heating network operator, as well as key potential industrial hydrogen customers. The needs of industry and district heating must be recorded in as much detail as possible. A process for bundling the required quantities as a basis for specific purchase quantities must be defined and their procurement implemented. In addition, the necessary plans for the specific network conversion and, if necessary, the laying of a main pipeline from the hydrogen core network must be recorded and presented. An initial comprehensive draft must be available by the second quarter of 2025. Active stakeholder management, e.g. with regard to transmission system operators, federal and state governments, as well as association work must be actively pursued by the partners. Objective: By the beginning of 2025, a comprehensive determination, evaluation and bundling of all hydrogen requirements in Dresden as well as a process definition for the bundled procurement of hydrogen quantities must have been completed. All necessary infrastructure measures must also be identified by then and underpinned by feasibility studies and preliminary planning with regard to cost estimates, approval processes and time required, etc. The partners involved are actively lobbying all relevant stakeholders for the realisation of the hydrogen core network for Dresden in 2032.  |   |

|  Establishment and stabilisation of a regular climate protection exchange format in the CoD  |   |
|  Description: A temporary IEK project group was set up as part of the updating of the Integrated Energy und Climate Protection Plan. This was to cover the duration of the update. Due to the express wish of those involved in the project group to continue exchanging information on a regular basis even after completion of the update, the idea arose to transform the IEK project group into an informal working format at working level. In contrast to the project groups of the Climate Protection Working Group, no specific objectives are imposed on this exchange format and there is no obligation to report formally. This informal format is intended to serve as a dialogue platform where stakeholders can exchange ideas on climate protection topics and issues within the administration. The aim is to create an open forum in which ideas can flow freely. Unlike the focussed project groups, space is deliberately created here for informal discussions. The IEK project group in this new format is thus intended to be a kind of nucleus for new projects and actions in the area of climate protection. In 2024, this format will be used to discuss specific topics within the framework of the EU Urban Mission, focussing on areas outside the core group. Preparations for the acquisition of a climate protection platform are also on the agenda in order to improve the coordination and management of the various initiatives. The format also serves to provide regular information about ongoing climate protection activities within the administration. In this informal setting, participants can gain a holistic overview of progress and challenges, which creates the basis for effective collaboration and future projects.  |   |
|  Objective: To promote the internal network, exchange information and gain knowledge, share best practice examples, build up expertise  |   |

|  Implementation of a web-based climate protection platform in the CoD  |   |
|  Description: The climate protection activities and the climate protection strategy of the city of Dresden are to be dynamically developed, monitored and made accessible to the public using a web-based platform. There are already established solutions on the market such as Climate View, Kausal Watch, FutureProofed and GAIA. These platforms were developed specifically for monitoring/controlling and scenario modelling. The platform serves both as a tool for coordinating and harmonising internal work and between the organisational units involved, as well as for communicating progress to the public in a meaningful and interactive way. The city's climate protection efforts are made visible, which can increase public awareness of the objectives as well as the motivation for civic participation. The platform is a suitable tool for controlling actions quickly and permanently. The actions can be assigned to different persons responsible so that each person responsible for the action can enter the progress independently. It is also possible to set deadlines for reporting progress on actions. Thanks to an automated report, the implementation status of the actions of the urban climate protection strategy can be easily retrieved and presented to decision-makers as required (e.g. resolution control for the IEK, city council enquiries). The platform facilitates access to the city's climate protection strategy and its implementation and enables many stakeholders to obtain the desired information quickly and clearly. In the first step, the platform is to be used to map the reduction path of the IEK for Dresden, to show the GHG savings for the key measures (from the data of the reduction path calculator) and to underpin this with the actions from the action portfolio. Further actions are to be added on an ongoing basis. For the award process, requirements for the software (specification) are to be jointly formulated by potential measure sponsors. Subsequently, the climate protection platform is to be used permanently for controlling actions. Example: in 2023, the city of Dortmund published its climate plan on a climate protection platform. This can be found under the term "Dortmund Climate Barometer". Direct link: https://www.dortmund.de/themen/umwelt-nachhaltigkeit-und-klimaschutz/klimaschutz-und-klimafolgenanpassung/klimabarometer/  |   |
|  Objective: Easy access to the city's climate protection strategy (transparency) for stakeholders in the city administration and associated companies  |   |

|  Description: The Climate Advisory Board advises the City Council, its committees and the Mayor on all issues relating to climate protection and adaptation to climate change in the City of Dresden. The Climate Advisory Board comments on drafts and amendments to the City of Dresden's fundamental plans and programmes in the energy, mobility, housing and nature conservation sectors in good time before the City Council adopts its resolutions. The Climate Advisory Board also deals with the central issues of climate change adaptation in the City of Dresden. At the request of the City Council, one of its committees or the Mayor, the Climate Advisory Board comments on specific individual issues relating to climate protection or climate change adaptation in the City of Dresden. The composition of the Climate Advisory Board is regulated by corresponding statutes in conjunction with the main statutes. The parliamentary groups of the City Council, universities, companies and transport and environmental organisations are represented on the Climate Advisory Board. |  Title: Financing municipal climate protection  |   |
|  Description:  |   |
|  According to the municipal task system, climate protection is still a voluntary, not a mandatory task. This leads to corresponding problems with regard to prioritising the task of climate protection when the local authority's financial scope for action is limited. The CoD should therefore advocate a corresponding strengthening of the task as part of the political discourse.  |   |
|  Furthermore, there is no standardised definition of what qualifies as a climate protection measure in the municipal context. As a rule, climate protection measures also have a positive impact on other areas (energy saving, health aspects), making it difficult to draw a clear distinction. Climate protection is a cross-sectional task and should therefore be taken into account in all municipal activities, including the preparation of the municipal budget. This applies in particular to investments. If a climate protection measure is economically viable, it should also be implemented. Economical climate protection measures must not be dispensed with in order to secure the overall budget in the event of cost increases. For the preparation of future budgets, it should also be examined how climate protection can be made (more) visible in the municipal budget and which expenses and investments should be prioritised with regard to achieving GHG-neutrality or where municipal expenses and investments may be an obstacle or even counteract the municipal climate protection goals.  |   |
|  In the future, the financing of actions in the area of climate protection will continue to compete with the financing of other municipal tasks. It is therefore important to examine alternative financing models and, if necessary, to make greater use of tried and tested solutions. The expansion of contracting solutions, for example, should be mentioned in this context. In addition, existing savings from the implementation of climate protection measures could be used to finance new climate investments as part of a fund model. Another possibility is an annual "climate budget". This budget could be based on the CO2 emissions of the CoD and a corresponding price per tonne of CO2. This "climate budget" would be available exclusively for financing climate protection measures.  |   |
|  Another point is the fulfilment of municipal tasks in the form of municipal associated companies, which must also be increasingly involved in the implementation of climate protection actions (see also action O.6-03).  |   |
#

Dresden. Die2qu

Action plan for climate neutrality 2030

#

There are already established procedures in the procurement process that have a positive impact on both climate protection and financial aspects. This applies, for example, to the life cycle assessment when analysing the economic viability of a purchase. These considerations should be focussed on even more in the future. In the future, it should also be examined whether it is possible to expand the criteria to include a climate protection assessment (including climate impact costs), which would lead to a more qualified assessment.

Objective: To secure a sustainable financing basis for municipal climate protection measures.

# Greenhouse gas-neutral Dresden 2040 action programme

Description: The expansion of the climate protection measures named in the Integrated Energy and Climate Protection Plan (IEK) into a coherent action programme represents an important step. This programme is to be continuously expanded in the coming years in order to reflect the target path set by the city council for achieving green house gas neutrality. Particular attention will be paid to clearly defining the municipal scope for action and at the same time integrating recommendations for action for stakeholders outside the CoD's remit.

New findings, technologies and experiences can be integrated into the planning process through continuous further development, which is ensured by the constant addition of actions. An adaptive approach is taken to ensure that the interim targets set are achieved. If interim targets are not met, actions are adjusted to ensure progress towards the overall target. This flexible and adaptable approach enables an effective response to changing conditions and challenges.

The action programme is to be published (in a reduced form) in order to promote the participation and understanding of urban society. Publication not only serves to provide information, but also creates a basis for citizen feedback and participation.

Responsibility for maintaining and implementing the actions lies with specific organisational units that contribute their expertise in the respective areas. These organisational units play a key role in the implementation of the actions and help to ensure that the set goals are achieved. The overall programme is continuously monitored and maintained by the Climate Protection and Adaptation Unit. This controlling ensures that the action programme is implemented efficiently, enables regular reviews of progress and helps to successfully achieve the overall goal of a greenhouse gas-neutral Dresden.

Adjustments may also be necessary prior to realisation if framework conditions change fundamentally. Decision-makers are involved through dynamic processes, including readjustment, taking new actions and decision-making by the city council. A close dialogue between stakeholders, well-maintained data and regular monitoring ensure the effective implementation of the IEK and enable a well-founded assessment of target achievement.

Regularly comparing the greenhouse gas balance with the targets from the reduction pathway is crucial to ensure that the actions have the intended effect. Any deviations identified serve as a basis for adjusting the climate protection strategy and formulating new actions. The comparison of the GHG inventory thus becomes the central instrument for the transparent monitoring and control of IEK implementation.

The following specific tasks are to be performed as part of monitoring and controlling.

Submit a proposal for further activities required to achieve the goal

Continuous harmonisation and coordination of all parties involved
Ensuring effective implementation of the actions under the IEK
Promotion of a transparent exchange of information

Well-maintained data structure:

Regular updating of the data framework required
Updateability of data and assumptions on the reduction path
Continuous monitoring as an accurate and relevant basis for adaptation requirements
