Summarised strategy for residual emissions

The residual emissions that will remain from 2030 until green house gas neutrality is achieved by 2040 in accordance with the target defined in the IEK are already presented in the Integrated Energy and Climate Protection Plan (IEK). The strategy for dealing with these residual emissions has therefore been comprehensively developed and integrated into the concept. A large part of this strategy has already been incorporated into the previous chapters, as the methodological approach to dealing with residual emissions was derived according to the same principles as the other actions.

The unavoidable residual emissions of 5% of 1990 GHG emissions, which must be offset in order to achieve the net zero target, are treated as follows: The remaining GHG emissions must then be balanced by "negative emissions". Possible technical processes for binding greenhouse gases are, for exampleBioenergy with carbon capture and storage (BECCS),Direct Air Carbon Capture and Storage (DACCS) orthe material binding of CO_{2} in green polymers (green naphtha).

The technical GHG sinks are currently still theoretical considerations or research statuses, but not yet market-ready broadband applications. It is also not clear how durable such storage or utilisation solutions for binding CO_{2} are. In addition, these solutions for capturing and storing CO_{2} require a great deal of energy and resources. The point is that technical CO_{2} sinks can therefore only make a small contribution to meeting climate protection targets.

One methodological problem that has not yet been solved is the avoidance of "double counting". There are no climate protection obligations below federal level in Germany - all measures at state or municipal level are voluntary. In order to rule out "double counting" of compensation projects below federal level with federal actions, a procedure is required for managing and weighting compensation payments below federal level. Such a procedure does not currently exist. As a result, local and regional climate protection projects can currently only be recognised informally as offsetting measures, as there is always a risk of double counting. Further expert discussion of the topic is required at federal, state and municipal level.

Natural CO_{2} sinks are actions in the areas of land use, land use change and forestry. The sinks account for around 21,000 CO_{2} tonnes per year in the city of Dresden. This means that they only have a minor offsetting effect compared to the greenhouse gases emitted.

In conclusion, it should be noted that technical (and natural) sinks are important in order to compensate for the (few) unavoidable residual GHG emissions. It remains to be seen in what form these can contribute to this in the long term. At present, the focus of climate protection should definitely be on the far greater and relevant potential for avoiding greenhouse gases.

### Module B-3 Indicators for monitoring, evaluation and learning

The evaluation of the city's climate protection strategy requires precise indicators that go beyond the BISKO balance sheet. The energy and GHG inventory already provides important indicators, especially when broken down into the commercial, industrial and private household sectors. This enables a detailed analysis of developments per consumer group.

Reviewing the local expansion of RE to the electricity supply is another crucial aspect. This can be done by evaluating data on the feed-in of EEG plants and analysing the market master data register. This information provides insights into the progress of the integration of RE into the local electricity grid.

Dresden. Diezqur

Action plan for climate neutrality 2030

#

Another indicator relates to the heat consumption of private households in relation to total living space. This indicator makes it possible to monitor developments in energy-efficient refurbishment and user behaviour. By analysing heat consumption in detail, it is possible to assess the extent to which actions to increase efficiency and change behaviour are being implemented.

An additional indicator to illustrate the reduction of greenhouse gases could be the relationship between the energy consumption of companies and their economic performance. This indicator makes it possible to assess the efficiency of companies in terms of their energy consumption and serves as an important factor in the assessment of economic sustainability.

As part of the further development of the monitoring and controlling concept of the City of Dresden, a set of indicators is being developed that enables a continuous and concrete review of the development of individual areas and is based on the indicators of the CCC. The effort involved in obtaining the necessary data must be reduced to an acceptable level so that the indicators can be updated annually together with the preparation of the GHG inventory.

The indicators mentioned focus on the main shares of the city's GHG emissions that are based on the use of final energy (stationary energy and transport). The accounting methods for other emission sources have not yet been sufficiently determined, meaning that the impact pathway in the area of non-energy emissions cannot yet be analysed in the municipal context. An example of this is the survey of GHG emissions from agriculture, which is derived from national key figures and only determines GHG emissions on the basis of livestock numbers and known agricultural areas. These figures cannot be used to identify a trend towards sustainable and climate-friendly agriculture at municipal level. These would only show average trends at national level or, depending on the data source, at state level.

# 4.1.1 Municipal climate protection structures:

The City Council commissioned the Mayor with the decision to restructure the divisions on 26 January 2023:

Action plan for climate neutrality 2030

O

(1) to form a Climate Advisory Board to advise the City Council and city administration (Section 25 (10) of Dresden's main statutes; the City Council is currently deliberating on the proposal),
(2) to establish a coordination centre to accelerate the implementation of climate protection measures and to achieve the mobility transition, including the planning of roads and transport routes (new Section 28a of Dresden's main statutes)
(3) and to establish a staff unit for climate protection and climate change adaptation and assign it to the Environment and Climate, Law and Order division.

## Climate Advisory Board

The Climate Advisory Board advises the Mayor and the City Council on all matters relating to climate protection and adaptation to climate change. It consists of representatives of the City Council as well as knowledgeable residents from the areas of higher education institutions, municipal companies, environmental, transport and business associations who are to be appointed by the City Council in an election.

The Climate Advisory Board comments on drafts and amendments to the City of Dresden's fundamental plans and programmes in the energy, mobility, housing and nature conservation sectors in good time before the City Council adopts its resolutions. The Climate Advisory Board also deals with the central issues of climate change adaptation in the City of Dresden. At the request of the City Council, one of its committees or the Mayor, the Climate Advisory Board comments on specific individual issues relating to climate protection or climate change adaptation in the City of Dresden.

The composition of the Climate Advisory Board is regulated by a corresponding statute in conjunction with the main statutes. The parliamentary groups of the City Council, universities, companies and transport and environmental organisations are represented on the Climate Advisory Board. In connection with the establishment and coordination of the Climate Advisory Board, administrative work is required for the preparation and follow-up of the meetings, the preparation of documents for the Climate Advisory Board, the drafting and issuing of the Board's statements and the monitoring of the meetings (minutes, etc.).

On 18 April 2024, the resolution on the Climate Advisory Board was confirmed by the City Council.

## Central Climate Protection Strategy Coordination Centre

With the amendment of the main statutes (V1938/22), the Mayor was instructed to set up a "Central Climate Protection Strategy" coordination centre. The tasks of this coordination centre are carried out by the Mayor's management conference/advice service and prepared by the Climate Protection and Adaptation Unit. The tasks include

Ensure an overview of the various concepts and projects in the CoD with climate protection relevance (e.g. IEK, climate change adaptation concept, DMP+, INSEK, sustainability strategy)
Ensuring the acceleration of the central climate protection strategy (GHG-neutrality in accordance with the IEK resolution) in city administration projects. Coordination of the interfaces between the individual concepts and projects
Submitting centralised funding applications for the entire city administration and its own companies (e.g. funding according to municipal guidelines)
Ensuring the exchange of information between the various players in the CoD and relevant players in urban society
#

Dresden. Diezqcu

Action plan for climate neutrality 2030

#

With regard to the associated companies, the Mayor or the Deputy Mayor representing him as Chairman of the Supervisory Board and the members of the City Council as elected members of the Supervisory Board can represent the interests of CoD to the extent permitted by their function.

An annual resolution review to the City Council and the public on the implementation of climate protection targets is linked to the current GHG inventory and is carried out additionally and in more detail, in particular including the decarbonisation of the energy and heat supply, and is sent to both the Climate Advisory Board and the members of the City Council. In particular, it will be placed on the agenda of the Environment and Climate Committee for information.

## Climate steering group

The existing cross-departmental Climate Steering Group (SG), chaired by the Deputy Mayor for Environment and Climate, Law and Order and representing the Lord Mayor, advises on important cross-departmental decisions on the implementation of climate protection and climate adaptation on the basis of the half-yearly information and meets in preparation for the Lord Mayor's official consultation.

Important cross-departmental actions are, in particular, those that affect several business areas, key issues of budget and staff planning, prioritisation within the administration or cooperation with the associated companies. Other members of the Climate Steering Group are the Deputy Mayor responsible for the topics to be discussed. Proposals for the topics of the steering group can be submitted to the Climate Protection and Climate Change Adaptation Unit from all divisions, companies and project groups.

If necessary, proposals for decisions are drawn up on the basis of the preliminary deliberations of the Climate Steering Group, which are then discussed and decided on in the Mayor's official consultation and submitted to the City Council for a decision.

## Climate Protection and Climate Change Adaptation Unit

The Climate Protection and Adaptation Unit is the central administrative unit for the development and implementation of the energy and climate protection concept. It currently consists of six people. It also prepares the official consultation of the Mayor (coordination centre) on the topic of climate and establishes the connection between the various concepts and the implementation of the IEK, such as the Dresden Mobility Plan 2035+ and the Integrated Urban Development Concept (INSEK). The staff unit is also responsible for the planning and implementation of municipal heat planning and the associated heat turnaround dialogue.

## Formation of project groups:

The formation of project groups has proven to be an effective instrument for interdepartmental cooperation on key topics. These can involve co-operation between departments and municipal enterprises as well as municipal associated companies and other external players. Successful project group work requires the agreement of a common project objective, the appointment of a project manager and a joint working agreement with a project objective.

In certain project phases, other participants may be involved. Project groups can be formed between those agreed or on behalf of the Mayor or Deputy Mayor. As a rule, the responsible Deputy Mayor or

These contact persons communicate directly with the Climate Protection and Adaptation Unit, ensure communication within their organisational unit and prepare decisions at the necessary level in a binding and swift manner. # Establishment and stabilisation of a regular climate protection exchange format in the CoD:

In the course of updating the Integrated Energy und Climate Protection Plan, a temporary IEK project group was set up. This was intended to cover the duration of the update. Due to the express wish of those involved in the project group to continue exchanging information on a regular basis after completion of the update, the idea was born to transform the IEK project group into an informal working format at working level. In contrast to the project groups of the Climate Protection Working Group, no specific objectives are imposed on this exchange format and there is no obligation to report formally. This informal format is intended to serve as a dialogue platform where participants can exchange views on climate protection topics and issues within the administration. The aim is to create an open forum in which ideas can flow freely. Unlike the focussed project groups, space is deliberately created here for informal discussions. The IEK project group in this new format is thus intended to be a kind of nucleus for new projects and actions in the area of climate protection. In 2024, this format will be used to discuss specific topics within the framework of the EU Urban Mission, with a focus on areas outside the core group. Preparations for the acquisition of a climate protection platform are also on the agenda in order to improve the coordination and management of the various initiatives. The format also serves to provide regular information on ongoing climate protection activities within the administration. In this informal setting, participants can gain a holistic overview of progress and challenges, which creates the basis for effective collaboration and future projects.

# 4.1.2 Multi-level governance:

The CoD plays a decisive role in communicating overarching responsibilities at state and national level. The City of Dresden is a member of the Saxon Association of Towns and Municipalities (SSG). This organisation represents municipal interests at regional (Saxon) level. Dresden is also a member of the German Association of Cities and is represented in the various specialised commissions at political and technical level. As part of the EU City Mission, Dresden is also a member of the informal stronGERcities network, which regularly (every fortnight) discusses the progress of the CCC at employee level.

As part of these formats, the CoD initiates a constructive exchange with the federal government and the Free State of Saxony regarding the aspects identified below. This includes not only the transfer of relevant information, but also active participation and cooperation with the national authorities in order to strengthen the effectiveness of climate protection measures:

Create framework conditions for increased expansion of RE in the electricity sector in line with the targets of the Climate Protection Act and expansion path in line with the EEG 2023 (reference electricity),
Creation of an improved regulatory framework and improved subsidy conditions to accelerate the switch from fossil-fuelled heating systems to renewable solutions and to reduce the energy requirements of residential and non-residential buildings in a socially acceptable manner,
Implementation of the hydrogen strategy for the provision of largely GHG-neutral ("green") hydrogen with accelerated ramp-up of the hydrogen infrastructure and domestic hydrogen. The introduction of a hydrogen system must not lead to a lock-in of fossil structures - transitional solutions must be limited to a short period of time in a binding and plannable manner,
Improve the incentive system for switching to climate-neutral energy sources and resources, e.g. through appropriate  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  pricing over the life cycle. Pricing should be based on the expected follow-up costs. Climate-damaging resource utilisation must not be more cost-effective than climate-friendly resource utilisation,
Revision of grid fee structures for the fair financing of climate grids
Harmonise distribution grid fees and equalise regions affected by strong RE expansion,
Implement flexible grid fee structures for controllable loads (in accordance with BNetzA regulations $^{19}$ ),
Limiting future increases in emissions from the German natural gas mix (influence of LNG gas and non-conventional natural gas sources) through contractually binding requirements for climate-friendly production conditions in producing countries and regular inspections of plants.

## 4.1.3 Involvement of relevant stakeholders:

### The public

Climate protection requires not only technological and political solutions, but also the active participation of urban society and effective public relations work. Involving the community in climate protection initiatives not only creates an awareness of the urgency of the problem, but also promotes broad support for appropriate actions.

Raising public awareness promotes identification with climate protection goals and strengthens the sense of responsibility at local level. By involving different interest groups, diverse perspectives can be taken into account and more effective, accepted solutions can be developed. Public relations work plays a decisive role in clarifying complex issues and reducing reservations about environmentally friendly actions. Transparent communication about progress, challenges and possible changes creates trust and enables informed participation of the population in the climate protection process. The active participation of the community also promotes identification with climate protection goals and strengthens the sense of responsibility at local level.

For effective participation and public relations work in the area of climate protection, it is advisable to develop a structured participation concept and a communication plan. These instruments help to clearly define the objectives, target groups, communication channels and activities. In future, these instruments should be utilised to a greater extent in the CoD in order to bundle and consolidate the participation and public relations work carried out by many stakeholders in the CoD. This may also require support from external service providers or the reorganisation of communication in climate protection.

### Objective:

Creating awareness,
Activation of the urban community,
Transparency on climate protection activities,
Identification with climate protection strategy

Public relations work plays a decisive role in municipal climate protection, especially when it comes to anchoring the municipal climate protection strategy on a broad level and actively mobilising society. A first step is to build on many years of public relations work and to update and systematically stabilise it around the new objective. This not only enables the dissemination of information, but also creates a reliable point of contact for citizens to obtain continuous information on the progress of municipal climate protection.

The integration of the city's climate protection strategy on a broad scale requires targeted and transparent communication. Various means are to be utilised for this, including press releases, potentially a regular newsletter, the constant updating of the website and the use of social media. Through these channels, the Integrated Energy and Climate Concept (IEK) will be presented to the public in a clear manner in order to inform citizens comprehensively about the IEK content.

It is essential to actively involve the public in the process of implementing the IEK. This can be done through targeted information events and dialogue platforms where citizens are not only informed but also invited to contribute their opinions and ideas. Transparency in communication creates trust and enables the participatory organisation of municipal climate protection. Continuous and appealing public relations work thus not only promotes acceptance, but also the active participation of the population in the climate protection process.

# Culture - Climate network

As part of the "Culture for Future" programme, the "Dresden Charter for Sustainability in the Cultural Sector" was created and signed by 37 municipal, state and independent cultural institutions. The central objective of this charter is to support a comprehensive sustainability transformation of the cultural sector. A sustainability strategy is to be successfully implemented in all of Dresden's cultural institutions by 2030. Significant changes must take place over the next three years within the Fields of action of energy efficiency/resource efficiency (themed year 2024), climate-friendly mobility (themed year 2025) and risk management (themed year 2026) in order to make cultural institutions fit for the future.

This requires network management. This should look after the network and thus make the presence and explosive nature of the topic visible within the participating partners. It should continue, stabilise and further expand the cooperation and networking activities between the cultural institutions sponsored by the municipality and municipally funded stakeholders that have been initiated as part of "Culture for Future". Introduced exchange formats are to be further developed and the transfer of knowledge beyond Dresden is to be established.

## Energy

In order to actively satisfy the need for information on municipal heat planning as the City of Dresden, a contact point is needed in Dresden for the numerous and mostly localised questions relating to a secure, greenhouse gas-neutral and affordable energy supply. To this end, STESAD GmbH is to quickly set up a municipal energy advice centre to support Dresden's citizens and companies (Energielotse Dresden), which will complement existing services offered by other providers and partners. It closes existing information gaps and either directs citizens and companies to existing relevant services and partners or, if not otherwise possible, provides its own information and advisory services. The energy pilot also provides important information on the municipal heat planning, which is scheduled for publication in 2025. The role of the energy pilot is not to provide individual technical advice, but rather to provide information on general heating supply and energy topics and refer people to suitable experts as required.

|  4. identification of heat supply areas (technology preselection) based on the most cost-effective technology for the buildings in the respective area  |   |
|   | According to the WPG, municipal heat planning must identify so-called heat supply areas. This means recommending a priority type of supply, i.e. either a heating network, a hydrogen network or a decentralised supply solution, in an area. In order to make the selection of the type of supply as cost-effective and thus as socially acceptable as possible, a comprehensive heat planning toolset is used in Dresden's municipal heat planning. This includes different assumptions for various future developments with regard to technological and economic parameters, such as the development of heat pump, electricity, hydrogen or CO2 costs. A scenario calculator uses these assumptions and calculates the costs for all buildings in Dresden for all types of heat supply available for the respective building and identifies the most favourable for the respective scenario. In an iterative u process, the plausibility and any additional costs for network expansion and conversion are then taken into account and finally a target scenario is derived that minimises the overall costs of the transformation.  |

|   | On the basis of statistical distributions of income data, including from the municipal citizens' survey, we generate an indicator in combination with the determined current and future heating costs (see point 1) that forms the ratio between heating costs and statistical household income. # Dresden Future City Process - Citizens' Lab

Dresden initiated a future process in 2015, funded by the Federal Ministry of Education and Research (BMBF). Together with Dresden's citizens, administration and scientific support - Leibniz Institute of Ecological Urban and Regional Development (IOER) and the knowledge architects at TU Dresden - research was conducted into how the path to a sustainable and innovative city can succeed. The aim of the competition was to design a holistic and sustainable Vision 2030+ for Dresden together with citizens, science, local politics, business and administration, to plan the path to this vision and to implement it in the form of projects. The implementation took place in Field tests, i.e. with scientific support (test areas in public spaces). Successfully initiated or implemented projects have given Dresden the status of a "city of the future" with a model character. The projects dealt with the recycling of materials (material mediation), the sustainable use of food and the climate-friendly design of school playgrounds.

# Innovative participation formats: Mobile-O-Mat

With the interactive Mobil-O-Mat, citizens can actively help shape what the mobility of the future should look like. At the end, a broad picture of public opinion emerges from all the participants. This makes it possible to see how citizens visualise mobility and transport in Dresden. Using the interactive participation tool Mobil-O-Mat, all Dresden residents and people from the region were able to plan their mobility of the future for the state capital from 5 February to 17 March 2024. In addition, interested parties were able to meet with transport planners from the City of Dresden on 5 afternoons in the city's citizens' laboratory and use the Mobil-O-Mat there.

There are four goals for the Mobil-O-Mat:

climate-friendly mobility
travelling socially, healthily and safely
urban-compatible transport system
accessibility and economic stability

The Mobil-O-Mat simulates the effects of each decision and shows how these set goals are influenced. A certain value is stored for each action, which is paid into the four targets. Their status slowly changes colour in the display from grey to light green and dark green. The more completely the participants achieve the targets, the more balanced the planning for Dresden will be. With the Mobil-O-Mat, each participant has made a selection of measures and submitted their personal set of measures.

Public participation with the Mobil-O-Mat is now complete. Over 6,600 people from Dresden and the region took the opportunity to playfully help shape the transport planning of the future. A quarter of

The results of this public participation are incorporated into the Dresden Mobility Plan 2035+.

# Residential courtyard design - climate change adaptation and citizenship

Since the fall of the Berlin Wall (1990), Dresden's neighbourhoods have developed in different ways. It has become clear that there are major social challenges in certain neighbourhoods. This is why the City of Dresden is focusing even more strongly on neighbourhoods with special development needs and pursuing holistic and cooperative neighbourhood development, such as in the Prohlis district. By the end of 2022, the City of Dresden had drawn up the "Prohlis 2030+ Masterplan" together with residents and institutional stakeholders. An important goal of the state capital is to further improve the quality of life and amenities in Prohlis. The many large and green residential courtyards, which provide a pleasant climate and offer potential for attractive places to exercise and spend time, offer great added value for the district.

The inner courtyard within Spreewalder Strasse, Prohliser Allee and Georg-Palitzsch-Strasse was selected as the pilot for an ideas workshop on residential courtyard design. Part of this residential courtyard is owned by the municipality and is available as an open space with development potential. The communal area in the inner courtyard is currently fenced off and not open to the public. An ideas workshop was held in September 2022 to design the inner courtyard.

TU Dresden provided methodological support for the ideas workshop and used the digital tool U-Code. The inner courtyard and its features (e.g. large green areas) were digitally recorded and displayed on a screen for all participants to see during the ideas workshop. The aim of the event was to collect and develop ideas for the inner courtyard design together with the residents present and to visualise the results in a virtual 3D model at the same time. At the same time, actions for climate adaptation were examined.

# Training and deployment of climate coaches

In order to make the topic of behavioural change and energy saving more concrete, the concept of climate coaches was born and implemented at district level (Johannstadt district). Citizens were supported by climate coaches over a certain period of time in their everyday lives. The climate coaches pointed out where CO2 could be successfully saved at home or during leisure time. In discussions with the households, they found out where further savings could be made. The climate coaches provide advice, tips and ideas and remain in contact with the households for an individually determined period of time.

# Johannstadt climate coaches - Johannstadt.de

The successful concept is now to be expanded and further promoted. Additional volunteer climate coaches are being trained in the city districts and localities to advise other residents on ways to save CO2 in a target group-oriented manner and based on their own personal experience (special target groups may include schoolchildren, senior citizens, migrants and the financially disadvantaged).

The training and deployment of climate coaches in the city districts and localities promotes climate protection awareness, education on CO2 avoidance and concrete local commitment and networking. This reaches people who otherwise cannot be reached through general public relations work. The climate ambassadors are trained in various modules and empowered to pass on their knowledge. In this way, residents are sensitised to the topic of climate protection in everyday life at a low threshold and empowered to take action themselves. If desired by the local council or borough, small project ideas can also be developed in the course of the consultation and, if necessary, financed via the local budgets.

# Foundation of a youth climate council by BUND

As part of the updating of the energy and climate protection concept (IEK), school pupils were also involved. Based on this commitment, the idea was developed to formalise the participation of young people (14-17 years) and to establish a youth climate council that can contribute more effectively to the public discourse on climate protection. The project focuses on the intersection of promoting democracy, youth participation, climate protection and climate adaptation. The aim is to incorporate the ideas, wishes and visions of young people into the city's climate protection policy. The Youth Climate Council

# Participation in the AGORA Climate Change Adaptation Project - EU Climate Adaptation Mission

The City of Dresden and various stakeholders from Dresden are participating in the EU-funded AGORA project, which supports the overall objectives of the EU mission on climate change adaptation. The aim is to promote transformation processes in different social, economic and political contexts through transdisciplinary instruments and approaches. The focus is on democracy, climate justice, gender equality and equity as well as climate change adaptability and empowering citizens to proactively support decision-making processes.

The City of Dresden is acting as a pilot region. The basis for the work with various stakeholders is the current draft of the climate change adaptation strategy of the City of Dresden, which serves as the starting point for the discussions. Relevant stakeholders from the entire city are brought together in various workshops and using different methods. The focus so far has been on climate risks and adaptation needs and challenges, as well as on identifying what has already been done and still needs to be done by both local administrations and other relevant stakeholders.

# Energy game - NEUTRAL PATH: Energise

As an innovative new tool for activating and involving citizens, a board game was created as part of the EU project NEUTRAL PATH: Energise.

The aim is for players to engage with positive energy districts. By drawing various action cards, players learn behaviours and habits that save or waste energy. By using product and service cards on sustainable technologies or actions, players can actively transform their own district into a zero-energy district and win the game. The money available must also be used wisely.

Outlook and next steps

The submission of the CCC in September 2024 marks the first milestone in the climate protection strategy up to 2030. This lays the foundation for adapting the CCC/IEK-DMP35+. The IEK action portfolio will be continuously developed throughout the city, thus ensuring the iteration of the CCC. In concrete terms, the iteration of the CCC for 2026 means that only changes compared to the first submission status in September 2024 will be reported. In addition, further commitments will be collected and stakeholders activated for structural urban climate protection work. The aim of the iteration is to enrich the climate protection strategy and the systemic approach through a deeper understanding of the framework conditions and necessary adjustments and to close current gaps.

### Co-operation

Climate protection can only succeed together. The City of Dresden is already working with selected stakeholders in the city on climate protection in a variety of forms and on a project basis in various areas. Examples include formats such as the sustainability round table of Dresden's business community, the Culture for Future sustainability process of Dresden's cultural sector and the participation committee for the Dresden Mobility Plan MOBIdialog 2035+. These processes are to be systematised and embedded in an overarching city-wide climate protection participation strategy, whereby the stakeholder-specific approach will continue to be pursued and expanded. The IEK/CCC and the process for gaining commitments for the CCC provide a framework that contributes to activating the urban ecosystem for climate protection.

### Evaluation and monitoring

As part of the further development of the monitoring and controlling concept of the City of Dresden, a set of indicators is being developed that enables a continuous and concrete review of the development of individual areas and is based on the indicators of the CCC and goes beyond the previous GHG inventory. The energy and GHG inventory already provides important indicators, especially when broken down into the commercial, industrial and private household sectors. This enables a detailed analysis of developments per consumer group, but must be further developed to include additional building blocks for describing green house gas neutrality in terms of the territorial principle. In the IEK, this topic is already described in the "Monitoring and controlling" package of measures. It states that monitoring and controlling must above all be systematised and transformed into a clear, continuous and consistent process. The indicators are updated annually together with the preparation of the GHG inventory and other monitoring and reporting instruments (e.g. resolution controls). This also includes digitising the monitoring of measures using a web-based climate protection platform.

# 6.1 Decarbonisation concept for district heating

The conversion and expansion of the district heating system requires considerable financial and human resources, which are, however, limited. The individual potentials must therefore be examined and qualified for implementation step by step. With the help of permanent monitoring of the economic feasibility of individual decarbonisation potentials and the achievement of the target of complete decarbonisation of district heating in Dresden, an optimal and continuously updated decarbonisation path can be determined. The basis for this continuous monitoring are scenarios and price time series from a fundamental model to map possible developments, which are adapted to the current political framework conditions, as well as a heat demand forecast for the city of Dresden.

In order to decarbonise district heating, SachsenEnergie AG is currently planning to implement the measures shown in Illustration 6-1 which are shown as milestones up to the year 2045.

# Low Ex - reduction of the mains temperatures

Low Ex means lowering the temperature level in the district heating network. This means that heat losses, which are currently around 15 Percent, can be reduced in the district heating network. A lower temperature level also enables better feed-in of renewable heat into the network and cost-effective heat storage in unpressurised large heat storage tanks (temperature level  $&lt; 100^{\circ}\mathrm{C}$ ). In addition, the thermal stress on the plastic casing pipes used in the district heating network is reduced, thereby increasing their service life. This potential is one of the key prerequisites for the further decarbonisation of district heating. In order to be able to operate the district heating system with lower flow temperatures even in winter (nominal design case), it is necessary to redesign the heat exchangers in the approximately 8,000 consumption points in the district heating network and to reduce the network return temperature from the customer systems. This action is therefore one of the long-term goals with a time horizon for full implementation by 2035/2040. Until all customer systems have been fully converted, the network will continue to be operated at higher temperature parameters during periods with very high load requirements (a few hundred hours per year) for hydraulic reasons. For the remaining and therefore predominant part of the year, however, a low-ex mode of operation is already possible today.

# Installation of large heat pumps

Heat pumps can raise low temperature levels to usable temperature levels for district heating using electrical energy, environmental or waste heat.

Several large heat pump projects are currently being planned (Table 6-). Due to the considerable challenges involved in determining an exact location, clarifying the ownership structure and the economic operation of the heat pumps, it cannot be assumed that all projects can be realised at the present time.

Ring 30 - Waste treatment and recycling plant

Together with Stadtreinigung Dresden GmbH, SachsenEnergie AG is planning the construction and operation of a thermal waste utilisation plant in the form of a substitute fuel cogeneration plant.

With the construction of its own plant in Dresden and its connection to CoD's central district heating network, up to 80 Percent of the energy contained in residual waste can be utilised. By pretreating and drying the waste, recyclable materials still contained in the residual waste can also be fed back into material cycles and a high calorific value substitute fuel can be produced for heat generation at the same site. The waste handling and long-distance transport previously required for the waste volumes from the Dresden conurbation could thus be eliminated in the future. The quantities produced on site will also be safely disposed of on site. Natural gas previously used and imported from abroad to generate heat will be substituted on a pro rata basis. As a result, local material and energy cycles can be closed through this self-economic solution in municipal hands. For further details, see Volume II, actions G.3-01.

# Solar thermal energy

Solar thermal energy must be located in the immediate vicinity of the district heating network in order to be economically viable. There is also competition for space between solar thermal energy and PV. A 1 MW solar thermal plant is currently being built in Dresden Räcknitz, with commissioning scheduled for March 2024. There are currently no plans to expand further solar thermal areas for feeding into the central district heating network.

# Deep geothermal energy

Utilising deep geothermal heat in the district heating network would be able to supply it with emission-free and (operationally) cost-effective heat for a long time. However, the technological, geological and therefore financial risks are high. Preliminary investigations are currently being carried out to examine suitable methods of geothermal heat utilisation for the subsurface and the legal framework for mining. If the risks (geological and cost risks) are reduced to a viable level and technical feasibility is ensured, around 40 MW of heat output should be tapped using deep geothermal energy by the mid-1930s.

# Electrode boiler

In electrode heating boilers, water is heated by the direct use of electrical energy. An electrode heating boiler is already in operation at the Nossener Brücke power plant. In addition, two further plants with 40 MW each are to be built at the Reick site in order to absorb power peaks and ensure a heat supply with green heat. Further electrode heating boilers will be built at the Nossener Brücke site in the mid-
s, so that the total number of electrode heating boilers will decarbonise around 10 Percent of the heat supply.

### Heat accumulator

Two storage lines are already in place at the Reick innovation power plant. As the volatility of generation will continue to increase in the future, further heat storage facilities with a thermal storage capacity of 1,750 MWh are to follow at the Nossener Brücke site at the end of the 1920s. For cost reasons, the storage facilities should preferably be realised as unpressurised storage facilities (temperature level <100°C).

### Electrolyser

Waste heat is generated during the operation of an electrolyser. SachsenEnergie AG is currently examining whether it makes sense to participate in the operation of electrolysers. To this end, the construction of an electrolyser is planned, whose waste heat potential of 3.75 MWh_{th} could be utilised for the district heating supply. An expansion potential for Dresden and the surrounding area is estimated at up to 210 GWh_{th} , which can also be fed into the central district heating network depending on the location of the electrolyser.

### Conversion of existing CHP plants to hydrogen

As a result of the investigations carried out, a complete decarbonisation of Dresden's district heating generation fleet is only possible by using hydrogen in the CHP plants that are still required. On the one hand, this requires the connection of the Nossener Brücke and Dresden Reick power plant sites to the European Hydrogen Backbone (EHB) and the sufficient availability of hydrogen at economically viable prices. Secondly, the plants must be made hydrogen-compatible, which requires the gas engine CHP plant in Reick and the gas turbine CHP plant at Nossener Brücke to be converted.

### Generation balance and emissions path

If all the decarbonisation potentials presented for district heating are implemented at a certain point in time, this results in a change in the district heating generation fleet over time. Illustration 6-2 shows the annual generation balance for the central district heating network in the years 2021 to 2045. The generation balance is the result of a deployment optimisation calculation, which uses a mathematical optimisation model to calculate the optimal operation of each individual generation unit based on the minimum total generation costs. In addition to technical plant parameters, the parameters included in the model are the hourly price time series of an energy industry scenario, the forecast development of heat demand and the temperature curves of environmental and waste heat sources.

The future generation fleet of the centralised district heating network will be made up of various technologies. These will be utilised depending on the current electricity, CO_{2} and gas/hydrogen prices and thus work together optimally. When electricity prices are low, power-to-heat systems such as electrode boilers, large heat pumps and electrolysers can be operated economically and feed heat into the central district heating network. When electricity prices are high, the existing CHP plants, which will run on hydrogen in the long term, will be used primarily to provide heat in future. Heat from thermal waste utilisation, waste heat from industrial processes, deep geothermal energy and solar thermal energy can be provided independently of the electricity price due to low variable heat generation costs. By integrating large heat storage systems into the system, the generation and consumption of heat can be decoupled in terms of time, thus increasing the flexibility and efficiency of the district heating network.

# 6.1.2 Expansion and redensification

In the more densely populated neighbourhoods of the city, where the potential for renewable energy is limited, the use of decarbonised district heating represents an important climate-neutral heating alternative to existing natural gas or heating oil solutions. This applies to buildings in existing district heating areas that still use a natural gas connection and to densely populated areas that are not yet part of the district heating supply area but could in principle have the prospect of being connected. A provisional district heating map with assumed expansion areas shows Illustration 6-5. This was used as the basis for the PotEEGeb study and determined that of around 13,300 buildings supplied with district heating in 2021, there is potential for growth of a good 4,000 buildings in the existing and expansion areas. As part of the heat transformation plan, SachsenEnergie AG is investigating which potential for densification and expansion can be realised for Dresden's district heating network. The results will be taken into account accordingly in municipal heat planning.

# Outlook

Dresden has the potential to completely decarbonise its district heating and it is possible to switch to using  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  -free heat sources. The district heating system is already an important part of Dresden's heating infrastructure. Due to its significant share of Dresden's heating market and the possibility of providing fully decarbonised heat in the future, the district heating system will continue to play an important role in the success of the decarbonisation of Dresden's heating supply in the long term. As a result, the densification of the existing district heating area and the expansion of the district heating network are also being analysed in SachsenEnergie AG's current heat transformation plan.

# 6.2 Definition of green house gas neutrality

The concept of climate neutrality is not clearly defined. Particularly in the municipal context, there are different definitions due to different accounting limits and local requirements compared to the global or national context.

Definition of greenhouse gas (GHG) neutrality and climate neutrality:
#

Dresden. Diezqcu

Action plan for climate neutrality 2030

#

Climate neutrality is a state in which human activities have no net effect on the climate system. These activities include climate-impacting emissions, actions aimed at removing greenhouse gases from the atmospheric cycle and human-induced activities that have regional or local biogeophysical effects.
GHG-neutrality, on the other hand, "only" means net zero GHG emissions. Accordingly, the goal of climate neutrality requires a different and more ambitious policy than the goal of GHG-neutrality, as in addition to GHG emissions, all other effects of human activity on the climate must also be taken into account, e.g. land sealing by roads and settlements.

In practice, the two terms are sometimes used interchangeably. In the IEK, the term GHG-neutrality is correctly used for the target.

In addition to the concept of GHG-neutrality, there is also the approach of the CO residual budget $^{20}$  for evaluating climate protection targets. Global warming is largely dependent on the total amount of greenhouse gases emitted. These greenhouse gases remain in the atmosphere and have a climate impact over many decades (so-called Global Warming Potential - GWP). This means that not only the annual emissions, but also the cumulative GHG emissions over time are decisive for limiting global warming. When assessing climate protection targets, it is therefore not only the point in time at which GHG-neutrality is achieved that is decisive, but above all the amount of greenhouse gases that are emitted in a defined period of time. If the  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  residual budget is considered, the path to GHG-neutrality must be steeper than if there is only one defined end point. The  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  residual budget was calculated for Germany by the German Advisory Council on the Environment and is therefore more of a concept for assessing national climate protection targets. There is no such calculation for local authorities, so a separate budget was derived for Dresden from the national budget. The derivation of the  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  residual budget can be found later in this chapter.

The following guidelines for achieving GHG-neutrality were developed for Dresden as part of the development of the IEK and agreed with the Scientific Advisory Board in summer 2021:

Avoiding GHG emissions takes priority in line with the precautionary principle.
The top priority is to comply with a  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  residual budget in accordance with the UN Paris Agreement.
The path to GHG-neutrality is described on the basis of the reduction potential, the  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  residual budget and a time target.
Energy-related GHG emissions can be largely avoided through technical and behavioural actions.
Unavoidable GHG emissions (e.g. from agriculture or wastewater or from the upstream chain) amounting to a maximum of 5 Percent $^{21}$  are offset, if possible regionally.
Rebound effects are minimised.

Due to the city council's decision to focus the climate protection concept on a specific time target (V1818/22), it is necessary to deviate from the previously adopted definition in certain respects. This concerns the use of a  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  residual budget to describe the target. Due to the clear target for the year 2035 (alternatively 2040), the  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  residual budget can no longer be used as the sole target definition.

GHG-neutrality in Dresden should therefore be described by the following parameters

the reduction of greenhouse gases by 95 Percent of the comparative level of GHG emissions from 1990 to the target year,

This describes the target at a specific point in time. Expressed in figures, this means that energy-related GHG emissions must fall to 0.4 million tonnes per year by the target year. The calculation steps for determining this figure and further details can be found later in this chapter.

Dresden's participation in the EU City Mission adds a further ambition to its own target: to be GHG-neutral by 2030. The minimum requirement according to the definition of the EU City Mission is the reduction of greenhouse gases by 80 Percent compared to 1990. This does not correspond to the definition of (almost) net zero emissions for the CoD (reduction by 95 Percent), but gives the opportunity to include the ambition of the EU mission in the reduction pathway up to the target year 2035/2040 as an interim target. This interim target (80 Percent reduction) also fulfils the previous climate protection target of the IEuKK.

# Excursus: Calculation of the GHG-neutrality target values and the residual CO2 budget for Dresden

The GHG emissions for the base year 1990 are required to calculate the GHG emission level for the GHG-neutrality target. These were determined for the CoD as part of a study that is not publicly accessible. The basis is data from 1987 and 1990, as better data was available for these years. The corresponding per capita greenhouse gas emissions of  $15.4\mathrm{tCO2}_{\mathrm{eq / EW / a}}$  are included and published in the old GHG inventories before the switch to the BISKO methodology and balancing with the climate protection planner. Based on the per capita emissions, the absolute GHG emissions were calculated using the population of Dresden in 1990. These values are not corrected for weather, as they are the greenhouse gases actually emitted. The target values that can be derived from the baseline value are shown in Table 6-1 are included.

The interim target (80 % reduction) also fulfils the IEuKK's previous climate protection target of 5.8 tCO2_eq/EW/a in 2030. With a projected population $^{22}$  of 569,100 in 2030, absolute GHG emissions would then amount to 3.3 million tCO2_eq/a, which is well above the 80 % reduction target of 1.5 million tCO2_eq/a.

# Unavoidable residual emissions

There is no forecast for Dresden as to what unavoidable residual emissions would remain after all GHG reduction potentials have been exhausted. For Germany, around  $5\%$  of emissions[23] from 1990 are estimated to be unavoidable (residual emissions from landfill, agriculture and industrial processes). This approach is also used for Dresden, although it is expected that the actual unavoidable emissions from the above-mentioned emission sources will be less than  $5\%$  of the GHG emissions from 1987/90, as the proportion of emissions from agriculture in the CoD, for example, will be significantly lower than the national average due to its urban character.

# Derivation of  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  budget

In order to meet the Paris climate targets, humanity only has a certain budget of  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  emissions left (IPCC report,  $2018^{25}$ ). This budget is calculated for Germany according to the size of the population (SRU - German Advisory Council on the Environment) and a budget target for the CoD is derived from this. The lower limit for energy-related  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  emissions is 26.7 million tonnes to achieve a  $1.75^{\circ}\mathrm{C}$  target with a  $67\%$  probability. The upper limit for the energy-related  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  budget is approx. 41.6 million tonnes to achieve a  $1.75^{\circ}\mathrm{C}$  target with a  $67\%$  probability. Budgeting is based on the distribution methodology. While the global  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  budget was presented in the IPCC report in 2018 for different temperature rises and probabilities, the national budget distribution between the countries has not yet been bindingly
#

Dresden. Diezqcu

Action plan for climate neutrality

0

#

clarified. The countries therefore have a free hand in the interpretation. Different approaches are being discussed on how to deal with the budget consideration in relation to their own target formulation, which is primarily concerned with the question of fair distribution of the remaining budget. The German Advisory Council on the Environment recommends the population principle for Germany. The principle is based on the assumption that past emissions are not taken into account, but that the budget is assumed to be as ambitious as possible. Furthermore, an equal per capita emission right is assumed for every inhabitant of the earth. If the population increases, the budget would increase accordingly; if it decreases, the budget would decrease. This principle is also applied to Dresden. The calculated values can be found in Table 6-3 and Table 6-4.

A fundamental problem with using this calculation approach for Dresden is that the specific budget values are not compatible with the energy-related GHG accounting methodology of the City of Dresden. The BISKO methodology refers to energy-related GHG emissions and considers several greenhouse gases. The residual budget only takes  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  into account and summarises energy-related and non-energy-related  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  emissions.

The following assumptions were therefore made to transfer the  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  budget to the balance sheet boundaries of Dresden:

Assumption for calculating the energy and non-energy budget: The BISKO balance sheet of the CoD only takes into account the energy-related  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  emissions. Accordingly, it is necessary to deduct the non-energy-related  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  emissions from the budget. The National Inventory Report on the German GHG Inventory shows that around  $93\%$  of  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  emissions (only  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  not  $\mathrm{CO}$ ) $_{2,\mathrm{aq}}^{24}$  are energy-related. Applied to Dresden,  $93.2\%$  of the  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  residual budget would be assumed to be energy-related, while  $6.8\%$  of the budget would not be energy-related. The derivation of the shares is shown below in Table 6-2 below.

Assumption for evaluating the reduction pathways in the various scenarios of the IEK: The annual GHG emissions per reduction pathway are totalled up to a defined year (cumulative emissions) and compared with the  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  budget. If the cumulative emissions exceed the  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  budget, the budget is used up and the respective temperature limitation target is missed from a municipal perspective.

Assumption for dealing with  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  emissions and GHG emissions: There is currently no data on a residual GHG budget (i.e. covering other greenhouse gases in addition to  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ ). The GHG emissions according to the BISKO accounting are therefore deducted from the energy share of the  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  budget for the sake of simplicity. According to this calculation, the residual budget is more heavily burdened, i.e. tends to be consumed earlier.

# 6.3 In-depth categorisation of sectors according to BISKO $^{26}$

Private households: The sector includes all single and multi-person households (including people in shared accommodation). This therefore also includes all hostels and communal facilities that serve the purpose of accommodation or housing. A separation from the small business sector (cf. tertiary sector/other) should be endeavoured.

Industry: Manufacturing companies (industry and manufacturing trade) of manufacturing companies with 20 or more employees. This corresponds to the definition used by the statistical offices of the federal states to record energy consumption. It can be assumed that for other data providers (e.g. energy suppliers) the industry/manufacturing sector largely corresponds to the sectors as listed in the individual sections of the manufacturing sector.

Municipal facilities: Defined here as the total energy consumption of municipal facilities. A differentiation between administrative buildings, municipal schools and day-care centres as well as street lighting

is desirable for the presentation of key figures in the municipal climate protection benchmark. This sector also includes other municipal buildings and the energy consumption of municipal infrastructure facilities, including water/wastewater, roads and waste.

TTS/Other: This sector includes the energy consumption of all previously unrecorded commercial operations (trade, commerce, services, mining, quarrying, manufacturing with fewer than 20 employees and agricultural operations).

# 6.4 Determination of GHG emissions from agriculture

As part of the evaluation of the potential integration of GHG emissions from agricultural activities in Dresden, emissions from livestock farming in Dresden were analysed in 2020.

The livestock data reported up to 1 January 2020 was used to determine the balance using data from the CoD Veterinary Office. The emission factors for the various animal classes were taken from Thünen Report  $67^{27}$  from 2019. Based on this, it was possible to calculate the emissions of the three main greenhouse gases (methane, ammonia, nitrous oxide) in tonnes per year. The animal classes cattle, pigs, sheep, chickens, horses and goats were considered in the analysis. The Global Warming Potential (GWP) factors stored in the climate protection planner were used to calculate the CO2 equivalents of the greenhouse gases analysed (methane 25, ammonia 8, nitrous oxide 298).

Taking into account the GWP factors, approx. 4,520 tCO2_eq/a are emitted annually by livestock farming in the Dresden region analysed. The values and calculation steps are listed in the table.

# 6.5 Parameter set for scenarios

# 6.5.1 GHG emission factors

There are various methods and observation areas according to which emission factors for greenhouse gases are determined. The CoD uses the emission factors provided by the climate protection planner for the city-wide GHG inventory. These are provided by ifeu on the basis of the GEMIS database and studies by the Federal Environment Agency via the climate protection planner[28]. These values are currently stored in the climate protection planner until 2021.

Forecasts for the development of GHG emission factors are also required to map the development of GHG emissions. These forecasts come in part from the input of SachsenEnergie AG from its decarboni

## Development of the electricity mix emission factors

The GHG emission factors used for the scenarios for the reference electricity mix are taken from an IINAS study $^{29}$ , which presents emission factors with upstream chain and influence of transport and conversion, as used in the BISKO methodology.

For the reference scenario and the target scenarios, different expansion stages of RE in the German electricity mix were assumed. In the reference scenario, the assumptions are based on the NECP model of the German electricity mix for the support years 2030 and 2050 (with the assumption of a  $65\%$  share of renewable energies by 2030).

For the target scenarios, it was assumed that the political targets set out in the EEG 2023 are achieved (expansion of RE by 2030 with an  $80\%$  share). The IINAS study also provides values for the emission factor for the reference electricity (IINAS-EEG model)

Reference scenario, values from Table 4 of the IINAS study

Electricity local 2030 NECP, consumer side  $261\mathrm{g / kWh}$  (with upstream chain and transport)
Electricity local 2050 NECP, consumer side  $31\mathrm{g / kWh}$  (with upstream chain and transport)

Share for transport and conversion is  $8\mathrm{g / kWh}$  for 2030 and  $2\mathrm{g / kWh}$  for 2050; these values are used to convert values for target scenarios from the producer side to the consumer side

Electricity power plant fleet (IINAS-EEG) 2030 (Table 9),  $126\mathrm{g / kWh}$  on the producer side,  $134\mathrm{g / kWh}$  on the consumer side (with surcharge of  $8\mathrm{g / kWh}$ )

In the electricity mix factors used on the consumer side, no distinctions are made with regard to the withdrawal of electricity from different voltage levels. The influence of the conversion from MV to LV is therefore neglected in this analysis, as it will only have a minor influence on the overall emissions anyway.

Linear interpolation is used between the above-mentioned base years.

# Development of the natural gas emission factor

The GHG emission factor for natural gas also requires a forecast within the scenarios due to current developments in the energy sector. The constant GHG emission value previously used in BISKO, which is based on Russian pipeline natural gas, is no longer considered realistic due to the partial switch to liquefied natural gas. In order to take into account an appropriate premium or an updated value, two studies were used to estimate medium-term developments. The Ifeu $^{30}$  provides an overview of the different GHG emission factors of pipeline natural gas and liquefied natural gas (see Table 6-). However, this source does not state what proportions of liquefied natural gas are forecast. For this purpose, a study by ewi $^{31}$  was used to estimate possible future shares of LNG. In the NZE-H scenario, which corresponds to a climate policy scenario, LNG has a share of approx. 7 to  $8\%$  in 2030. The mixed emission factor for natural gas is calculated on the basis of these assumptions (see Table 6-). A value of  $7\%$  for LNG and  $5\%$  for hydrogen is assumed for 2030. For the year 2025/26, the values are set at  $18\%$  for LNG and  $1\%$  for hydrogen. The calculation results in a mixed emission factor of 0.246 for 2030 and 0.270 for 2025/26 - these are assumed to be the same for the target scenarios and the reference scenario. The intermediate values are interpolated linearly.

# Development of district heating emission factors

For district heating, the developments in the final energy source mix of SachsenEnergie AG's decarbonisation concept were offset against the GHG emission factors used in the IEK. In order to take into account the proportionate GHG emissions for the provision of heat from CHP plants, an allocation factor was determined from the empirical data in the climate protection planner for the district heating generation plants. The district heating network losses, which were assumed to be  $15\%$ , were deducted from this factor. As a result, an allocation factor of  $57.47\%$  was used, which reflects the GHG emissions share of the heat supply from the CHP generation plants. For the sake of simplicity, this was also used for the

# Emission factors for local renewable energies

Values for the GHG emission factors of renewable energies for 2018 and 2021 are taken from the climate protection planner. These GHG emission factors primarily account for a large proportion of specific emissions from the upstream chain, i.e. the production process for these plants, and hardly any from operational greenhouse gas emissions. The development of GHG emissions from the energy used in production and transport therefore plays a significant role for these technologies. This applies to the renewable energies biomass, solar thermal energy, photovoltaics and wind. For the GHG emission factors of the other renewable energy sources, a flat-rate reduction to  $50\%$  of the GHG emission factor from 2018 in 2045 (the same in all scenarios) is envisaged.

## 6.6 Calculation of the reduction path in the IEK

The reduction path calculator is a tool that shows the possible greenhouse gas reduction for energy-related greenhouse gas emissions for the city of Dresden over time in three different scenarios. An Excel tool was developed by the climate protection team to enable this visualisation.

The timeline covers the period from the starting year 2018 (current greenhouse gas inventory) to 2050. The choice of the long period beyond the target year 2035/2040 is intended to enable comparison within a constant observation horizon. It also makes it clear that the GHG reductions will continue to have an effect even after GHG-neutrality has been achieved in the target year.

In addition to the explanations in 2.2.2 it should be noted that the calculated final energy requirements are annual values - in MWh/a. These are therefore balance sheet considerations of the demand and supply side. The temporal progression of the feed-in from renewable energy systems is not stored, but is calculated over a year using the full utilisation hours. There is a deviation from this for PV systems on buildings. For these, a temporal resolution (6-hour block) of the respective system yield was also taken into account in the model that was created for the potential study on local renewable energy supply at building level (PotEEGeb). This was used to determine the coverage shares and surplus quantities of the PV systems. These are included in the reduction path calculator.

In order to be able to map the substitution and reduction potentials pragmatically but appropriately, various specifications must be made for the reduction path calculator, as shown below, which make the tool manageable.

# Breakdown of final energy consumption by energy source

For the use of heat pumps, the energy requirements are divided into environmental heat (renewable energy) and electrical drive energy (electricity). This is necessary because in future the greenhouse gas emission factor for the electricity purchased from the grid (German electricity mix) will be significantly lower than today. For the "heat pump" application, the electricity-related share of specific greenhouse gas emissions due to the electricity required for operation is comparatively high compared to other renewable energy applications such as wind, solar thermal and photovoltaics. In the case of wind, solar
#

thermal and photovoltaics, the influence of the electricity mix on the respective GHG emission factor comes primarily from the upstream chain (production, transport). For heat pump applications, the development of the GHG emission factor for the electricity mix is therefore taken into account by recording the energy flows separately as heating electricity and "emission-free" environmental heat.

For the GHG emission factors of the other renewable energy sources, a flat-rate reduction to 50 % of the GHG emission factor from 2018 in 2045 (the same in all scenarios) is envisaged.

## Dealing with the GHG reduction pathway for the mobility sector

Since no scenarios from the DMP+ process were available for the mobility sector at the time the IEK was finalised, the default values of the reduction path according to the Climate Protection Act (KSG) were used. The system described above for mapping the final energy requirements per energy source is also applied to the area of mobility. As no specific reduction paths per energy source were available from the DMP+ process in relation to energy demand, the reduction in the mobility sector for GHG was mapped by using mixed values. As soon as the exact scenarios are available, they will be stored in the reduction path calculator and thus also the reduction path for the final energy demand in the mobility sector.

In deviation from the reduction paths that were developed in advance for the mobility sector for 2035, 2040 and 2045 in accordance with the Climate Protection Act (KSG), an adjustment had to be made in the reduction path: the reduction to 0 % assumes that no residual emissions (e.g. from the upstream chain) arise. However, as shown in 6.5.1 (especially for reference electricity up to 2045), there are still emissions, such a generalised reduction is not in line with the BISKO system. For this reason, as no specific energy requirements per energy source were available that could be offset against the GHG emission factors used, the reduction path according to the KSG was used as a basis for the target scenarios. In the reference scenario, a flat-rate and linear reduction from 2025 to 2045 was assumed. Even if GHG-neutrality is achieved in 2045, a share of 5 % in the target scenarios and 10 % in the reference scenario is still assumed for residual emissions (upstream chain of electricity supply and mobility sectors that are difficult to convert, e.g. heavy goods and air transport). ## Dealing with local renewable electricity producers

By definition, the BISKO methodology applies the GHG emission factor of the German electricity mix to the final energy demand for electricity. From a physical/technical point of view, this is the correct approach, as a municipality can never be self-sufficient in terms of supply from the overarching electricity
#

Dresden. Die2qcu

Action plan for climate neutrality

0

#

grid. Due to the surplus or shortfall in electricity generation and fluctuating electricity demand, quantities of electricity are drawn from or fed into the higher-level grid at different times. This cannot be mapped in the municipal greenhouse gas balance, as the composition of the purchased electricity (specific GHG emissions) at the respective times for each municipality would also need to be known for a correct calculation.

The reduction path deviates from this agreement in that it is calculated using a local electricity mix for renewable energies. The advantage of this approach is that it also recognises and takes into account local efforts to expand renewable energies for electricity generation. These would otherwise "fizzle out" if the GHG emission factor of the German electricity mix were used. In reality, however, local efforts to expand renewable energies are also included in the German electricity mix. The GHG emission factor for the German electricity mix can only fall in future if the expansion of renewable energies is driven forward across the board.

![img-0.jpeg](img-0.jpeg)
Illustration 6-8System for taking local RE plants (local electricity mix) into account in the reduction path calculator

In the calculation model, the yield values of the potential renewable energy systems (wind, building-independent PV and PV on/at buildings) are added together. The required reference electricity is the difference between the final energy demand for electricity and the yield of the local renewable energy systems for the respective year. The GHG emission factor of the local electricity mix is then calculated from the individual values. It should be noted that only the RE plants from the potential analysis are taken into account. Other electricity generation plants that exist in the urban area are included in the federal electricity mix. The electricity used by the building's own PV systems is included in the local electricity mix in the calculation model, as this corresponds to the system for calculating greenhouse gas emissions. The calculation method does not differentiate according to the voltage level at which the electricity is consumed. In reality, of course, this also has an impact on the loading and unloading of the electricity grid infrastructure. However, this cannot be mapped in this framework. However, in order to obtain indications of developments in relation to the electricity distribution grid, surplus electricity used by the company and surplus electricity fed into the grid are analysed and presented separately.
#

The reference electricity is valued with the GHG emission factor of the federal electricity mix. Theoretically, this factor would have to be adjusted for the yields from the renewable energy plants that are taken into account separately for the local electricity mix. However, the shift in the specific GHG emission factor of the federal electricity mix is negligible in the calculation model due to the magnitude of the local RE potential compared to the total electricity generation in Germany (0.3% of Germany's total net feed-in in 2022).

The local electricity mix factor (non-BISKO) is used to analyse the reduction path. In the reduction path calculator, there is also an evaluation with the federal electricity mix - without taking into account the local RE plants. Due to a similar development (reduction of the GHG factor of the federal electricity mix and gradual expansion of RE plants and thus gradual reduction of the local electricity mix factor), both approaches result in almost congruent reduction paths. In Illustration 6-9 shows an example of the course of the GHG emission factors for the local electricity mix and the federal electricity mix for the Target_2035 scenario.

![img-0.jpeg](img-0.jpeg)
Illustration 6-9 Comparison of the GHG emission factor for the local electricity mix and the federal electricity mix using the 2035 target scenario as an example

This shows that the difference between the factors over time is small and therefore the non-BISKO method can be used for the evaluation. The visualisation of local efforts was given preference over adherence to the BISKO methodology due to its importance for the implementation of the energy transition. It should also be noted that this methodology is only used to calculate the GHG emitted and is not designed for forecasts. In future, both representations (BISKO with federal electricity mix and local electricity mix as a secondary balance) will be used to compare the reduction path with the current GHG inventory.
