# Wasaplatz/ Kreischaer Straße/ Rayskistraße

## Ziele:

Entlastung des Bereiches Wasaplatz/ Altstrehlen vom durchgehenden Kfz-Verkehr und umfeldgerechte Aufwertung der Straßenräume am Wasaplatz und in Altstrehlen,
Anbindung des Wissenschaftsstandortes Ost an Straße und ÖPNV und Umgestaltung der Wintergartenstraße zur Radroute in Richtung Großer Garten.

## Ansatz:

Prüfung bestandsnaher Ansätze zur Entlastung von Kfz-Verkehr am Wasaplatz im Zusammenhang mit dem Stadtbahnprogramm (Strecke Löbtau – Strehlen) wie z. B. Durchbindung der Hugo-Bürkner-Straße zur Teplitzer Straße und Verkehrsberuhigung am Wasaplatz),
Mittelfristig zweistreifige Führung des Kfz-Verkehrs durch eine neue Bahnunterführung in Verlängerung der Liebstädter Straße bis zur Reicker Straße und in einem 2. Abschnitt weiter bis zur Dohnaer Straße (2. Abschnitt für Ziel „Entlastung Wasaplatz“ von hoher Bedeutung),
Zweistreifige Verlängerung der Tiergartenstraße zur Liebstädter Straße mit Anbindung des Wissenschaftsstandorts Dresden-Ost und in 2. Stufe (nach 2025) bis Oskar-Röder-Straße,
Umgestaltung der Winterbergstraße und vollständige Ausstattung mit Radverkehrsanlagen,
Verkehrsberuhigung im Bereich Altstrehlen und Abstufung zur Hauptsammelstraße,
Langfristig bis 2025 ergänzende Umsetzung einer Stadtbahnlinie „61“ zwischen Wasaplatz - Zwinglistraße – Schillerplatz mit Anbindung des Wissenschaftsstandorts Dresden-Ost im Bereich Tiergartenstraße oder Grunaer Weg,
Es besteht vertiefender Untersuchungsbedarf zur verkehrlichen Wirkung der Maßnahmen unter Berücksichtigung der strukturellen Auswirkungen des neuen Wissenschaftsstandorts Dresden-Ost sowie einer Durchbindung der Liebstädter Straße bis zur B 172.

# Umgang mit weiteren stadträumlichen Defizitbereichen

Die weiteren stadträumlichen Defizitbereiche der Gruppe 3 (siehe Anlage 3) berücksichtigen 15 Stadtbereiche mit stadträumlichen Defiziten (besonders auch in den Ortsteilen). Verbesserungen sind hier durch Maßnahmen weitgehend im Bestand zu erreichen bzw. es liegen Planungen vor, den Bestand anzupassen. Teilweise bestehen auch nur in zwei Kategorien Konflikte.

Im Folgenden werden erste Lösungsideen beschrieben:

Albertstraße/ Archivplatz: als VEP-Maßnahme im Kapitel zum Fußgängerverkehr verankert,
Bautzener Landstraße/ Weißer Hirsch/ Bühlau: Verkehrsmengen werden perspektivisch nicht deutlich sinken, Umgestaltungen im Rahmen der Straßensanierung,
Bautzner Straße zwischen Hoyerswerdaer Straße und Martin-Luther-Straße: umfassende Sanierung als zweistreifige Stadtstraße, stadträumliche Aufwertung und Verbesserung der Querungssicherheit (wird als Umbaumaßnahme in 2013 umgesetzt),
Bautzner Straße zwischen Martin-Luther-Straße und Radeberger Straße: Sanierung im Nachgang des ersten Teilstücks von der Hoyerswerdaer Straße, zweistreifige, stadtverträgliche Gestaltung sinnvoll, neben der Kfz-Verbindungsfunktion spielen vor allem die Belange der Querungen zur Elbe sowie des ÖPNV und Radverkehrs eine wichtige Rolle,
Bischofsplatz: Sanierung erfolgt im Zusammenhang mit dem S-Bahn-Ausbau (HP Bischofsplatz, derzeit in Planung) – besondere Berücksichtigung des Querungsbedarfes und der Umgestaltung der großen (nutzlosen) Verkehrsflächen,
Blasewitzer Straße: Umgestaltungen im Rahmen der Bestandssanierung, Einfluss der Waldschlößchenbrücke auf die Verkehrsmengen (Nachher-Untersuchungen) sind geplant,
Borsbergstraße/ Schandauer Straße: umfassende Sanierung und Aufwertung ist in 2013 geplant,
Carolapatz: Umgestaltung und Aufwertung erforderlich, Sanierung der Haltestellen, Kompaktierung der Verkehrsanlage,
Fetscherplatz/ Fetscherstraße zw. Blasewitzer Straße und Stübelallee: umfassende Sanierung der Straße mit Haltestellen und Radverkehrsanlagen ist im Nachgang der Verkehrswirksamkeit der Waldschlößchenbrücke vorr. in 2015/2016 geplant – die Verkehrsmengen werden durch die Waldschlößchenbrücke in diesem Bereich tendenziell ansteigen, sodass grundlegende Veränderungen im Querschnitt zu Gunsten von Randbereichen kaum möglich erscheinen,
Hansastraße/ Schlesischer Platz/ Hainstraße: Oberflächensanierung, räumliche Aufwertung, Verbesserung der Querbarkeit, Verbesserung der Radführungen, Prüfung von veränderten Kfz-Abbiegebeziehungen im Zusammenhang mit Veränderungen an der Großen Meißner Straße,

# NeutralPath – Dresden as a pioneer on the way to becoming a climate-neutral city

## Summary NeutralPath

The Smart City project NeutralPath of the City of Dresden focuses on the urban heat and energy transition, especially the building sector with locations in the city districts of Leuben and Loschwitz. Altogether there are five cities that form the consortia network: Together with Zaragoza, Dresden is a frontrunner city that demonstrates feasible PCEDs, in close cooperation with the three follower cities Ghent, Istanbul and Vantaa. The EU is funding the project through the Horizon Europe program in the period 2023-2027 with around €19.6 million, of which around €7.7 million will go to the local demonstration project in Dresden alone. The city administration is investing over €1.3 million in this project.

## Project goal

The aim is to develop and demonstrate energy-positive, climate-neutral urban districts (Positive Clean Energy Districts (PCEDs) in Dresden (Germany) and Zaragoza (Spain) and the follower cities Ghent (Belgium), Istanbul (Turkey) and Vantaa (Finland). The project focuses on the building sector, specifically the decarbonization of the heat supply, the expansion of the use of renewable energy sources and the increase in the energy efficiency of buildings ("heat transition"). Electromobility and sector coupling are being addressed as integrated topics.

By demonstrating practical and affordable solutions for a future-proof energy and heat supply and by supporting cities in reducing CO2 emissions more quickly and setting up environmentally friendly innovation centers, we are making an important contribution to the development of a modern and sustainable city.

In parallel, paths are being developed to replicate, scale and embed PCEDs in the municipal administration and local housing sector in order to enable the long-term goals in NeutralPath for optimal climate protection in housing construction, energy supply and urban mobility.

The most important measures of the project are listed here:

Demonstration of climate-neutral neighborhoods (Positive Clean Energy Districts) in Dresden
Installation of photovoltaic systems and heat pumps to increase local energy production and optimise consumption
Construction of a low-temperature heating network as a prerequisite for the integration of renewable energies in Leuben
Energy-efficient renovation and modernization of existing residential buildings as well as installation of innovative insulation solutions in Pillnitz-Hosterwitz
As of 04.09.2024

DRESDEN 2030 NEUTRALPATH

Monitoring and performance monitoring of the installed systems in parallel: Establishment of innovation centers for PCEDs ( Climate -Neutral Labs) in Dresden

# Project areas and measures

The Positive and Climate-Neutral Energy Districts (PCEDs) initiative in Dresden integrates two pilot sites in Leuben and Loschwitz into an energy balance, which are particularly suitable due to their special potential to be repeated and expanded in Dresden. The exact locations in Jessener Straße and Pillnitzer Landstraße / Van-Gogh-Straße are shown in the thematic city map:

# Location A – Jessener Straße (Leuben district)

Jessener Strasse is located in Leuben, a district in the east of Dresden, near the inner city park Grosser Garten. The picture here is dominated by high-rise buildings that are typical of the residential complexes built in the 1970s. There is a supermarket and a kindergarten in the area, which enrich the everyday lives of the residents. The high-rise buildings on Jessener Strasse are connected to SachsenEnergie's district heating network, which has so far been operated primarily with fossil fuels. However, in cooperation with Vonovia and SachsenEnergie, an innovative project is being pushed forward to gradually make the district climate-neutral. This includes installing photovoltaic systems to make renewable energies available to residents. Vonovia is investing over two million euros in the project to transform the district into a model example of CO2-free living. Charging stations for electric vehicles are also planned so that residents can actively participate in the energy transition. These developments make Jessener Strasse an ideal test field for the integration of modern and environmentally friendly heating solutions. The project is supported by NeutralPath and jointly driven by SachsenEnergie and Vonovia. These measures make a decisive contribution to the decarbonization of the energy system in Dresden.

# Planned measures

Decarbonisation and flexibilisation of the district heating network: Connection to the central district heating network of SachsenEnergie, which is to be completely decarbonised by 2035
Expansion of thermal storage capacities: Additional storage capacities for flexible compensation of fluctuations in renewable energies
Local solar systems and tenant electricity model: Use of solar energy to operate heat pumps and other electrical heating equipment (sector coupling)
E-mobility concept: installation of fast charging stations and introduction of dynamic pricing models
As of 04.09.2024

DRESDEN 2030 NEUTRALPATH

# Location B – Pillnitzer Landstrasse/Van-Gogh-Strasse/Weberweg (Hosterwitz/Pillnitz district)

The site is a quiet residential area on Pillnitzer Landstrasse and has a loose development structure with two-storey apartment buildings of an older design. The district is not connected to the district heating network and is of central importance in municipal heat planning. The surrounding area is characterized by a good structural situation. The property with existing buildings from the 1950s and 1960s, some of which have been renovated, offers plenty of green space, a pleasant living atmosphere and extremely good conditions for piloting a PCED without a district heating connection. A large part of the energy required is to be generated and used directly on site with renewable supply systems. A local low-temperature heating network is to be installed in order to ensure an almost CO2-neutral heat supply and to achieve a positive energy balance in the district throughout the year. This location has the potential to become a model for sustainable building and living and to inspire other districts in Dresden and beyond to follow suit.

## Planned measures

Renovation of old buildings and new construction: renovation of existing buildings to zero or plus energy standards and new construction of energy-efficient residential buildings
Low-temperature heating network ("LowEx"): Implementation of a local low-temperature heating network to reduce CO2 emissions
Integration of renewable energies: Use of solar energy and other renewable sources to meet energy needs

# NeutralPath – Dresden als Vorreiter auf dem Weg zur klimaneutralen Stadt

## Was ist NeutralPath?

Das Smart City-Vorhaben „NeutralPath“ der Stadt Dresden hat den Fokus auf die urbane Wärme- und Energiewende, vor allem den Gebäudesektor mit Standorten in den Stadtteilen Leuben und Loschwitz. Fünf Städte bilden hier das Innovationsnetzwerk ab: Gemeinsam mit Zaragossa demonstriert Dresden als Vorreiterstadt machbare PCEDs, in engem Austausch mit den drei „Nachahmerstädten“ Ghent, Istanbul und Vantaa. Die EU fördert das Projekt über das Horizon Europe Programm im Zeitraum 2023-2027 mit rund 19,6 Millionen €, davon entfallen rund 7,7 Millionen € allein auf das lokale Demonstrationsvorhaben in Dresden. Die Stadtverwaltung investiert im Rahmen dieses Projekts über 1,3 Millionen €.

## Projektziel

Ziel ist die Entwicklung und Demonstration von energiepositiven, klimaneutralen Stadtquartieren (Positive Clean Energy Districts/PCEDs) in Dresden und Zaragossa als Modellstädte und Ghent (Belgien), Istanbul (Türkei) und Vantaa (Finnland) als Multiplikatoren bzw. Nachahmerstädte. Das Vorhaben hat den Fokus auf den Gebäudesektor, konkret die Dekarbonisierung der Wärmeversorgung, die Ausweitung des Einsatzes erneuerbarer Energiequellen und die Steigerung der Energieeffizienz von Gebäuden („Wärmewende“). Elektromobilität und Sektorenkopplung werden als integrierter Themen bearbeitet.

Durch das Vorführen praktischer und bezahlbarer Lösungen für eine zukunftssichere Energie- und Wärmeversorgung sowie die Unterstützung von Städten bei der schnelleren Verringerung von CO2-Emissionen und dem Aufbau umweltfreundlicher Innovationszentren leisten wir einen wichtigen Beitrag zur Entwicklung einer modernen und nachhaltigen Stadt.

Parallel werden Pfade zur Replizierung, Skalierung und Verankerung von PCEDs in der städtischen Verwaltung und hiesigen Wohnungswirtschaft ausgearbeitet, um die langfristigen Ziele in NeutralPath für optimalen Klimaschutz beim Wohnungsbau, bei der Energieversorgung und urbanen Mobilität zu ermöglichen.

Hier sind die wichtigsten Maßnahmen des Projekts aufgelistet:

Demonstration klimaneutraler Quartiere (Positive Clean Energy Districts) in Dresden
Installation von Photovoltaikanlagen und Wärmepumpen zur Erhöhung der lokalen Energieerzeugung und optimierten Verbrauch
Aufbau eines Niedertemperatur-Wärmenetzes als Voraussetzung der Integration von Erneuerbaren Energien in Leuben
Energetische Sanierung und Modernisierung bestehender Wohngebäude sowie Anbau der innovativen Isolierungslösungen in Pillnitz-Hosterwitz
As of 04/09/2024

DRESDEN 2030 NEUTRALPATH

Monitoring und Performanceüberwachung der installierten Systeme parallel dazu: Einrichtung von Innovationszentren für PCEDs (Climate-Neutral Labs) in Dresden

# Projektgebiete und Maßnahmen

Die Initiative *Positive und klimaneutrale Energiedistrikte* (PCEDs) in Dresden integriert zwei Pilotstandorte in Leuben und Loschwitz in eine Energiebilanz, die wegen ihres besonderen Potenzials, in Dresden wiederholt und ausgeweitet zu werden, besonders geeignet sind. Die genauen Standorte in der Jessener Straße und Pillnitzer Landstraße / Van-Gogh-Straße werden im Themenstadtplan angezeigt:

# Standort A – Jessener Straße (Stadtteil Leuben):

Die Jessener Straße befindet sich in Leuben, einem Stadtteil im Osten von Dresden, nahe dem Großen Garten. Hier prägen Hochhäuser das Bild, die typisch für die in den 1970er Jahren errichteten Wohnkomplexe sind. In der Umgebung gibt es einen Supermarkt und einen Kindergarten, die den Alltag der Bewohner bereichern. Die Hochhäuser an der Jessener Straße sind ans Fernwärmenetz von SachsenEnergie angeschlossen, das bisher überwiegend mit fossilen Brennstoffen betrieben wird. In Zusammenarbeit mit Vonovia und SachsenEnergie wird jedoch ein innovatives Projekt vorangetrieben, um das Quartier schrittweise klimaneutral zu gestalten. Dazu werden unter anderem Photovoltaikanlagen installiert, um erneuerbare Energien für die Bewohner nutzbar zu machen. Vonovia investiert über zwei Millionen Euro in das Projekt, um das Quartier in ein Vorzeigebeispiel für CO2-freies Wohnen zu verwandeln. Geplant sind auch Ladestationen für Elektrofahrzeuge, sodass die Bewohner aktiv an der Energiewende teilnehmen können. Diese Entwicklungen machen die Jessener Straße zu einem idealen Testfeld für die Integration moderner und umweltfreundlicher Heizlösungen. Das Projekt wird von NeutralPath unterstützt und von SachsenEnergie und Vonovia gemeinsam vorangetrieben. Diese Maßnahmen tragen entscheidend zur Dekarbonisierung des Energiesystems in Dresden bei.

# Geplante Maßnahmen

Dekarbonisierung und Flexibilisierung des Fernwärmenetzes: Anbindung an das zentrale Fernwärmenetz von SachsenEnergie, das bis 2035 vollständig dekarbonisiert sein soll
Erweiterung der thermischen Speicherkapazitäten: Zusätzliche Speicherkapazitäten zum flexiblen Ausgleichen von Schwankungen bei erneuerbaren Energien
Lokale Solaranlagen und Mieterstrommodell: Nutzung von Solarenergie für den Betrieb von Wärmepumpen und anderem elektrischen Heiz-Equipment (Sektorenkopplung)
E-Mobilitätskonzept: Einrichtung von Schnellladestationen und Einführung dynamischer Preismodelle
As of 04/09/2024

DRESDEN 2030 NEUTRALPATH

# Standort B – Pillnitzer Landstraße/Van-Gogh-Straße/Weberweg (Stadtteil Hosterwitz/Pillnitz)

Der Standort umfasst ein ruhiges Wohngebiet an der Pillnitzer Landstraße und weist eine lockere Bebauungsstruktur mit 2-geschossigen Mehrfamilienhäusern älterer Bauart auf. Das Quartier ist nicht ans Fernwärmenetz angebunden und hat zentrale Bedeutung bei der kommunalen Wärmeplanung. Die Umgebung ist von einer guten baulichen Situation geprägt. Das Grundstück mit Bestandsgebäuden aus den 1950er und 1960er Jahren, teilweise saniert, bietet viel Grünfläche, eine angenehme Wohnatmosphäre und äußerst gute Bedingungen für die Pilotierung eines PCED ohne Fernwärmanschluss. Dabei soll ein Großteil der benötigten Energie direkt vor Ort mit regenerativen Versorgungssystemen erzeugt und genutzt werden. Ein lokales Niedertemperatur-Heiznetz soll installiert werden, um eine nahezu CO2-neutrale Wärmeversorgung zu gewährleisten und im Quartier über das gesamte Jahr hinweg eine positive Energiebilanz zu erreichen. Dieser Standort hat das Potenzial, sich zu einem Vorbild für nachhaltiges Bauen und Wohnen zu entwickeln und andere Stadtteile in Dresden sowie darüber hinaus zur Nachahmung zu inspirieren.

## Geplante Maßnahmen

Altbausanierung und Neubau: Sanierung bestehender Gebäude zu Null- oder Plusenergie-Standards und Neubau von energieeffizienten Wohnhäusern
Niedertemperatur-Heiznetz ("LowEx"): Implementierung eines lokalen Niedertemperatur-Heiznetzes zur Reduzierung der CO2-Emissionen
Integration erneuerbarer Energien: Nutzung von Solarenergie und anderen erneuerbaren Quellen zur Deckung des Energiebedarfs

# 1 Introduction

In view of the rapidly advancing global climate change and the serious consequences of global warming, including for the health and prosperity of people in Dresden, the City Council of the City of Dresden declared climate protection to be a top-priority task for the provision of services of general interest by the city and municipal holding companies in 2020. This was accompanied by a mandate to the administration to revise the existing energy and climate protection strategy and to develop actions for climate protection together with relevant stakeholders and interested parties in urban society. Particular emphasis was placed on the social compatibility of all actions.¹

Climate protection is not a mandatory municipal task in Germany. Nevertheless, global warming, extreme weather events and resource scarcity are fundamental challenges that influence municipal action and pose a particular challenge to cities as places with high population, building and economic densities. Added to this are political and social developments such as wars, pandemics and economic crises, which cause additional burdens. In times of profound change and uncertainty, the city's most important mission is to guarantee the provision of municipal services for all citizens and to create a liveable, resilient and crisis-proof city of the future. Climate protection and adaptation is part of this mission.

The Saxon City of Dresden, located in the border triangle of Germany, the Czech Republic and Poland on the banks of the Elbe, has already undergone radical transformation processes in recent decades. Heavily destroyed in the Second World War, parts of the city were rebuilt as a model socialist city. Historic buildings were neglected and new residential areas were built using prefabricated housing. The political changes of 1990 brought further far-reaching changes: buildings were renovated and refurbished on a large scale and the (transport) infrastructure and technical equipment were modernised. Energetically advantageous structures such as the polycentric layout of the city with a good mix of uses, the extensive public transport network and the district heating supply in combined heat and power generation were retained and further developed. This urban structure makes it easy to transfer city-wide actions to individual sub-areas. Individual urban areas, in turn, correspond to the typology of large European cities, so that approaches are mutually transferable and a lively exchange between both eastern and western European cities characterised by their culture takes place and is further developed. In the mid-1990s, there was a switch from coal to natural gas for heating and district heating. Dresden has one of the most modern district heating systems in Germany. It is over 400 kilometres long and supplies over 125,000 Dresden flats as well as numerous public facilities and commercial properties.

Today, Dresden is an important European city of culture. Its economy and population are developing dynamically. Also known as the "Gateway to Central Europe", it maintains close, historically grown relations with the neighbouring states to the east. It has the densest network of research institutions in Europe, is home to the only German university of excellence in the new federal states and is Europe's most important chip centre. Dresden is also an important location for "greentech" in Europe. A total of over 360 players in the state capital are involved in green technologies. These include around 70

And in view of the diverse climatic challenges, strong growth can also be expected for greentech from Dresden in the coming years.

## Developments to date in the area of climate protection at CoD:

Climatic conditions in Dresden have changed significantly since the 1980s. The 30-year average annual temperature rose from 8.9 degrees Celsius (1961 to 1990) to 9.8 degrees Celsius (1991 to 2020). Since 1988, all but two years have been warmer than the average value of the climate reference period. The highest average annual temperatures measured have occurred in the extremely short period of time since 2014 from a climatic perspective. The average annual temperature exceeded eleven degrees Celsius for the first time in 2018, and since then this has been the case in the three other years 2019, 2020 and 2023. The warming trend can be observed in all seasons, albeit to varying degrees. It is strongest in summer at +1.3 degrees.

As early as 2008, the Federal Government provided a political framework for climate adaptation in Germany with the adoption of the German Strategy for Adaptation to Climate Change (DAS). From 2008, the City of Dresden therefore analysed and developed possible climate change adaptation measures with numerous regional stakeholders as part of the REGKLAM research project. Options and strategies for climate adaptation were developed in the agricultural and commercial sectors as well as in urban planning issues (e.g. building equipment, green space design). The project, which was funded by the Federal Ministry of Education and Research (2008 to 2013), created an Integrated Regional Climate Adaptation Programme (IRKAP) for the model region of Dresden, which is now gradually being put into practice. Dresden can now draw up and implement the climate change adaptation strategy that is currently being developed on the basis of this comprehensive programme.

Climate protection played an important role in Dresden even before 2013. By joining the Climate Alliance of European Cities in 1994 and signing the Aalborg Charter in 1995, Dresden set ambitious goals early on, such as reducing $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ emissions by at least $20\%$ by 2005. The city council adopted the first municipal climate protection programme as early as 1998, which was regularly updated with reports. A decisive step was the establishment of the climate protection office in 2010, which took over the coordination of actions. The strategic framework for a sustainable climate policy was further consolidated with the creation of the Integrated Energy and Climate Protection Plan (IEuKK) in 2011. The Integrated Energy und Climate Protection Plan (IEuKK) was developed as a pioneering instrument and played a decisive role in understanding the challenges of climate protection in Dresden and tackling them in an integrated approach. The IEuKK set a target for Dresden to reduce GHG emissions by $10\%$ every five years from 2005 to 2030. In addition, activities and actions in the area of sustainability increased. Since 2019, urban development has been increasingly geared towards the 2030 Agenda, the UN Sustainable Development Goals. The Integrated Urban Development Concept (INSEK) - the city's key planning instrument - is underpinned by the sustainability goals.

In 2020, the Dresden City Council instructed the Mayor to update and adapt the existing Integrated Energy and Climate Protection Plan from 2013 and to update it with new findings in its resolution (SR/007/2020) "Updating the climate protection goals of the City of Dresden". The City Council resolution also stipulated that "draft resolutions, in particular on construction projects, transport and energy

The Integrated Energy and Climate Protection Plan (IEK) was presented in January 2024. This was confirmed by the top management on 20 February 2024 and has now been submitted to the newly elected City Council on 9 June 2024 for political decision-making. In addition to the IEK, the City Council adopted the statutes for a new Climate Advisory Board of the City of Dresden at its meeting on 18 April 2024. The Climate Advisory Board will advise the City Council, its committees and the Mayor on all issues relating to climate protection and adaptation to climate change in the City of Dresden. It will be made up of representatives of the City Council as well as knowledgeable citizens from various relevant stakeholders in Dresden.

## Participation in global or European initiatives and programmes

International networking has always played a key role in local development. Early on after the political change in 1990, Dresden orientated itself towards the most important inter-municipal European and international networks. In 1992, Dresden became a member of the ICLEI network, which promotes sustainable development in municipalities. In 1994, the state capital joined the Climate Alliance. Since 2004, the City of Dresden has been a member of the EUROCITIES and POLIS city networks. In 2010/2011, Dresden held the presidency of POLIS. The regional transport association Oberelbe is also a member of the international network UITP. EUROCITIES, ICLEI, Climate Alliance and UITP are members of NetZeroCities.

In 2020, Dresden joined many POLIS partners in committing to the European climate targets in the transport sector. In 2020, Dresden was one of the signatory cities of the "Pledge Letter", a declaration of intent for the local implementation of the "Green Deal". This was presented to the Vice-President of the European Commission, Frans Timmermans. With the POLIS Pledge Letter, the cities reaffirmed that the climate protection targets and the 55 Percent reduction in emissions required by 2030 can only be achieved if the transition to sustainable urban mobility is accelerated and substantial changes are implemented at many levels. On 21 March 2019 in Brussels, the EU Commissioner for Transport, Violeta Bulc, awarded the City of Dresden second place (together with Basel) in the "SUMP Award", the European prize for sustainable mobility. Dresden had applied for this award with its transport development plan and its multimodal priorities. Back in 2015, the City of Dresden was recognised for its strategic transport development planning with an emphatic award from the EU Commission for Transport. The Commissioner for Transport of the European Union, Ms Violeta Bulc, also honoured the work done in drawing up the transport development plan (VEP) of the City of Dresden and its contents in Brussels.

The CoD has been a member of the Covenant of Mayors since 2016 and reports via the MyCovenant platform as part of the Sustainable Energy and Climate Action Plan (SECAP). This takes into account Dresden's integrated plans for climate protection, climate change adaptation and a secure, sustainable and affordable energy supply. As part of the current updates of the climate protection concept and the climate change adaptation concept, a joint report (SECAP) will be uploaded to MyCovenant for the end of 2024.

In January 2022, the Dresden City Council voted in favour of participating in the EU Green City Accord. With the Landscape Plan, the Integrated Urban Development Concept (INSEK), the Clean Air and Noise Action Plan, the Waste Management Concept and others, the City of Dresden has adopted and in some cases already implemented key resolutions that correspond in principle to the objectives of the Green City Accord and now reports regularly to the EU as part of the EU Green City Accord monitoring programme.

Dresden has already successfully participated in European collaborative projects in the past. As one of four Horizon 2020 Lighthouse Cities in Germany, Dresden has demonstrated its expertise in the development and transfer of smart city solutions at local and European level in the EU project MAtch-UP. In the new funding period, the CoD was also able to successfully acquire further EU projects from HorizonEurope and other EU programmes.

At the beginning of 2022, the City of Dresden successfully applied for the EU city mission "100 climate neutral and smart cities by 2030". Participation in the EU city mission is a continuation of efforts to combine, test and implement innovation-driven approaches at local and international level. Existing potential is to be fully utilised and, together with partners from the public, science and business, key projects and decisive steps towards climate neutrality are to be taken.

The city's goal of climate neutrality is not an end in itself. The consequences of global warming and climate change are also being felt in Dresden. By reducing greenhouse gases, protecting and strengthening the local ecosystem, expanding renewable energy and reducing dependence on gas, the city of Dresden aims to be robust and resilient for the future.

# 2 Goal: climate neutrality by 2030

## 2.1 The city's climate neutrality target for 2030

The objective of the Integrated Energy and Climate Protection Plan (IEuKK) adopted by the City of Dresden (CoD) in 2013 was to reduce $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ emissions in the city by 41 Percent between 2005 and 2030. Formally, the Integrated Energy and Climate Protection Plan (IEuKK) from 2013 represents the current climate protection decisions of the City of Dresden (BAU scenario).

A city council resolution on 30 January 2020 initiated the update of the Integrated Energy und Climate Protection Plan (IEuKK) from 2013.² This city council resolution set the goal of climate neutrality well before 2050 and thus formulated a concrete target for greenhouse gas neutrality for the first time and thus a political mandate for achieving green house gas neutrality over time. In 2022, a citizens' petition by Dresden Zero called for the 2035 target for Dresden's climate neutrality. The Dresden City Council recognised the urgency and commissioned the administration to present the goal of climate neutrality by 2035 (alternatively 2040) as part of the adopted revision of the Integrated Energy und Climate Protection Plan of the City of Dresden (IEK) when updating the Integrated Energy und Climate Protection Plan and to align the corresponding action portfolio with this goal.³ (However, this does not constitute a resolution).

The IEK includes targets for energy-related greenhouse gas emissions. Two target scenarios (2035, 2040) and a reference scenario (2045 in accordance with the Climate Protection Act) were analysed for the IEK and converted into corresponding reduction paths on the basis of concrete potential studies, some of which were specific to buildings and locations. Cost scenarios were also drawn up for the Fields of action of building energy and the expansion of renewable energies, which provide an initial orientation on the necessary financial framework conditions. The area of mobility, for which the VEP 2025plus transport development plan is currently being updated in the form of the Dresden Mobility Plan (DMP) 2035+, is a special case in point. As the development of specific scenarios and actions based on the Integrated Transport Model (IVM) is reserved for the DMP 2035+, the IEK includes a target for achieving GHG-neutrality for the mobility sector.

As a result of the IEK, GHG-neutrality by 2040 is proposed as a minimum target in accordance with the reduction path of the 2040 target scenario. The background to this is that achieving the pre-defined GHG-neutrality target by 2035 is not feasible even in the 2035 target scenario.

By setting the target year 2040, there is still sufficient leeway to achieve GHG-neutrality. Nevertheless, in view of the resolution on the Dresden Zero citizens' petition, all urban actions should be accelerated as much as possible in order to achieve GHG-neutrality as early as possible. In the mobility sector, a separate target pathway is assumed, which is based on the scenarios used in the DMP 2035+ and envisages GHG-neutrality by 2045. Specific interim targets are also proposed in order to maximise the binding nature of the target year 2040 and to ensure sufficient speed of implementation. These are also based on compliance with a paris-compliant residual budget. The expansion path according to the 2035 target scenario is proposed for tapping the potential for renewable energies, particularly in the areas of wind energy and photovoltaics (PV). This is backed up with specific annual generation targets. For the EU urban emissions and the target year 2030, an interim target was defined in the IEK that corresponds to an  $80\%$  reduction in the city's energy-related GHG from 1990 to 2030. Complete GHG-neutrality (with unavoidable  $5\%$  residual emissions) is to be achieved by 2040 according to the proposed resolution in the IEK.

The target pathway also takes into account that further commercial and industrial development is expected to lead to an increase in energy and resource requirements and the resulting GHG emissions. The developments known at the time the IEK was created were integrated into the potential analyses and the reduction pathway. Dresden was selected as the location for TSMC's first European semiconductor plant. The construction of this semiconductor factory will not only further strengthen Dresden and thus the largest microelectronics cluster in Europe, Silicon Saxony, but will also drive forward Saxony as an economic and technology centre as a whole and provide a significant boost to growth. This will create both opportunities and challenges for the city.

On the one hand, this involves investments totalling billions and the creation of numerous new jobs - both directly and indirectly, including for skilled trades and SMEs - and is of great importance for the region. On the other hand, it is currently of crucial importance for the city of Dresden to lay the foundations for a needs-based infrastructure for the north of Dresden, which not only includes the supply and disposal of water, but also guarantees a stable energy supply and efficient transport infrastructure and mobility. In addition, sufficient commercial space must be provided for the supply industry, for example. The expected creation of many new jobs is associated with an influx to cover the demand for labour. This will lead to increased demand for adequate housing and facilities such as daycare centres, schools and medical care.

All of these developments are caught between the conflicting priorities of climate-neutral and resource-conserving development. Not least because of this, Dresden is a unique testing ground in Europe for the compatibility of central European objectives: Strengthening technological competitiveness and security of supply while simultaneously implementing the Green Deal and a climate-neutral smart Europe.

Further and more detailed information on the climate protection strategy can be found in the Action Plan and in the CCC's Investment Plan.

# 2.2 Additional benefits for the city through increased climate protection measures

Climate protection aims to minimise the negative effects of climate change as far as possible. In the context of urban development, the goal of a climate-robust and resilient city takes centre stage. A city that not only withstands the challenges of climate change, but is also sustainable and adaptable, offers a variety of additional benefits. These include an increased quality of life, improved public health and the creation of attractive green and recreational spaces. In addition, sustainable urban design helps to reduce maintenance and flood protection costs. A particular focus here is on the city of Dresden, where targeted climate protection measures can both save costs and improve environmental and living conditions in the long term. The most important benefits and associated cost and savings potentials are presented in more detail below. The costs and cost savings mentioned relate to Dresden.

| --- | --- |
|  Avoidance of CO2 costs | All players in the city already have to pay costs for the emission of greenhouse gases. A distinction must be made between European and national emissions trading. Certificate prices in European emissions trading are expected to rise from 2027. A forecast by SachsenEnergie AG estimates the CO2 price for 2045 at 208 EUR/t, albeit with major uncertainties. This forecast serves to illustrate possible savings for Dresden if GHG-neutrality is achieved. This would mean an annual reduction of 3.2 million tonnes of CO2 compared to 2018 and potentially save costs of around EUR 668 million per year.  |
|  Reduction of climate impact costs - ecological benefits according to the damage cost approach | The damage cost approach published by the Federal Environment Agency (UBA) estimates the amount of damage caused to society by GHG emissions and the resulting climate change. For GHG emissions emitted in 2022, this damage cost rate is estimated by the UBA at 237 euros/t CO2 and for 2050 at 286 euros/t CO2, but with a higher weighting of the prosperity of current generations compared to that of future generations (time preference 1 Percent). If the prosperity claim were weighted equally (0 Percent time preference), the cost rate for 2050 would rise to 865 Euro/t CO2. This clearly shows that not only the achievement of GHG-neutrality itself, but also the total emissions still emitted until GHG-neutrality is achieved cause considerable damage and must therefore be included in the analysis. Based on the damage cost rates for a higher weighting of the current level of prosperity (time preference 1 Percent) and in comparison between the target and the reference scenario, the acceleration of the federal target to achieve GHG-neutrality in 2045 alone results in a reduction in the damage amount of around 3.2 billion euros by achieving GHG-neutrality in 2040 and meeting the CO2 budget for the 1.75 °C target.  |

# 3 Strategic priorities or key measures

The strategic priorities and key measures can be found in defined Fields of Action, which are outlined in the Integrated Energy und Climate Protection Plan. Some of these can also be implemented in several fields of action. (This is made clear by the numbers in Table 3.2).

# 3.1 Fields of action

There are nine Fields of action in the urban climate protection strategy. The Fields of action define strategic priorities with corresponding topics for action. These also include non-energy-related greenhouse gas emissions, for which initial actions have been identified in the IEK as far as possible, but for which no detailed analyses have yet been carried out.

|   | Fields of action (FoA)  |
| --- | --- |
|  1 | Building energy supply  |
|   | In the Fields of action of building energy supply, the focus is on actions for climate-neutral heat supply, as the heat supply of buildings plays a decisive role in the overall balance of GHG emissions. This area currently accounts for around 1 million tonnes of greenhouse gases, or around 27 per cent of Dresden's GHG emissions. At the same time, the building sector offers considerable potential for utilising renewable energies directly at the consumer level. A climate-neutral heat supply seems possible by 2040. This is essentially based on decarbonised district heating in densely populated urban districts and the use of ambient heat potentials by means of heat pumps in less densely populated urban areas, as well as small amounts of biomass and direct electric heating. The central planning instrument for an affordable, secure and climate-neutral heat supply is municipal heat planning. The decarbonisation strategy and the heat transformation plan of SachsenEnergie AG based on it for a GHG-neutral district heating supply in the future as well as the expansion and densification of the existing district heating area are closely related to this.
In addition, the city has the potential to generate around 715 GWh of electricity per year from PV systems on buildings. Data on the suitability of roofs and façades can be viewed publicly in the CoD's thematic city map.  |
|  2 | Expansion of renewable energies in the area  |
|   | The Fields of action "Expansion of renewable energies in the area" includes concrete potential analyses, in particular for PV systems and wind turbines, in order to increase generation from renewable energies. The building-independent PV potential is made up of photovoltaic systems on open spaces, car parks, agri-PV (combined use of agricultural land for farming and electricity generation) and floating PV (PV systems on bodies of water).  |
|  3 | Mobility  |
|   | For the transport sector (Fields of action: mobility), which accounts for around 24 Percent of Dresden's GHG emissions, an in-depth analysis of potential, including the necessary  |

|  3. the adaptation of Dresden's transport system towards sustainable, climate-neutral and flexible mobility | 3  |
|  4. the GHG-neutral city administration | 1, 3, 4, 6, 7, 9  |
|  5. increased cooperation and coordination of the city's climate protection measures | 9  |

The strategic priorities are characterised by the fact that they have the greatest impact on reducing greenhouse gas emissions in the city. At the same time, they must be implemented quickly in order to achieve short-term reductions. The necessary planning and implementation periods must be taken into account, particularly in the case of infrastructural changes.

# Key stakeholders:

In order to achieve the goal of green house gas neutrality, the city administration is dependent on many players and their cooperation. As the operator of the district heating network in Dresden, SachsenEnergie AG and SachsenNetze for the gas and electricity network are involved with the aim of dovetailing infrastructure planning as closely as possible in the process of creating the IEK and municipal heat planning. The involvement and integration of a large number of other important players (stakeholders) is also relevant. These include the city council and city districts as well as local councils, companies, banks, representatives from industry and trade, representatives from the scientific community, trade unions, associations, initiatives, the housing sector, property owners, energy cooperatives, banks and citizens. These stakeholders are already involved in a wide range of formats, processes and structures in the City of Dresden (see action plan). As part of the CCC and future climate protection work in Dresden, existing participation formats with stakeholders in the city of Dresden will be docked onto, further networked and made visible. The focus is on cooperation with stakeholders who are expected to have the greatest potential for CO2 savings.

# 4 Process and principles in the CCC

# 1. Strategy integration

As an overall framework document, the CCC describes the city's current climate protection efforts. The content is based on the Integrated Energy and Climate Protection Concept (IEK) as the overarching climate protection strategy of the City of Dresden. The Climate Protection and Adaptation Unit is responsible for the IEK. Findings and information are integrated from other city plans, the exchange with other city stakeholders and the inter-municipal exchange at national and European level. Various governance mechanisms such as the steering group or the Climate Advisory Board (see Action Plan) ensure horizontal steering and increased democratic participation in the administration. The iteration of the CCC will also be organically integrated into the (planning) processes and procedures of the CoD and build on existing reports and publications.

# 2. Co-operation

Climate protection can only succeed together. The City of Dresden is already working with selected stakeholders in the city on climate protection in a variety of forms and on a project basis in various areas. Examples include formats such as the sustainability round table of Dresden's business community, the Culture for Future sustainability process of Dresden's cultural sector and the participation committee for the Dresden Mobility Plan MOBIdialog 2035+. These processes are to be systematised and embedded in an overarching city-wide climate protection participation strategy, whereby the stakeholder-specific approach will continue to be pursued and expanded. With the IEK/CCC and the process for gaining commitments for the CCC, a framework has been established that contributes to activating the urban ecosystem for climate protection. Three different stakeholder groups are differentiated within the CCC.

![img-0.jpeg](img-0.jpeg)
Figure 2: Different levels of cooperation in the Climate City Contract

Level A - Kernteam Klimastadtvertrag

Das Kernteam erarbeitet gemeinsam die Inhalte des Action Plans und des Investment Plans; Mitglieder des Kernteams tragen übergeordnete strategische Planungen oder akteurs- und gebietsübergreifende Maßnahmen bei; die Mitglieder des Kernteams sind Teil des Konzerns Stadt

# Level B - Kooperationspartner

Kooperationspartner unterschreiben eine Selbstverpflichtung zum Klimaschutz; Kooperationspartner zeichnet eine große Einfluss aus, diese arbeiten eigenständig und gemeinsam mit der Stadtverwaltung an der Erreichung der Klimaschutzziele; Kooperationspartner tragen eigene Maßnahmen bei, die das Ziel der Stadt zur Erreichung von Treibhausgasneutralität in relevantem Maß unterstützen;

# Level C - Unterstützende

Unterstützende können auf Eigeninitiative hin relevante Beiträge zum Klimaschutz in den Prozess einreichen; im Unterschied zu den Kooperationspartnern handelt sich dabei um individuelle Beiträge, die die Unterstützenden eigenständig umsetzen können

The adoption of the IEK and the creation of the CCC are closely linked. A crucial point here is that public relations work on the climate protection strategy and the CCC can only begin once the IEK has been officially adopted by the city council. The first step is to involve relevant stakeholders before the actions are presented to the wider public. Following the resolution, a targeted campaign will be launched in order to obtain further, low-threshold commitments from the urban community (Level C - supporters). These actions are planned for the update of the Climate City Agreement in 2026. Further contributions and commitments from other stakeholders (core team, cooperation partners) are also expected.

# 3. Evaluation and monitoring

As part of the further development of the monitoring and controlling concept of the City of Dresden, a set of indicators is being developed that enables a continuous and concrete review of the development of individual areas and is based on the indicators of the CCC and goes beyond the previous GHG inventory. The energy and GHG inventory already provides important indicators, especially when broken down into the commercial, industrial and private household sectors. This enables a detailed analysis of developments per consumer group, but must be further developed to include additional building blocks for describing green house gas neutrality in terms of the territorial principle. In the IEK, this topic is already described in the "Monitoring and controlling" package of measures. It states that monitoring and controlling must above all be systematised and transformed into a clear, continuous and consistent process. The indicators are updated annually together with the preparation of the GHG inventory and other monitoring and reporting instruments (e.g. resolution controls). This also includes digitising the monitoring of measures using a web-based climate protection platform.

# 4. Transparency

Transparency of climate protection measures and their effectiveness is an important tool for increasing knowledge about and acceptance of climate protection measures. The City of Dresden is already working with various digital tools to make the effects of climate change (heavy rainfall) visible to the public in the city's digital city map. A web-based climate protection platform is intended to present the implementation status of climate protection actions in a low-threshold and transparent manner. This should also have a steering effect and ensure timely readjustment.

# 5. Multi-level governance

The CoD already works with the state and federal government in various forums and at various levels. Specifically, the CoD is active in the German Association of Cities and also in Saxon municipal associations and representative bodies. There is informal cooperation with the other German mission cities via the mission process, with regular jour fixe meetings. The German mission cities appear together under the label "stronGERcities". As a mouthpiece for the EU and federal level, this cooperation between the mission cities is to be stabilised. In addition, Dresden and Leipzig are already exchanging information with the state level on an informal level in order to jointly process experiences and findings from the European city mission process and make them effective for Saxony.

# 6 Learning and capacity building
#

Dresden. Dc2qcu

Commitments to climate neutrality by 2030

#

The transformation to a climate-neutral and resilient city of the future is a mammoth task. This requires expertise and knowledge, the search for new solutions and the acquisition of new knowledge about data, impacts, systems, players and new business models. In addition to an internal training programme, which is increasingly focusing on climate protection and climate change adaptation, the City of Dresden is also involved in intensive learning and capacity building as part of various European projects. In the EU project Neutral Path, the City of Dresden is an active partner in the capacity building programme. Through the EnAct4CleanCities pilot project, Dresden is actively exchanging ideas with the other Saxon mission city of Leipzig in order to exchange information on the modalities, challenges and possible solutions in the field of municipal heat planning. An exchange of knowledge with Saxon and international municipalities/cities is also planned as part of this pilot project. Acquired knowledge from the work on climate protection and within the framework of the EU City Mission will also be passed on in exchange with Ukrainian pilot cities as part of the Horizon Europe project U_CAN. These diverse exchange platforms enable extensive learning and adaptation of own solutions and strategies.

# 7 Iteration and further development

The CCC is a living document, just like the framework for action set out in the Integrated Energy and Climate Protection Programme. Once it has been adopted, it will be expanded into a more comprehensive programme of climate protection actions in a permanent process and integrated with the requirements of the CCC. In concrete terms, the iteration of the CCC for 2026 means that only changes compared to the first submission status in September 2024 will be reported. In addition, further commitments will be collected and stakeholders activated for structural urban climate protection work. The aim of the iteration is to enrich the climate protection strategy and the systemic approach through a deeper understanding of the framework conditions and necessary adjustments and to close current gaps.

A further 136 kWp are to be installed on carports yet to be built as so-called solar carports. After full commissioning, this action will lead to a total reduction of approx. 127 tCO2/a from 2028. GHG savings of at least 5%/year are already being achieved within energy management compared to the average (2020-2023). Compared to the base year 2020, 194 tonnes of CO2 have already been saved in Scope 1 and 2. Further actions have already been taken and are in line with our values. As part of Dresden's industrial landscape, Novaled is committed to supporting the important topic of climate protection as part of sustainability and the associated energy transformation. We have supported the Dresden Sustainability Round Table from the very beginning and have been happy to share our experiences, plans and ideas with the other industrial partners. This network is an important communication forum because we can only accomplish this mammoth task together. As a research institution and leading provider of organic materials developed in-house and innovative technologies for premium OLEDs for displays, luminaires and OSCs, we see it as our duty to not only focus on the performance of the end product right from the start of its life cycle, but also to accompany its manufacturing process from the laboratory specification through to production. We see our responsibility as extending beyond the factory gate and also take this into account in our supply chain. Novaled and our suppliers and business partners are equally committed to protecting the environment and the climate. This is anchored in our Code of Conduct. Natural resources are to be used sparingly and conserved wherever possible. The use and consumption of resources during production and the generation of waste of any kind, including water and energy, must be reduced to the necessary level or avoided. The use of natural resources shall be reduced through practices such as material conservation and substitution, sharing, maintenance, reuse, remanufacturing and recycling or upcycling. In addition, Novaled and its suppliers are committed to the continuous development and use of environmentally and climate-friendly products, processes and technologies. Applicable laws and regulations regarding the prohibition and restriction of certain substances in production must be strictly adhered to, and labelling for recycling and disposal must be carried out. |  Theaterpädagogisches Zentrum Sachsen e.V. | The key foundation and driving force behind our work is the promotion of participation. This value includes the promotion and safeguarding of diversity, sustainability and democracy. Participation of all people, regardless of age, gender identity, sexuality, origin, physical characteristics, health or social status, abilities and religion, means taking responsibility for diversity. Securing this in the long term - not only in an ecological sense, but also for society as a whole - is a requirement of sustainability. And democracy is not possible without participation, and participation is inconceivable without the participation of all in the joint shaping of life and society.

In addition to the content-related component of our work, we also pay attention to ecological sustainability. For example, we purchase most of our office materials from the provider MEMO AG, our printed materials are printed almost exclusively on recycled paper in Germany and we use the TeilAuto car-sharing scheme.

We have been a signatory to the Dresden Charter for Sustainability in the Cultural Sector since 2022.

Participation also includes the topics of gender sensitivity and gender equality, which we actively address. As a cultural education institution with a high proportion of collaborations with schools, we follow the recommendations and guidelines of the Saxon State Ministry of Culture when it comes to gender-equitable spelling.

However, we also favour solutions in the area of digitality that ensure participation, require and enable participation, promote self-determination and justice and, last but not least, are transparent and sustainable. The software we use is almost exclusively open source and non-proprietary, available to everyone free of charge, accessible and respects privacy. This applies to the operating systems of our office computers (Linux). This also has the additional effect of saving costs, as there are no expensive licences or fees. This also applies to our digital exchange platform, a managed Nextcloud with a server location in Germany, our website and email hosting, our research software (here, too, the server location is in Germany), the platform for schools and teachers (TaskCards, a Thuringian start-up) and our conference tool, a BigBlueButton instance on the server of the data security initiative "Senfcall".

As transparency, data protection and self-determination are important to us, we only use services that are EU GDPR-compliant and do not have a business model based on the accumulation and use of private data. This is another reason - along with many other more ethical considerations - why we are not represented on social networks such as Facebook, Instagram and Twitter.  |

|  Ostrale - Zentrum für zeitgenössische Kunst e.V. | Mobility: Our employees, artists, etc. are expressly encouraged to cycle, walk or use public transport such as buses and trains for their daily commute. This not only promotes their health, but also helps to reduce their ecological footprint. For business trips, we place particular emphasis on using the train or bus instead of your own car or plane wherever possible in order to promote a more environmentally friendly and sustainable method of travelling. In this way, we contribute to climate protection and support the transport revolution.

Exhibition logistics: In order to increase efficiency and conserve resources, we prefer to use groupage transport instead of individual private/DHL shipments. Although we endeavour to implement this practice consistently, the use of DHL shipments outside Europe cannot be avoided in every case. Our aim is to reduce the environmental impact and optimise logistics processes by bundling shipments.

Waste and waste water: All employees and visitors to the biennials are required to separate waste conscientiously in order to ensure an effective recycling rate. Organic waste is disposed of in our in-house compost, which not only helps to reduce waste, but also to produce valuable compost for our green spaces. These actions promote the sustainable use of resources and support our efforts to protect the environment and avoid waste.

Sustainable use of resources and building materials: We attach great importance to reusing objects that are no longer suitable for the exhibition. We creatively remodel these objects and give them a second life. A good example of this is old partition walls, which we use to make planters or seating. These actions not only help us to reduce waste, but also significantly extend the useful life of the materials. This is in line with our philosophy of sustainable resource utilisation and promotes the responsible use of our building materials.

Regional procurement: We are increasingly favouring local suppliers over large platforms such as Amazon. We pay particular attention to purchasing materials from the region in order to support the local economy and ensure short transport routes. An outstanding example of this is our long-standing partnership with "Holzmüller Sachsen", which supplies us with high-quality wood and at the same time emphasises our sustainable procurement strategy.

Green infrastructure: As part of our sustainability initiative, we have rainwater collection points on all gutters and small roofs on the site. Our garden is intentionally planted with a variety of crops to promote biodiversity and support sustainable nutrition. These plants are watered exclusively with collected rainwater, which we obtain through our rainwater harvesting systems. In  |

By implementing the packages of measures 1-8, VON ARDENNE can achieve final energy savings of 1,430,110 kWh/a on the Weißig campus, which corresponds to 43.7% of the baseline. In addition, CO2 savings of 608.59 tonnes per year can be achieved, which corresponds to 48.9% of the baseline. The realisation of the project will be ensured by an investment company of the VON ARDENNE Group - regenery GmbH. |  Deutsche Werkstätten Hellerau | Communication & participation:
All areas of action are organised in cooperation between HSE, Facility and Sustainability Coordination. The people in charge regularly take part in networking meetings in the region, such as the IHK-Umwelttreff or DD-Stammtisch "Nachhaltigkeit", for further training and dialogue. At the Climate Neutrality Network, Deutsche Werkstätten works with other companies to learn all about preparing their own GHG inventory.
Internally, the individual departments are specifically sensitised in order to be able to optimally implement targeted actions.

Energy efficiency:
In the area of energy efficiency, Deutsche Werkstätten is focussing on the conscious use of energy. The solar panels on the building enable a proportionate, environmentally friendly consumption of electricity for production and the offices. Consumption is regularly reported and evaluated so that concrete recommendations for action can be made. For example, the production hall is being converted to so-called "intelligent" ceiling lighting - this means that the light is controlled by sensors and only partially. Fundamental attention is being paid to keeping the machinery modern and therefore energy-efficient.

Waste & recycling:
Waste disposal is based on conscientious waste separation, whereby care is taken to feed as much material as possible into recurring recycling loops, such as aluminium and various plastics. Any wood waste is thermally utilised directly on site and used for heating. Cardboard scraps are perforated so that they can be used as filling material for packaging and thus reduce polystyrene consumption.

Mobility:
Deutsche Werkstätten Hellerau is building on the increased use of public transport for commuting and business trips. The offer of railcards and the combined DVB job ticket with the Germany ticket are an integral part of more resource-efficient mobility. There is also a widely used range of job bikes.  |

|  UNU-FLORES | Climate Protection Measures taken by UNU-FLORES

background
The initiative to create a comprehensive sustainability vision and strategy for the United Nations system began at the meeting of the Senior Officials of the United Nations Environment Management Group in 2018 and was reinforced by the Secretary-General's call for increased internal efforts to address climate change. Phase I of the Sustainability Management Strategy, introduced in 2019, concentrated on environmental sustainability in management. Phase II of the Strategy, endorsed in 2021 seeks to implement environmental and social sustainability in United Nations system policies, programming and support functions. UNU-FLORES was involved in the development of the strategy and is dedicated to being a role model for integrating environmental and social sustainability considerations across its work. UNU-FLORES is committed to reducing its environmental footprint and striving for sustainability in all functions and procurement activities within the institute.

procurement
Before requesting a purchase, the purchase's necessity must be carefully considered and discussed with the respective supervisor. Once approved, the requestor is responsible for finding potential suppliers and checking the social and environmental impacts of the product. Providers that are regularly used are listed. Aspects that should be considered, depending on the available information:
Environmental Impact: Evaluate the product's lifecycle footprint from raw materials to disposal.
Resource Efficiency: Choose products that reduce resource use, waste, and energy consumption.
Materials: Opt for materials from renewable or responsibly managed sources.
Emissions Reduction: Select low-emission products and suppliers, e.g., vegan/vegetarian catering.
Social Responsibility: Ensure suppliers practice ethical labour, fair wages, and safe conditions.
Supply Chain Transparency: Verify social and environmental claims through supply chain transparency.  |

Non-debatable: -
Vegan/vegetarian and organic catering for events
Local drinks and tap water for meetings

Avoid procurement if the item is available for rent
Strongly recommended: -
Local food whenever possible
Local companies for services and procurement
Products made from recycled or upcycled materials
If water bottles are necessary (field trip), a sustainable brand must be used

laptops
UNU-FLORES purchases laptops with the maximum extended warranty period offered by the provider, including incidental damage insurance and worldwide next-business-day support. That way laptops can be used and maintained by the manufacturer until the end-of-life period according to the standards published by UNU's IT. Given frequent travels, the reliability and worldwide coverage of the warranty justify replacing laptops after the extended warranty period expires. Beyond the 5-year period, laptops that are in good shape shall be retained as spare laptops for temporary assignments, for colleagues that work exclusively from within the duty station (e.g., non travels), or as shared computers in meeting rooms. Otherwise, laptops are sold internally or donated to external organisations for a second life. The purchase of modular laptops is explored and supported.  |

aspects to be considered for the travel planning:
From both a sustainability and cost perspective, virtual engagement should be preferred over travelling whenever feasible and effective.
The number of participants required to travel should be minimised.
Selecting the appropriate transport mode can significantly impact travel’s environmental footprint. Efficient and sustainable travel options should be prioritised. Trains should be considered the primary choice whenever possible. For flights, preference should be given to direct routes and economy class over business class. Even if more time or money is needed, choosing a train over a flight should still be considered and discussed with the supervisor.
To raise awareness about the climate impact of travel and facilitate emission compensation data collection, travellers must calculate and complete their CO2 emissions in a provided table. Confirmation of this information in the travel request is mandatory. Travel requests lacking this data will not be approved.  |
|   | 5. waste disposal
UNU-FLORES follows the German system for waste separation. As the respective signs show, the following waste streams are separated in the office:
Paper and Cardboard: This category includes newspapers, magazines, cardboard packaging, and other paper-based materials. Only clean paper should go into that bin - plastic must be removed. Used paper towels and greasy paper belongs to the residual waste.
Packaging Waste: Packaging materials such as plastic, metal, and Tetra Pak cartons are separated and collected for recycling.  |

The ETC: ETC is the largest network of publicly funded theatres in Europe with 63 members in 31 countries. Green Theatre Committee of the ETC: The Green Theatre Committee is working to become a climate-neutral network by 2030. Founded in 2021, the Green Theatre Committee is made up of experts from the ETC network (including Joachim Klement, Staatsschauspiel Dresden) and external experts and contributes to the development of knowledge, analyses and guidelines on sustainability. It plays a key role in realising the ETC's ambitious goal of becoming a climate-neutral network by 2030, as set out in the ETC Sustainability Action Code.
